This chapter details the world of the Garou — the 
werewolves' physical environs, theirculture, institutions, friends 
and foes. 


«Che Gothic-Punk 


Worlo 


Turn on, tune in, burn out in the acid rain 
— Sisters of Mercy, “Black Planet” 

The world of Werewolf is not our own, though it resembles 
ours in many ways. Werewolf is set in a Gothic-Punk world — 
a World of Darkness. Externally, little differs between our 
world and this World of Darkness — the established religious, 
social and political institutions are much like those ofour own 
planet. The World of Darkness, however, isa film noir environ- 
ment— thecitiesare labyrinthine and gloomy, the bureaucrats 
are corrupt, and the important people have skeletons in their 
closets. It is a world of extremes — the rich are usually filthy 
rich, and their money has warped them in the manner of The 
Great Gatsby's characters. The poor are much more numerous 
and visible here, and their lot is even more desperate than in 
our world. Starvation, even on the streets of the First World, 
isnot unknown, and the poor often provide prey for the urban 


-——— UO— PERDER ERIPUIT 


predators — the werewolves, vampires and other night stalk- 
ers. 


Chapter Two: Setting 


LZ ———— I? 


Night City seemed designed by a bored researcher with one 
finger on the fast-forward button. 
— William Gibson, Neuromancer 


Gothic describes many of the world's physical features 
massive, brooding, dark and ominous. The sense of oppression 
and conspiracy is much greater here, and everything seems to 
be done with an ulterior purpose in mind. Buildings are huge, 
looming edifices, often encrusted with gargoyles and other 
statuary. Housesoften stand forcenturies, giving many suburbs 
a "haunted house" ambience. Corporate and government 
agents are faceless and impersonal, dressed severely in black 
suits and ties. The Church is enormous and ritualistic, with 
strong similarities to the medieval Catholic Church. Eeriness 
and foreboding pervade the world, and there always seems to 
be a storm in the sky at the right time. 

Punk is the other half of the equation. The counterculture 
ofthe cities, sick of the oppressive physical and social tableau, 
rebel with words, dress, music and often violence. The down- 
towncoresofthecitiesarefilled with underground clubs, street 
gangs and bands inciting aggression and revolution. Crime is 
perennial and open, and people are generally tougher and 
more cynical than in our own world. 

Obviously, not every troupe will wish to range the full 
spectrum of Gothic-Punk. The Storyteller is free to add as 
much or as little Gothic and/or Punk as she wishes. It should 
be noted, however, that Werewolf is largely a game of mood. 
Without a suitably tense, strange atmosphere, the game can 
lose much of its flavor. 


«Che Cities 


Nocturnal motions as we leave our cocoons 

Antennae tuned to inhuman vibrations 

Shaping the cities of the world that's to come. 

— Killing Joke, "Inside the Termite Mound" 

The cities of the World of Darkness are oppressive places. 
Eventheirhuman inhabitants find them bleak, and the Garou 
despise them as sores on the skin of Gaia. Though the Bone 
Gnawer and Glass Walker tribe have to some degree en- 
croached into the cities, urbanareasremain largely thedemesnes 
of the Wyrm. The very earth-spirits are warped and mutated 
by such places; at best they become fey and strange, at worst 
they are actively malevolent. 

It is important to understand that werewolves, particularly 
those not of the Bone Gnawer or Glass Walker tribe, are not 
at home here. Werewolves view the concrete wastelands in 
the same manner that a “civilized” human views the Amazon 
Jungle or Sahara Desert. As previously noted, the cities are 
largely under the sway of the Wyrm’s creatures, and many 
urban spirits display overt hostility toward the Garou. Mali- 
cious city elementals mock the werewolf travelers, lead them 
into traps or even attack them outright. The hated vampires 
constantly watch for Garou, slaying any they find. The loom- 
ingskyscrapers house Wyrm-corrupted businesspersons, while 
the rusting tracts of industrial wasteland are haunted by 
fomori. Werewolves do not lightly venture beyond the con- 
fines of the forests and hills. 


The Wilderness 


This is the forest primeval. 

— Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, “Evangeline” 

If the “civilized” areas of the World of Darkness are bleak 
and oppressive, the wildernessis little more comforting. When 
one views the sullen, shadowy expanses of tangled forests, 
windswept moors and stagnant swamps, one can understand 
why the humans of the Gothic-Punk world so frantically cover 
the land with cities. 

Theambience of the World of Darkness pervades the wilds. 
The line of demarcation between city and wilderness is 
narrow, and once it is crossed, the human traveler finds herself 
in an alien land. The wilds have long been guarded by the 
savage Garou and their Impergium, and thus humans instinc- 
tively fear and distrust the dark places beyond the city lights. 
The dwellers of the rural towns tend to be sullen, insular and 
secretive; many strange events quietly take place in such 
locales. Rural folk know they are not alone in the wilds, and 
superstition runs rampant through the hamlets and truck 
stops. City newspapers write off the occasional bizarre slayings 
as the deeds of serial killers and the like, but the natives know 
better. 

Even the Garou, who call the wilds home, know but a few 
of the land's secrets. Indeed, the wiser Garou reiterate that 
some of Gaia’s mysteries are better left unknown. Gaia is not 
alwaysa loving mother, and werewolves have long known that 


| 


certain places in the wilds are taboo. Garou who foolishly 
venture into these places often do not return; their more 
prudent brethren sigh and shrug. Such is Gaia's way... 


Wolves 


Wild wolvesare virtually extinct. A few scattered packs can 
be found in Europe and the United States, but wolves are 
largely relegated to zoos and breeding projects. Only in 
Alaska, Canada, Scandinavia, and Siberia can they still be 
found in their natural habitat. 

This situation is disastrous for the Garou. Lupusaccountfor 
as little as 13% of the total Garou population — the wolf side 
of the werewolves’ blood has dangerously thinned. Garou 
require the strength of both their human intellect and their 
wolf instinct if they wish to be whole. The growing imbalance 
has rendered many werewolves weak in body and mind (this 
isparticularly true of the inbred Silver Fangs). Many werewolves 
go insane; others succumb to the lure of the Wyrm. 

It might be noted that wolves do not suffer from the 
Delirium; however, an enraged werewolf in Crinos form will 
terrify even the wolf packs. Packs viewing such a sight usually 
leave their territory, never to return. In this age of dwindling 
forestsand encroaching towns, sucha migration usually proves 
fatal for the wolves. 

Garou may communicate with wolves just as they can with 
humans; this is an automatic action if the Garou is in Lupus or 
Hispo form. Garou in Homid, Glabro or Crinos form will not 
always be understood. 


The Present Day 


Wandering between two worlds, one dead, 

The other powerless to be born. 

— Matthew Amold, “Stanzas from the Grande Chartreuse” 

The stagnation and confusion of the modern world have 
affected the Garou moreso than most creatures. Whereas in 
the old days there were vast expanses of wilderness and clearly 
defined territories, in this age of cities and factories there is 
simply not enough land to go around. As the sacred sites are 
drained of energy by human negligence and supernatural plots, 
the tribes and septs must compete for mundane and spiritual 
resources alike. Werewolves of different tribes, who once 
looked upon one another as brethren, now glare at one 
another with lowered ears and slitted eyes. Even the packs vie 
with each other for supremacy. 

Many Garou, afraid or tired or simply disgusted, turn away 
from their duties, seeking freedom in anonymity. Indeed, 
apathy and malaise are among the Wyrm's greatest allies. The 
Garou have, in large part, lost their fire. They roll around with 
each other in the dirt, seeking dominance over some petty 
pack; desperately clutch at their ever-shrinking domains; or 
simply retreat to the stagnant security of tedious human 
existence. Cynicism and callousness are increasingly com- 
mon, and the numbers of ronin (Garou who turn away from 
their pack and tribe) swell with each new moon. 


Chapter Two: Setting 


an ee // 


Now, in this age of smog and concrete and rust, when the 
Garou are at their nadir, the Wyrm will strike in earnest. Will 
the planet succumb to the great cancer, or can a handful of 
determined warriorssomehow stem the onrushing maelstrom? 


Other Lycanthropes 


The ancients were people, yet also animals. In form some 
looked human, while some walked on all fours like animals. 
Some could fly like birds; others could swim like fishes. All had 
the gift of speech, as well as greater powers and cunning than 
either animals or people. 

— Okanogan Native American legend 

The Garou carried out their Impergium not only against 
humans, butagainst the planet's other species ofshapeshifters. 
In their quest to prove themselves supreme among Gaia's 
creatures, the Garou implemented the War of Rage, decimat- 
ing all those whom they deemed rivals. The other members of 
the Changing Breed — the werecats, weremegatheriums, 
werealligators, and the like — were either driven toextinction 
or forced into far corners and caves. The Garou then forgot 
about them. 

The other lycanthropes, however, did not forget, and 
harbored a festering hate ever after. Hidden in their jungles 
and caves, they whispered tales of the Garou oppressors to 
their children, and their children's children. Gradually, the 
Garou assumed the status of devils — to be avoided or, 
preferably, killed on sight. 

The Garou long ago realized their mistake and would just as 
soon leave the other lycanthropes alone. As the wilderness 
slowly shrinks and human incursions increase, this is not 
alwaysan option. The Garou and the others have increasingly 
been forced into contact — usually with violent results. 


Garou Society 


I believe in the way of an older law 
When we used to dance to a different drum 
And we are changing our ways 
Yes we are taking on different roads 
Tell me about the forest that you once called home. 
— Dead Can Dance, "Tell Me About the Forest" 
Garou are as much wolf as human, and their society reflects 


this. The following sections describe their cultural institutions 
and beliefs. 


Becoming Garou 


For eons, Garou reproduced by breeding with humans and 
wolves in relatively equal proportions, thus keeping their 
blood relatively pure. In the early days, when humans were few 
and wolf packs roamed the world, Garou could take their pick 
of breeding stock. Certain groups of humans and wolves 
became favored by certain groups of Garou, and thus the 
different tribes and lineages were born. Chosen breeding stock 


31 


—-—-—^^^A^A^A^-—^————— RBS 


became known among the Garou as flocks, and great battles 
were fought over breeding rights to the best flocks. 

Because the Garou gene isrecessive, nine children out of 10 
are born normal humans or wolves. These children are still 
immune to the Delirium and often aid their brethren in 
mundane matters (see Kinfolk, below). Even the few that are 
to become Garou spend their childhood years as normal 
members of their mundane species. They are often watched 
from afar by their Garou family. Garou-to-be are markedly 
different; they have strange and sometimes terrifying dreams, 
often wanderalone for hours or days, andare frequently unable 
to get along with or relate to their peers. They often have a 
sense of inexplicable longing. 

Between 10 and 16 years of age (if human) or one and two 
years (if wolf), the Garou-to-be undergoes further trauma; a 
wolf is often driven from the pack, while a human adolescent 
is often ostracized or institutionalized. At this point, the 
Garou ofthe tribe show themselves, kidnapping the child and 
guiding her through the shock of the first transformation. The 
confused and often traumatized adolescent Garou is taught 
the rudiments of tribal lore. Following this, she, along with 
other “cubs,” is savagely thrust into a great test of cunning and 
strength. This test is known as a Rite of Passage, and it is 
inevitably a harsh and deadly affair. Many Garou do not 
survive their Rites, but those that do establish themselves as 
the fiercest of predators and gain a sense of what it means to 
rely on pack-brethren. Garou who survive the Rite of Passage 
are accepted as full, if novice, members of their sept and tribe. 


Lost Cubs 


Lately, the Garou have discovered more and more adult 
humans (or, very rarely, wolves) who have the potential to 


become werewolves, but who were somehow lost by their 
tribes and never taken through a Rite of Passage. These 
individuals have so repressed the wolf aspect of themselves 
that they have no idea it is there. They are known as “lost 
cubs,” and many go insane or die of depression. So few 
Garou are left that it is considered a time of great joy when 
such a lost individual is discovered. 


Breeds 


Creatures kissing in the rain 

Shapeless in the dark again 

In the hanging garden change the past 

In the hanging garden wearing furs and masks. 

— The Cure, “The Hanging Garden” 

Garou usually live among either human or wolf society 
prior to becoming Garou; this factor engenders many different 
outlooks on life. 

Homid: Homid Garou grew up in human society. Although 
they were often maladjusted and ostracized, they still know how 
the system works. They understand and use the subtle shadings of 
human vocabulary, and can interact with humans much better 
than other Garou can. (Note that “homid” refers to Garou bom 
from human stock, while “human” refers to the race as a whole.) 


32 Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


[POPE m mn m ————À 


Homids are in the middle of a moral quandary. They see the 
environmental devastation wrought by their kindred, but cannot 
reconcile themselves to the destruction of their people. The guile 
they feel at their race's folly is often synthesized into anger at the 
lupus. Homid Garou often insult and bicker with their lupine 
brethren, treating them like rustic fools. 

Certain groups of homid Garou, confident in their superiority, 
feel that ifthe lupuscan't hack it, maybe they don't deserve to live. 
These Social Darwinists feel that homid Garou, as the dominant 
predators of the dominant species, are the only legitimate branch 
of Garou. 

Metis: Although metis Garou are the most familiar with Garou 
culture, in many ways they are leasta partofit. Their very existence 
isastain on the Garou, a reminder ofpastsin. Metis themselves are 
sterile and deformed, victims of their recessive, inbred genes. They 
are generally scomed by their peers, although these days they are 
permitted to live — the Garou can't be too picky about their 
warriors, and of all the breeds, the metis can most easily attain the 
dread Crinos battle-form. 

Surprisingly, few metisleavethe tribe. Theirdeformitiesare just 
asnoticeable among humansor wolves, and in Garou society metis 
atleast havea place, low as it may be. Asa result of theirtreatment, 
many metisare themselves hostile and cruel, thus reinforcing their 
stereotype as vile and base creatures. A few metis, however, are 
caring and compassionate. Such a metis is a truly tragic figure, for 
his sympathy for others is rarely returned. 

Lupus: Lupus Garou spent their early years among wolves. 
Once lupus constituted a significant proportion of the Garou 
populace, but now they are rare. 

Lupus were raised as creatures of instinct, and tend to act on gut 
intuition. Although they were always more intelligent than their 
wolfsurrogate family, they were andare still generally untutored in 
the subtletiesofhigher thought. They tend to speak less often and 
valueactionsmorethan long-windedorations (“monkey-babble”). 
When they do speak, they speak directly, with little flattery, irony, 
sarcasm or metaphor. Lupus detest hypocrisy; those disliked by a 
lupus generally know it. 

This is not to imply that lupus are stupid; on the contrary, 
they are among the most cunning of the Garou in terms of 
simply getting things done, and can concoct elaborate plans for 
achieving objectives. 

The lupus know well that they are dying, and that this is largely 
the fault of the humans; because of this, and because of their low 
numbers, lupus tend to be cliquish, often disdaining the company 
of metisand homidalike. Many lupus belong to the genocidal Red 
Talon tribe, or at least agree with its policies. 


Caerns 


She took me to her elfin grot 
And there she wept and sighed full sore. 
— John Keats, “La Belle Dame Sans Merci” 
Ley lines. Menhirs. Burial mounds. Dragon-stanes. Haunted 
spots. That creepy old house at the end of the road. 


Just as the Sun has its sunspots, places where the solar flares 
erupt into space, so does the Earth have areas where the raw 


| 


mystical energy of Caia leaks into the world. Werewolves 
build temples and shrines atop these spots, which are then 
called caerns. By tapping into the power of caerns, Garou can 
travel between them, even across vast distances. Garou can 
also use caerns as "lightning rods" to summon powerful spirits 
or evoke awesome mystical energies. 

Much to the Garou's chagrin, other beings know of these 
sites. Mages seek out caerns and systematically rape them of 
theirenergy (which the mages call Quintessence). Minions of 
the Wyrm corrupt and occupy caerns, warping them to evil 
(see Wyrm Caems, below). Faeries use caerns as bridges 
between their world and Earth. 

Caerns are integral to Garou culture. They serve as sites of 
worship, meeting areas, and final resting places for those 
werewolves too old tocontinue life’s journey. Even the Garou's 
physical and mental health are affected by the proximity of 
caerns. Without the mystic energy of the sacred spots to unite 
their disparate natures, werewolves may well sicken and die, or 
go insane. 

Each tribe possesses its own caerns, although there are some 
communal sites. These sites are appropriate to the tribe — 
Children of Gaia may take refuge at a serene glen, while Get 
of Fenris may hold mad revels upon a battlefield. 

Caerns are usually dedicated toa particular spirit, often the 
totem spirit of the tribe that maintains the caern. Gates to 
these spirits’ domains can be opened by those Garou powerful 
and learned enough to know and enact the correct rite. 

The Wyrm also has unholy sites of its own; such places are 
discussed later in the chapter, in the Wyrm Caerns section. 


Urban Caerns 


Many caerns have been swallowed by the expanding cities. 
Most such caerns are rendered inert in the process, but some 
survive, pockets of mystical might in the midst of spiritual 
desolation. Thus, as the number of wild caerns dwindles, 
Garou more and more frequently risk the cities in order to 
worship at what was once theirs. Obviously, such worship runs 
an extreme risk of exposure. Revels, where the Garou run 
about in Crinos form to frighten intruders, are particularly 
important to Garou worshipping at urban caerns. 

This covert worship provides fodder for many urban legends 
and nursery rhymes. For example, if werewolves hold monthly 
moots in an abandoned stockyard, the Delirium ensures that 
people instinctively avoid that spot, especially when the hour 
of the moot draws nigh. No one understands why such unease 
is felt, but few are brave enough to traverse the “haunted lot” 
or the site of the “weird axe murders,” particularly at night. 


The Litany 


The Litany is the great song of ages containing the tradi- 
tions, codes and laws of the Garou. All Philodox are required 
to learn it by heart, and most good Moon Dancers learn a 
significant portion of it. The Fianna are the true masters of the 
Litany, and even their Ragabash know most of its intricacies 
— ideal for extricating themselves from various situations. 


The Litany isa complex and often convoluted thing, but its 
intricacies serve the purpose of poetry moreso than 
pontification. Practical application of the Litany is much 
simpler than the hours-long chants of the Fianna would seem 
to indicate. The Garou are a fairly straightforward people and 
have little patience with convoluted legal maneuvering. In 
most cases, a violator of the Litany is well aware of the 
consequences of his actions. 

The following are some of the basic tenets of the Litany; 
there are many others, often varying by sept or tribe. 


Garou Shall Vot Mate with Garou 


Because of the deformities and psychoses displayed by metis 
werewolves (and the age-old prejudice correspondingly levied 
against metis), Garou are forbidden to mate with their own 
kind. Werewolves must instead seek mates among either 
human or wolf society. This tenet embodies one of the great 
Garou tragedies; Moon Dancers often move audiences to tears 
with ballads of Garou who fell in love and could not express 
their passion — or who did and were torn to pieces by their 
outraged tribe. 

Reality: The number of metis among the Garou shows that 
this law is no longer so inviolate as it once was — certainly not 
a capital offense, though a source of great shame to the 
offenders and their lineages. 


Combat the Wyrm Wherever Jt 
(Dwells and Whenever Jt Breeds 


The Garou were spawned, say the bards, to fight the Wyrm, 
and much of their early history comprises battles between their 
great heroes and the Wyrm's minions. Most Garou pay at least 
lip service to this tradition. 

Reality: In recent ages, many Garou have forgotten or 
simply ignored their mission. Increasing political tension, 
competition for living space, and the general complexity (and 
unattractiveness) of the homid world have taken their toll. 


Respect the Territory of Another 


The practice of this portion of the Litany has changed over 
the last few centuries; humans have spread to the extent that 
urinating one’s territorial markings has become impractical. 
Instead, a Garou visitor or immigrant must first ask permission 
by singing the Howl of Introduction, reciting name, sept, 
lineage, totem and tribe. 

Reality: The Glass Walkers and other urban Garou con- 
sider howling in public uncouth and will accept a telephone 
call or fax from a visitor. Many younger Garou ignore this 
portion of the Litany altogether, considering it “fascist.” 


Accept an Honorable Surrender 


The Garou realize that they are a dwindling race and that 
intraspecies duels commonly occur. Realizing that continuous 
battles to the death would only advance the Wyrm’s cause, the 
Children of Gaia and Fianna incorporated this element into 
the Litany. In theory, a Garou combatant may end a duel by 


Chapter Two: Setting 33 


POL PT TR —————PÀ 


| 


exposing her throat; the opponent is honor-bound to accept 
the surrender. The loser suffers no reduction in Renown, 
although the winner may certainly gain Renown. 

Reality: In practice, this element is not commonly in- 
voked. Certain tribes consider losing to be shameful, and 
damn the Litany if it says otherwise! Wendigo, Silver Fangs, 
Shadow Lords and, especially, Get of Fenris lose considerable 
respect among their peers by surrendering. Additionally, Get 
of Fenrisare notorious for "accidentally" ignoring a surrender, 
instead tearing out the offered throat. 


Submission to Those of Higher Station 


Garou’s wolf nature practically enforces a hierarchical 
structure within their society. Thus the Garou have imple- 
mented the concepts of Renown and Rank. Within reason, 
any request by a Garou of higher Rank is to be obeyed. 

Reality: Many of the younger homid Garou scoffat the idea 
of kowtowing to a bunch of blunt-fanged, mangy, crusty, 
broken-down old alphas. The Bone Gnawers all but ignore 
this section of the Litany (otherwise, they argue with a sneer, 
they would have to spend their entire lives submitting). The 
Silent Striders, Children of Gaia, Stargazers and other egali- 
tarian werewolves espouse personal choice in the matter of 
whom to respect. The Silver Fangs and Shadow Lords, of 
course, enforce this edict with iron claws. 


The First Share of the Kill for the 
Greatest in Station 


This portion of the Litany is much favored by the Garou 
elders, as well as such tribes as the Silver Fangs and Shadow 
Lords; it is grudgingly acquiesced to by the rest. The “kill 
clause" also applies to the spoils of war — thus, in theory, the 
prey’s most powerful fetishes and the like may be garnered by 
the Garou with the highest Renown. 

Reality: By their nature, packs subject all the tenets of 
Garou society to interpretation. Very few packs allow one 
member to keep all the best loot all the time. A Garou who 
tries too hard to enforce this edict will probably be obeyed, but 
should be prepared to accept the consequences of her selfish- 
ness, 


ye Shall Not Eat the Flesh of Humans 


This portion of the Litany was first sung in the post- 
Impergium days; the Stargazers are believed to be responsible 
for its insertion. They noticed that Garou who routinely 
consumed human flesh often grew Wyrm-tainted; further- 
more, cannibals had a hard time stalking and killing more 
challenging prey, such as woolly rhinos or Banes. Addition- 
ally, in these modern times, this rule serves a function similar 
to the “kosher” laws of the Hebrews; modern humans’ chemi- 
cal-laden diet makes their flesh bitter and unhealthy. 

Reality: Red Talons scoff at this section of the Litany; indeed, 
they often make a point of hunting and devouring humans. 
Though they donot like to admit it, many Garou who succumb to 
frenzy later awaken with a strange taste in their mouths. 


34 


Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


Respect for Those beneath Ye — All 
Are of Gaia 


Garou tend to think of themselves in communal terms, and 
they thus realize that most creatures have some sort of contri- 
bution to make toward the whole. When all is said and done, 
Garou were created to be the world’s protectors. The chivalric 
ideal is much in vogue among some septs, and Garou who 
display a great deal of noblesse oblige may gain Renown. 

Reality: The Shadow Lordsand Get of Fenris pay lipservice 
at best to this edict and would strike it from the Litany if they 
could. The Bone Gnawers cynically jest that because no one 
is beneath them in station, they need respect no one. Most 
tribal gatherings will ignore a younger Garou, frenzied and in 
Crinos form, who thoughtlessly slays a lesser being such as a 
deer or human. 


The Veil Shall Not Be Lifted 


This is perhaps the most inviolate portion of the Litany. 
There is no “reality” here — Garou are aware that both the 
Wyrm and the Inquisition hunt for them. Garou who disobey 
this edict die at the claws of their brethren. 


Do Not Suffer Thy People to Tend 
Thy Sickness 


In the ancient days, an injured, infirm or aged Garou was 
simply torn to pieces by his peers. As time went on, however, 


^ 


itcame to be considered more dignified to let such a Garou end 
his own life. 

Reality: The Children of Gaia adamantly believe in natu- 
ral death and defend their old against the depredations of other 
tribes. Some older or wounded Garou, particularly those too 
weak to shapeshift, accept the shame of returning to human or 
wolf society to die. 


The Leader May Be Challenged at 
Any Time during Peace 


Though Garou are known for their pack mentality, this 
does not mean they must slavishly obey their leaders. If no 
immediate threat is pending, Garou of sufficient standing may 
challenge another's position of leadership. A contest of some 
sort is usually staged. If the challenger wins, she assumes the 
mantle of leadership; if she loses, she must accept the leader's 
dictates with good grace. 

Reality: An extremely tough and skilled leader is often 
virtually immune to challenge. Some unscrupulous packs 
have challenged leader one after the other, wearingdown the 
leader and thus ensuring that at least one among the pack wins 
the leadership position. Certain cunning leaders among the 
Bone Gnawers and Shadow Lords have declared continuous 
states of martial law. 


The Leader May Not Be Challenged 
during Wartime 


Certain creatures of the Wyrm are monstrous in size and 
power, and no one Garou can best them. Pack tactics are vital 
to the Garou's success against such creatures, and obedience is 
vital to successful pack tactics. In battle, the word of the leader 
is immutable law. A Garou who disobeys a superior will be 
destroyed as soon as circumstances permit. 

Reality: If it is evident that the leader is incompetent, 
Wyrm-corrupted or under magical control, Half Moon judges 
often ignore the “insubordination” of a Garou whose disobe- 
dience saves a pack or sept. Unfortunately, any Renown said 
subordinate would have otherwise received is negated by the 
technical violation of the Litany. 


ye Shall Take No Action That Causes 
a Caern to Be Violated 


Like the preceding clause about the Veil, this rule is fairly 
ironclad. The caerns are Gaia’s lifeblood, and if they are 
destroyed, the Garou will cease to exist. Even a Garou who 
accidentally leads an enemy to a caern is often severely 
punished. 


Justice 


Rules are written in the stone, 
Break the rules and you get no bone 
All you get is ridicule, laughter, 
And a trip to the House of Pain. 
— Oingo Boingo, “No Spill Blood” 


Chapter Two: Setting 


[POF D EEE ET Ss ZT ER ——— 


Garou are not a rigid, doctrinarian race. A simple explana- 
tion of wrongdoing is often enough to solve an impending 
problem. Mostdisputesare settled viaa reprimand, a mediator, 
or, if necessary, a duel. The mere disapproval of pack, sept or 
tribe is often enough to correct these intensely communal 
beings. Accordingly, Garou crimes and criminals are rare. 

Nonetheless, the laws and traditions are at times broken. In 
such cases, the sept or tribe sees to it that the offender is 
brought to justice. 

Trial procedures vary depending on the sept or tribe in- 
volved. The Get of Fenris prefer trial by combat, while the 
Bone Gnawers' "courts" are informal and subject to rampant 
bribery. The Children of Caia most often settle matters simply 
and cleanly, with but a single arbitrator; by contrast, the High 
Inquisitions of the Shadow Lords are terrible things, with 
lengthy interrogations and grueling ordeals. The Uktena use 
various strange spirits to frighten the truth from the accused, 
while the Glass Walkers rely on polygraph tests and modern 
criminological procedures. 

Sometimes the leaders of an outraged sept offer a bounty for 
the capture (or the skin) ofa violator. This bounty consists of 
talensand training, and can be quite substantial. Some younger 
Garouemploy themselvesasfull-time investigators and bounty 
hunters, traveling from sept to sept and capturing werewolf 
criminals. 


Organization and Power 
Structures 


Power and equality, and I’m out to get it 

I know some of you ain't with it. 

— Public Enemy, "Party for Your Right to Fight" 

Garou hierarchy often varies by tribe; obviously, the social 
structure of the Children of Gaia is less stratified than that of 
the Shadow Lords. Still, Garou are part wolf, and instinct thus 
plays a large role in how they relate to each other. 

Garou social units, from pack to tribe, are remarkably 
similar in structure, varying only by size. A pecking order is 
established early on, and one individual ischosenas the leader, 
or alpha. While Garou society contains several broad social 
strata, thereare very few absolute equals. Some tribes and septs 
establish their members’ places by brute force; most, however, 
use the system of Renown to establish hierarchy. This system. 
channels ambition in a positive direction — if Skullflayer 
wants to be leader, let him go out and kill a few Banes to prove. 
himself worthy! 

Though this "caste system" sounds somewhat Orwellian, it 
is important to remember that Garou instinct reinforces it; 
every fiberofa werewolf's being insists that he stay in his place. 
Werewolf superiors rarely abuse their lessers, and the lessersfor 
their part are content to be loyal vassals. If this sounds overly 
servile — well, take a look at the behavior of the average family 
dog. 

Additionally, while a werewolf group's hierarchy is crystal- 
line at any given moment, it can change like quicksilver as 


35 


| 


challengesare given and received. Yesterday's pack leader may 
well be today's underdog (and tomorrow's pack leader!). 
Social structure is integral to Garou interaction; tribes that 
emphasize individuality, such as the Stargazersand Silent Striders, 
are looked upon with bafflement or suspicion by other Garou. 
Members of these tribes don’t fit into the system, and thus other 
Garou often don’t know how to deal with or relate to them. 
When two Garou of widely disparate Rank or Renown 
interact, each Garou's relative position is fairly apparent. 
When Rank or Renown is roughly equal, however, things are 
notsoclear-cut. When two Garou of roughly equal status both 
claim dominance, the situation becomes both problematic 
and dangerous. Thus, one of the most important functions of 
Garou society is to provide a way for Garou to struggle for 
leadership positions without killing each other. The elaborate 
protocol involved in such struggles has served admirably, 
allowing each Garou to excel in her specialty. Thus, the 
greatest warrior among the Garou might lead the tribe or sept 
in battle, only to be subsequently defeated in a mental chal- 
lenge by the most cunning Garou during a situation in which 
wits and cleverness were important. If the situation required 
negotiation, a Garou who excelled at verbal interplay would 
promptly defeat the aforementioned Garou in a debate, thus 
becoming leader in time to use her skills for the benefit of all, 
Ideally, leadership is a temporary gaining of 
privileges in return for service to the rest of the Garou. 
Recently, however, the above has begun to change. Per- 
haps this is caused by the sudden predominance of human 
blood in the Garou's veins, perhaps by the subtle taint of the 
Wyrm. In any event, leadership is increasingly sought for its 
ownsake, for the perks and the sense of control it brings, rather 
than for the good of the group. For the first time in werewolf 
history, certain Garou septs and tribal groups are ruled by 
“permanent” leaders — often bloody-clawed dictators who 
hold their positions through intimidation and violence. 


Politics 


Garou are not inherently devious creatures. Even the 
political masters among werewolves — the Glass Walkers and 
Shadow Lords — are as children beside the Kindred and their 
centuries-old machinations. Garou tend to rely on themselves 
to get what they want. 

Garou politics have long been simple. The Garou with the 
most wisdom, Renown or expertise on the subject at hand is 
consulted, and the group as a whole listens to her advice, 
generally following it. The above approach worked while the 
land was wide and open, and the Garou ranged its length 
without disharmony or conflict. 


and so on. 


Inthe last century, however, decreasing wilderness area has 
forced Garou to dwell in close proximity to each other. Garou 
has begun to battle Garou, and tribe turn against tribe. With 
external distrust comes intratribal dissension, as Garou begin 
to question the wisdom and veracity of their leaders. 

As the young scorn the old and the old revile the young as 
a lost generation, as the noble Silver Fangs become more 
unstable by the year, unscrupulous Garou have been able to 


turn the turmoil to their advantage, wresting personal power 
from Garouand human society. The Glass Walkerssit in their 
data havens and dictate policy down the chain of command; 
the Get of Fenris rule by raw, brutal force; and the Shadow 
Lords daily become downright Machiavellian in their at- 
tempts to control all the Garou. 


(Dominance 


Garou hierarchy constantly fluctuates, thus ensuring that 
the werewolf most fit to lead the others in a given situation 
does so. Werewolves forever test one another, and Garou 
society has evolved a variety of contests to establish domi- 
nance. 

Dominance is central to Garou existence. Formal and 
informal challenges compose a large part of many moots. 
Usually, the werewolf being challenged may decide the specif- 
icsofthecontest. There are three primary means ofestablishing 
dominance: the facedown, the gamecraft and the duel. 


The facedown is a contest of wills. Two Garou stare into 
each other's eyes until one looks away. It is the simplest of the 
contests, but is not without peril; frenzy is not unknown during 
such contests. 

The gamecraft is favored by Stargazers, Glass Walkers and 
other mental sorts. In gamecraft, the Garou compete in a 
contest of skill or wits: a riddle contest, a chess match, or the 
like. Gamecraft is usually considered a valid means of est 
lishing dominance when facing mental conundrums; it i 
favored when the impending situation calls for a strong 
warlord. 


The duel is exactly that: a combat. The winner becomes 
leader. Duels are rarely intentionally fatal, but frenzy during 
duels is all too common. Certain tribes, such as the Get of 
Fenris, rely exclusively on duels. 

Theloserofa dominance contest must immediately display 
submission: falling to the ground, exposing the throat, display- 
ing the buttocks, urinating or what have you. Generally, the 
closer to Homid form the Garou is, the less visible the 
response. If some sign of acquiescence is not made, the winner 
is by tradition free to attack the loser. 


Language 


The Garou have a language of their own, invented by the 
Fianna tribe in the dim mists of the past. All Garou are taught 
it immediately following the Rite of Passage, and while there 
might be differences in regional accent and dialect, any 
member of Garou society may communicate with any other. 
Many newer words, however, may be misunderstood by par- 
ticularly isolated Garou. Additionally, Lunatics and lost cubs, 
those who have never had their nature revealed to them, do 
not know the Garou tongue. 

The Garou language contains many interesting philologi- 
cal features. It places as much emphasis on body language and 
toneasonactual words. There are as many metaphors for smell 
as there are for sight. Finally, certain words cannot be pro- 


36 Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


p/m. am, EN EEE ZT -——————— 


nounced by a human or wolf throat and thus require a degree 
of partial transformation; most Garou view these particular 
words as “high-falutin’.” 

As mentioned above (see Wolves), Garou in Hispo or Lupus 
form may freely communicate with wolves. Garou in other 
forms may try todoso, but might be misunderstood. Unlike the 
Garou language, the ability to communicate with wolves isan 
innate ability. 


Howls 


Werewolves’ howls are their most powerful and evocative 
means of expression. By howling, Garou may condense enor- 
mous amounts of information into a few notes. Mastering the 
howls is the life's work of a Moon Dancer (much to the 
irritation of her sharp-eared friends if she is less than gifted). 

Howls are usually begun by one Garou, but often joined by 
others. Whatever howl is employed, harmony is disdained and 
cacophony is sought. When two Garou hit the same note, one 
instinctively alters pitch, thereby remaining in discord. 
Through such tactics the pack is made to seem larger than it 
is, and foes are thereby intimidated. 

There are many howls; here are a few of the more common: 

* Anthem of War — Moon Dancers raise this inspiring 
battle cry to muster their brethren for battle, or to rally them 
if their spirits have fallen. 

* Call for Succor — Used to call a Garou's pack to his aid. 
Embarrassing, but occasionally necessary. The howl sounds 
somewhat like the bark of a puppy for its mother. 

* Call to Hunt — A long, low ululation used to alert the 
pack to the position and type of prey. 

* Chant of Challenge — Invented by the Fianna, the 
Chant isa systematic recital of one’s name, pack, sept, lineage, 
tribe and deeds, followed by a creative insult of the challenged 
one's personal habits, ancestry and deeds. Obviously, this is 
used to initiate duels. 

* Curseof Ignominy — This snarling whine is used by the 
sept or tribe to dishonor and mock those who have fallen from 
favor. 

* Dirge for the Fallen — This is a somber, low-pitched, 
drawn-out howl. It is used as a requiem for the honored dead; 
the volume and length depend on the status of the deceased. 

* Snarl of Precedence — This is howled by a Garou who 
wishes to go one-on-one with a foe. The Snarl does not have 
to be honored by those of higher Renown, but generally is. 

* Song of Mockery — This is a particularly infuriating 
pitch that Ragabash add to any other howl. It is sure to enrage 
Ahroun, Shadow Lords, etc. It is an insulting gesture — the 
Garou equivalent of "the finger." 

* Symphony of the Abyss — A reverberating, mad whine 
used by Black Spiral Dancers while hunting. The song is 
designed to terrify quarry, and it does. 

* Wail of Foreboding — The Wail is a general danger 
signal, often used to warn of natural disasters. 

* Warning of the Wyrm's Approach — A very sharply 
pitched howl, emitted in a series of brief staccato bursts. This 


mm 12 SS Er arms CU 


howl is used only to announce the presence of the Wyrm's 
minions.

The Packs 


Their's not to make reply, 

Their's not to reason why, 

Their's but to do and die: 

Into the valley of Death 

Rode the six hundred. 

— Lord Alfred Tennyson, “The Charge of the 
Light Brigade” 

Garou are intensely communal creatures and gather into 
groups reflexively. The pack is the most basic, and the oldest, 
werewolf social unit. It is also the most closely knit. A pack 
comprises between two and 10 Garou joined by a common 
purpose and totem spirit. A pack's purpose can be specific and 
finite, such as, "Stop Pentex expansion into Happy Acres 
National Park," or general and long-lasting, such as, "Destroy 
the minions of the Wyrm wherever they are found." Some 
packs last for weeks; others last for lifetimes. 

While a pack exists, its members are bound by very deep 
ties. Human friendship combines with lupine instinct to forge 
nearly unbreakable bonds. In most situations, the pack is very 
nearly of one mind; other creatures who observe a werewolf 
pack in action often wonder if its members share a telepathic 
link. Individual members of a pack may feel rivalry or even 
animosity toward other members, but rare indeed is the 
werewolf who will not defend her packmate to the death. 

When a pack is first created, a special totem spirit is often 
bound to that pack in a great rite. The spirit serves the pack as 
guardian, guide and envoy to its fellows in the Umbra. When 
the pack breaks up, its purpose accomplished, the spirit is 
released. 


Lineage 


The old adage, "You can choose your friends, but not your 
relatives," is a truism among the Garou. If the members of a 
pack are the friends a werewolf chooses, the lineage is the 
family he never escapes. A werewolf's lineage largely deter- 
mines the initial respect a Garou receives. Members of a 
lineage are quick to chastise and punish errant Garou who 
"bring shame upon the line" — i.e., do anything the elder 
members of the lineage find distasteful. 

Certain ancient lineages, particularly those among the 
Silver Fangs, are powers in and of themselves, with hordes of 
Kinfolk, palatial estates and many Purebred members. These 
lineages can be very useful, but are incredibly demanding of 
their young. Lineages are often major links between humans 


Chapter Two: Setting 37 


AI Ps ARTI RR E ——— 


and Garou, and in coming days the lineages may well attempt 
to assume positions of importance in human society. 


The Sept 


Garou who live near and guard a particular caern are 
collectively known as a sept. Most septs originate from one 
tribe, but in recent years, as the number of caerns dwindles, 
multitribal septs have formed. These multitribal septs are 
bastions of tolerance amongan increasingly xenophobic race, 
and may be the only hope for the werewolves' salvation. 

The sept performs social, political and religious functions, 
but its primary task is to guard its caern and Moon Bridge from 
harm. Because many of the sept's members are older Garou 
who have settled down to remain on permanent vigilance, the 
septoftenemployspacksof younger Garou to perform missions 
for it. The good will of the area's sept is vital, for its members 
are the region's eyes and ears, and often know of trouble long 


before the packs do. 


The Tribe 


The tribe is the largest social unit among Garou — the 
"species" of Garou, if you will. A werewolf's tribe determines 
her cultural outlook, upbringing and, often, physical traits. 
Different tribes control different areas and have different 
philosophies. A werewolf'sauspice isoften interpreted through 
the lens of her tribe — a Ragabash from the Bone Gnawers 
might be a transient scrounger, while one from the Glass

Walkers might be aslick con man, one from the Silent Striders 
might be a cunning scout, one from the Shadow Lords might 
be a Machiavellian politician, and one from the Get of Fenris 
might be a deadly assassin. 


The Thirteen Tribes 


Once there were many tribes of Garou, each with a particu- 
lar purview, but time and the Wyrm have whittled down the 
werewolves’ numbers. Today there are but 13 tribesextantand 
uncontaminated. These are: 

Black Furies — The avengers of the Wyld, the Garou 
known as the Black Furies are almost entirely female. The 
Black Furies originated in ancient Greece, where their par- 
ticularly harsh enforcement of the Impergium inspired a body 
of horrible mythology among the people of the region. They 
dwell in the deepest wildernesses and are staunch worshippers 
of the Wyld; they emerge only to carry out surgical strikes 
against those who would desecrate the dwindling magical 
places of the world. 

Bone Gnawers — The lowliest of the tribes, the Bone 
Gnawers live precariously on the streets of the urban slums. 
Often resembling jackals more than wolves, scorned and 
despised by the other Garou, the scrawny and mangy Gnawers 
are nonetheless survivors without peer. They are perhaps the 
most cunning of their species. Pragmatic and cynical, the 
Bone Gnawers long ago forsook the lofty ideals of the other 
Garou; they do what they have todo tosurvive from day to day. 

Children of Gaia — Ofall the Garou, the Children of Gaia 
are the ones most in harmony with the collective will of the 
planet. TheGlass Walkersseek toalter the planet, the Shadow 
Lordsseek to dominate it, and the Stargazers seek to transcend 
it; only the Children of Gaia seek true unity. They prefer a 
peaceful, harmonious existence, but when necessary they can 
be as merciless as the natural order they serve. 

Fianna — Masters of language and song, the Celtic Garou 
known as the Fianna are the preservers of the werewolves" 
history and lore. Collectively, they are the most creative of the 
Garou. They prefer to occupy their days with wordplay, song, 
drinkandrevelry. Whenangered, however, these descendants 
of the mighty dire wolf can be among the most savage and 
relentless of the Garou. 

Get of Fenris — It is said among the Garou that the Get of 
Fenris would gladly allow themselves to be devoured by a 
‘Wyrm demon just so they could rip out its tongue before they 
died. The harbingers of war and destruction, the Get of Fenris 
are savage berserkers who live for combat. The Get are shock 
troops, always on the front line in the war against the Wyrm. 
Their bloodlust and rage unnerves even other Garou, who 
note with shock how they throw themselves heedless and 
howling into their foes. 

Glass Walkers — Most Garou find the city to bea concrete 
abyss gaping to swallow them whole. Not the Glass Walkers. 
These quirky and rebellious Garou long ago adapted to the city 
and are now purveyors of technology and wealth. Willing to 
accept the changing urban landscape and involved in various 


dr A A AAN rr 


less-than-savory activities therein, the Glass Walkers are 
perhaps the least trusted Garou. Their connections, their 
wealth and their hordes of urban elemental servants ensure 
that few dare to express that distrust openly. 

Red Talons — Composed entirely of lupus Garou, the tribe 
known as the Red Talons sees only one way to preserve Caia. 
The homid despoilers — every last one — must be extermi- 
nated. Of all werewolves, the Talons are most in touch with 
their bestial natures — for good and for ill. They remember 
many of the wilderness's secrets, secrets even the other Garou 
have forgotten. 

Shadow Lords — Cold, regal, vengeful and ruthless, the 
Shadow Lords are the dark warriors of the Garou. Mighty in 
battle and cunning in peacetime, the Shadow Lords follow the 
path of ambition and conquest wherever it leads. Their 
courage and tenacity are unquestioned, but neither is their 
arrogance, and the Shadow Lords will stop at nothing less than 
total domination of Garou and human alike. Although the 
Shadow Lords do not care to admit it, more than one member 
of the clan has been lured to the Wyrm by the promise of 
power. 

Silent Striders — The most mysterious of the Garou, the 
Silent Striders hold no permanent homes, but wander from 
caern tocaern and throughout the urban, wilderness and spirit 
realmsas they choose. Travelis theirexistence, and few know 
the secrets of both the mortal and spirit lands like they do. The 
Silent Striders are a laconic people, and little is known about 
them, yet they always seem presciently aware of impending 
events. 

Silver Fangs — No werewolves are more revered than the 
members of the aristocratic tribe known as the Silver Fangs. 
Find a mighty hero, a wise sage or creative virtuoso in the 
Garou epics, and as often as not that mythic figure is a Silver 
Fang. In recent years, however, a strange malady has stalked 
thenoble line. Fewerand fewer children are born to them, and 
many of these children display disquieting traits that other 
Garou have only recently dared to call madness. Though the 
Fangsare pure and beautiful on the outside, sickness slowly rots 
the Garou's greatest lords. 

Stargazers — Mystic spiritualists and contemplators, the 
Stargazers wander hither and yon seeking enlightenment. 
Perhaps the most attuned to their inner nature, the Stargazers 
roam the dark and lonely places of the world, protecting the 
weak from the Wyrm. In this they are unexcelled, for their 
inner understanding allows them to perform lupine martial 
disciplines and feats of will unknown to other Garou. 

Uktena— The Uktenaare the remnants ofone of the three 
great North American Garou tribes. Sly, reticent and devious, 
the Uktena certainly understand the spirit ways better than do 
most other Garou. The use to which they put their knowledge 
islesscertain. The tribe's moots and ritualsare secret and dark, 
conducted in shadowy places. Some wonder if the Uktena are 
not already corrupted. Only superstitious fear (reinforced by 
the Uktena's formidable magical might) keeps the other 
Garou from gaining more forceful answers. 


Wendigo — Gray ghosts of the deep forests, the Wendigo 
once ran free across the face of North America, as did the 
Native Americans from whom they took their human flock. 
Masters of survival, spirits and war, the Wendigo were none- 
theless nearly exterminated by the genocidal practices of the 
Europeans. The remnants of the tribe now lair in the deep 
Canadian taiga, where they struggle unceasingly to win back 
the lands that were theirs. 


The Lost Tribes 


Once the Garou’s numbers were far greater, but the 
Wyrm’s genocide has taken its toll. Entire tribes of 
werewolves have been wiped out through the Wyrm's 
machinations. The litany of the dead is long, but three lost 
tribes stand out among the others. 


The White Howlers 


Garou bards sing dirges lamenting the loss of the White 
Howlers. Once the guardians of the north, the White Howlers 
walked into a Wyrmpittoslay the horrors therein. When they 
emerged, they had themselves become horrors: twisted mu- 
tants calling themselves Black Spiral Dancers (see Black Spiral 
Dancers). The White Howlers are rarely spoken of, lest their 
curse be called upon the other Garou's heads. 


The Croatan 


Garou bards sing epics celebrating the valor of the Croatan. 
This tribe was once the proud guardian of North America’s 
shores. It gave its collective life to banish the Wyrm beast 
known as Eater-of-Souls, which had traveled to the New 
World with the Roanoke colonists. Only the carvings on a 
gnarled tree memorialize the Croatan’s valiant deeds, but the 
Garou remember. 


The Bunyip 


No song is sung for the Bunyip, for the Garou are too 
ashamed. In many ways, the fate of the Bunyip is the most 
tragic of all the lost tribes. The Bunyip were slain not by the 
machinations of the Wyrm, but by their own brethren. 
European Garou and Kinfolk, desperate for a new land far 
from the Wyrm, invaded the Bunyip’s homeland. Over the 
next few centuries, the Bunyip and their flock, the Tasma- 
nian wolves, were hunted to extinction. 


Ronin 


Throughout the ages, despite the great stigma attached to 
so doing, certain Garou have always chosen (or been forced) 
to walk their own path, free from the constraints of pack, sept 
ortribe. Such Garou have been given many epithets down the 
years; the most recent is the Japanese word ronin, or “wave 
man.” The Garou ronin, like his samurai counterpart, bobs up 
and down on the sea of life without purpose or direction. 

Ronin hold no position in Garou society; they may gain the 
Gifts and other trappings of a given Rank (though it is very

difficult — Mentors can be found, but they are the sort who 
require bribes) but have neither the status northe responsibili- 
ties of their Rank. Ronin are scorned by most other Garou, but 
lately their numbers have been increasing. 

Some ronin go insane or become Wyrm-tainted. These 
lonely night stalkers are responsible for many legends of *man- 
eating werewolves” and the like. 


Kinfolk 


No, I am not Prince Hamlet, nor was meant to be — 

Am an attendant lord, one that will do 

To swell a progress, start a scene or two. 

— T.S. Eliot, "The Love Songof]. Alfred Prufrock” 

To reproduce, Garou must mate with either humans or 
wolves. Because the Garou gene is recessive, most of these 
matings produce children who are, by and large, normal 
members of their species. However, such children are immune 
to the Delirium and can interact with werewolves. These 
humans or wolves are known as Kinfolk. 

Kinfolk, particularly human Kinfolk, are vital to Garou 
existence. Because they suffer neither frenzy nor Delirium, 
Kinfolk may freely enter human society to perform missions for 
their Garou cousins. Certain tribes, such as the Glass Walkers 
and Shadow Lords, have extensive networks of Kinfolk. Many 
of these Kinfolk hold positions of power among mortals, 
though the opposition of the vampires has checked Kinfolk 
dominance to an extent. 

Most Kinfolk have no special powers beyond their ability to 
fraternize with Garou. However, it is rumored that a few 
exceptional Kinfolk have rudimentary levels of Gnosisoreven 
Rage. Such exceptional Kinfolk could conceivably learn Gifts, 
though few werewolves would teach them. 


Moots 


Garou assemblies are known as moots. Moots combine 
social, religious and political functions, and are thus tremen- 
dously important. At moots, Garou bond with one another 
and reaffirm their commitments to their species and to Gaia. 
Garou who frequently avoid moots are viewed with suspicion 
by their brethren. 

Moots are generally called on the full moon. They are 
always held at caerns, and many moots involve the summon- 
ing of spirits. At moots, questions of policy are debated, plans 
for the future are discussed, heroes are honored, violators ofthe 
Litany are reviled and, most importantly, the caern is re- 
charged via the passion (and Gnosis) expended during the 
ceremony. Moon Bridges often open during moots, permitting 
passage between caerns. 

Philodox handle the “business” aspects of the moot, while 
Galliards organize the social and storytelling aspects. 


Types of Moots 


There are many types of moots, varying by size, purpose and 
the Garou in attendance. 


40

[PPO CEPA ET i ET ER —€— 922 


* Sept Moot: Sept moots are the most common kind of 
moot, and are generally held monthly at the sept’s caern. Any 
Garou can attend, but Garou not of the sept are often viewed 
with suspicion. 

In addition to their other functions, sept moots help re- 
charge the sept’s caern. 

* Grand Moot: A grand moot is called to discuss very 
important matters affecting an entire tribe. All nearby 
werewolves of the tribe are expected to attend. 

* Concolation: Concolations are the greatest moots. All 
werewolves, regardless of pack, sept or tribe, are welcome (and 
expected) to attend a concolation. Concolations are called 
only to discuss the weightiest and most critical matters. 
Accordingly, they are extremely rare. 

A concolation must be called for by five elder Garou from 
five different tribes. Concolations are usually called for during 
anormal moot; the concolation is then scheduled to take place 
on the moot site, exactly three months hence. Meanwhile, 
messengers traverse the region (or the continentor, rarely, the 
world), going from caern to caern and spreading word of the 
impending gathering. 


Tribal Moots 


* Black Furies — The Furies hold their moots in idyllic, 
isolated locales such as distant glades and still pools. Many of 
their verbal rituals revolve around choral chants and re- 
sponses. The Furies also hold sacred hunts during their moots, 
and any game animal or human (particularly a human male) 
in the vicinity of a Black Fury moot is in serious jeopardy. 

* Bone Gnawers — Formal moots are rare among this 
tribe. Most of the time, the city's Gnawers scrounge up what 
cash they can, hit the local liquor stores and McDonalds, and 
proceed to stuff themselves and get trashed. Caia's name is: 
rarely invoked save via creative profanity. Occasionally the 
Gnawers do call a moot to trap or kill particularly dangerous 
urban spirits; such moots are often called "Orkins." 


* Children of Gaia — Children of Gaia moots range from 
the calm and serene to the wild and joyous. One never knows 
what to expect at a Children of Gaia moot: eight hours of 
staring motionless at the moon, or an orgy of hallucinogens 
and sex with any humans and wolves present. 

e Fianna — Fianna moots generally fall intotwo categories. 
The first type of moot is a solemn affair held on the holidays 
of the Celtic calendar — Samhain, Beltane, etc. Here, bards 
recite the history of the Garou (often from memory), and great 
epics are sung. 

The second type of Fianna moot is a wild party. Other 
Garoustrive to be invited to these parties, wherein song, dance 
and drink combine in a mix certain to loosen up even the 
stuffiest Red Talon or Shadow Lord. Moon Dancers of all 
tribes use these moots to display their latest compositions. 

* Get of Fenris — The Get's moots are wild affairs 
involving howling, eating, drinking and, of course, fighting. 
Indeed, to an outsider, the entire moot might seem like a giant 
brawl, though the Getareactually followingrigid rulesofform.

* Glass Walkers — The Glass Walkers meet on the 23rd

Lately, the younger Walkers have been calling moots of 
their own. These events are similar to raves and are primarily 
social affairs, with drink, drugs, and music ranging from 
ambient house to punk. 


* Red Talons — Red Talons' moots often revolve around

: to divorce oneself of sentience and become as much a

unquestioningly obeying the will of the wolf alpha.

* Shadow Lords — Shadow Lord moots are most often 
held in gloomy, isolated locales, preferably while storm clouds

pomp and circumstance; much ado is made about Rank,

Drums and Gregorian-style chanting are common features of

* Silent Striders — Silent Striders rarely congregate, and

their moots. Rarely do Silent Striders stay in one place 
throughout their moots; indeed, races, relays and the like are 
common activities during Strider moots. 

* Silver Fangs — Silver Fang moots are marked by 
elaborate, beautiful dances and singing, as well as litanies to 
the spirits. The Silver Fangs hold their moots in isolated, 
idyllic locales. They favor the use of candles and often wear 
white robes during the ceremonies. 

+ Stargazers — Stargazer moots, when they are held at all, 
are simple affairs. Several members of the tribe gather to 
exchange information, engage in riddle contests, or simply 
meditate. Often, not a word is spoken during the moot.
