Uktena — The ceremonies of the Uktenaare very strange. 
Much emphasis is placed on mysticism and spirit summoning. 
The Uktenasupplement these activities with elaborate dances, 
incantations and chants, and passages read from ancient books 
the tribe has collected over the eons. The Uktena insist that 
no other Garou be allowed to view their rites. 

Wendigo — Wendigo moots derive much of their content 
from Native American rites, complete with fire dancing, pipe 
smoking and peyote ingestion. Garou often undergo 
visionquests at these moots, hoping to discover their purpose 
in life. Umbral travel and ritual combat are emphasized. 
Wendigo Theurges often capture and bind a powerful spirit so 
that it can be hunted by the tribe as a whole (after first 
placating its brethren-spirits with sacrifice and prayers). 


Revel 


The end of a moot is usually celebrated by a revel. During 
the revel, Garou transform into Crinos shape and lope about 
the area, clearing away all that threaten the caern. This run is 
so strenuous that elders occasionally die in their efforts to keep 
pace. 


Once the Garou start their revel, they continue until dawn 
oruntil they drop from exhaustion. The exultation of the revel 
often sends the Garou into frenzy — a Garou revel is a very 
dangerous thing. 


Garou Cosmology 


Above all, say the Garou, stand the lords of the Triat — the 
Weaver, spider-mistress of perfect order; the Wyld, ever- 
changing maelstrom of mad chaos; and the Wyrm, blighted 
serpent of entropic decay. In the Time Before Time, these 
three beings maintained balance. The Wyld would randomly 
ejaculate raw, shapeless creation. The Weaver would then 
bind the Wyld’s effluvia into forms and patterns, thus creating 
matter and energy. Finally, if either order or chaos became 
dominant, the Wyrm would catabolize the excess and thus 
restore balance. 


Thensomethinghappened, a cosmic catastrophe that warped 
the Triat into its present imbalance and forever ruined the 
world. Some Garou believe that the Weaver went mad and 
attempted to bind the entire universe in her webs; when the 
Wyrm intervened, it was partially crystallized. Mad from the 
pain, the Wyrm forever after attempted to destroy not just 
excess creation, but all creation. 

Other Garou feel that the Wyrm corrupted the Weaver, not 
the other way around. In any event, the Wyrm has since been 
the Garou's greatest foe. The Weaver, too, has waxed overly 
strong; her human agents seek to transform the universe into 
a stagnant, motionless stronghold of utter rigidity. 


Below the Triat are the Celestines, godlike spirits of tre- 
mendous potency. Luna isa Celestine, as isthe sun-god Helios. 
Celestinesare often worshipped, and certain septs are devoted 
entirely to the worship of a single Celestine. 


Below the Celestines are the Incarna, spirits who fill the 
roles of demigods in the Garou pantheon. Tribal totems such 


42 Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


Zo ———— a 


as Chimera or Grandfather Thunder are considered Incarna. 
Incarna are revered, but rarely worshipped outright. 

Garou also believe in a host of lesser spirits, elementals and 
other beings; these creatures are often called Jagglings or 
Gafflings. Those spirits corrupted by the Wyrm are called 
Banes (see Banes, below). 


Geography 

Oh, East is East and West is West and ne'er the twain shall 
meet 

Till Earth and Sky alike shall stand ‘neath God's great 
judgment seat. 

— Rudyard Kipling, "The Ballad of East and West" 

Garou civilization is much older than that of humanity, 
and the Garou have ranged far and wide across the globe. 
Many tribes cling to their ancestral homelands, while 
others have colonized distant reaches of the world. Garou 
demographics vary from region to region, though in general 
Garou stay close to the ranges of their wolf brethren. 


North America 


North America's vast pine forests and rolling plains have 
long provided dwelling places for the Garou. Here, Garou and 
human coexisted harmoniously. Native Americans’ respect 
for nature and relatively low population kept the claws of the 
Impergium largely at bay. Indeed, many humans of Native 
American descent are able to look upon Garou without 
suffering the effects of the Delirium. North America long 
provided its three indigenous Garou tribes — Wendigo, 
Croatan and Uktena — with a refuge from the Wyrm. 

TheinfluxofEuropean immigrantsdestroyed thecontinent's 
tranquillity, for the Wyrm came with them. One of the first 
incursions — the Roanoke settlement — unleashed a great 
Wyrm beast that completely destroyed the Croatan tribe. 
European Garou followed, and their “manifest destiny” im- 
pulse mirrored that of their human flocks. Unable to compete 
successfully with the Europeans' overwhelming numbers, the 
native humans and Garou were slowly pushed into the inte- 
rior. The native Garou fought back savagely, but there were 
simply too few to turn the tide, and their efforts were largely 
spent against their cousins among the Get of Fenris and 
Shadow Lords. To this day, Wendigo and Uktena werewolves 
loathe the Get and the Lords. 

Recently, the threat of the Wyrm has forced an uneasy truce 
between native and colonist werewolves. Today, members of 
every tribe may be found in North America’s cities and rural 
tracts, and by and large they tolerate each other. Tensions flare 
from time to time, however, particularly in areas dominated by 
the Wendigo. 


South America 


Few Garou call South America home. The continent has 
long been a bastion of the world’s other lycanthropes — the 


— SL 


shapeshifters who were driven into the wastes by the Garou's 
WarofRage. A variety ofcreatures— werejaguars, werecaimans 
and others — dwell in the shrinking jungles of the Amazon. 
The Garou, concerned about the rain forests destruction, 
have made overtures of alliance, but the other creatures well 
remember the days of the War of Rage. Garou trespassing on 
the others' territory are often punished with death. 


Recently, Pentex's depredations have forced the Garou to 
invade the Amazon en masse. The two-front war against the 
Wyrm’s agents and the other lycanthropes has seriously weak- 
ened the Garou. 


Europe 


Europe has long been a Garou battleground. The peasants 
of France, the serfs of Hungary, the cotters of England — all 
told chilling tales of the werewolves in the dark. Europe, 
because of its small size and large population, was where the 
Impergium was most harshly enforced. 

Many werewolf tribes, including the Fianna, Get of Fenris, 
Silver Fangsand Shadow Lords, originated in Europe and have 
been quite active there. Unfortunately, so has the Wyrm. 
Various Wyrm minions are responsible for legends of dragons 
and the like; the first fomori were created here to battle the 
Fianna. Furthermore, Garou and mages sporadically war for 
possession of Europe's dwindling mystical sites. 

The Garou of Europe are among the foremost proponents 
of war with the humans, for they are running out of room. 
Already, Get of Fenris packs have made commando raids into 
European cities. Though the Veil masks such incidents as 
terrorist attacks and the like, it is only a matter of time before 
the Garou are discovered. 


Alrica 


Like South America, Africa remains a stronghold of the 
other species of shapeshifters. Silent Strider Garou traverse 
thecontinent, andafew packs of Red Talons feed on Ethiopia's 
misery, but by and large the Garou are unwelcome in Africa. 
Werewolf incursions into the heart of the Dark Continent 
have been savagely repulsed by packs of wereleopards and 
reptilian shapeshifters (these latter beings may well be respon- 
sible for the Congo dinosaur legends). 

Certain Garou whisper of a great Garou caern-city lost ages 
ago in the Congo, but the few packs who quested for the city 
have never returned. 


Asia 

Though much of Asia remains a mystery to the Garou, they 
have traveled throughout the continent over the centuries. 
Many of the more warlike tribes ran with the Mongol and Hun 
hordes. 

Packs of Silver Fangs dwell in Siberia, and a number of 
caerns dot the region, though in recent years both packs and 
caerns have begun to disappear. Caerns have been “deacti- 
vated,” their spiritual essences drained. Entire Silver Fang 


packs have disappeared withouta trace. The very acts of Moon 
Bridge and Umbral travel to Russia are difficult; a “spirit fog" 
shrouds the land, inhibiting travel. 


Elsewhere, the Garou are more numerous. India houses 
many Children of Gaia; they spend the majority of their time 
preventing the region's Red Talons (known as “dholes”) from 
decimating the overpopulated peninsula. Stargazers wander 
China, Southeast Asia and Tibet (a Tibetan Garou's frenzy 
may well have inspired the yeti legends). 

Japan has become a major Garou battleground. The 
Japanese's austere bushido code pleases the Garou. The tech- 
nological base of the islands attracts Glass Walkers, while the 
enormous corporate zaibatsu are veritable playgrounds for 
Shadow Lords. Garou of all tribes seek footholds into the 
region, wishing to ascertain whether the Black Spiral Dancers 
are at the root of Japanese legends depicting malevolent 
transforming foxes. 

The Indonesian jungles house the last remnants of Asia's 
other shapeshifters. Garou, fearing the shapeshifters’ ven- 
geance, hesitate togothere. The marketsand bazaarsof Jakarta 
have recently been rife with tales of weresharks, shapeshifting 
pythonsand enormous, sentient orangutans. Something big is 
evidently happening in the jungles, but its precise nature 
remains a mystery to the Garou. 


44 Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


JI n UR, EEE ET AT TE A 


Australia 


Australia’s connection to the Umbra is deep and abiding, 
resulting in the phenomenon known among the Aborigines as 
the Dreamtime. In the Dreamtime, Earth and Umbra juxta- 
pose, allowing creatures to cross the boundaries between 
worlds. 


Australia was long the home of the Bunyip (see The Lost 
Tribes), Garou who bred with the marsupial Tasmanian wolves. 
The Bunyip’s totem, the Rainbow Snake, gifted the tribe with 
tremendous powers over reality and Dreamtime alike. The 
Bunyip were longdeemed the wisestand most powerful Garou. 

Alas, neither wisdom nor power enabled the Bunyip to 
withstand the greed of their brethren. European Garou, subtly 
influenced by the Wyrm, coveted the rich spiritual tapestry of 
Australia. Silver Fangs, Fianna, Shadow Lords and others used 
the colonization as an excuse to invade the lands of the 
Bunyip, citing potential Wyrm corruption. The Bunyip de- 
fended themselves ferociously, but were no match for the 
European Garou's superior numbers. The Bunyip had also not 
reckoned with the hordes of Garou Kinfolk that began todrive 
the Tasmanian wolf to extinction. The last Bunyip fell in 
1934; the last Tasmanian wolf died in captivity soon thereaf- 


LA 
ter. 
Now the Australian Garou (who breed with dingoes in the 
absence of wolves) live with shame and fear. Recently, septs of 
Garou have begun to vanish outright, and tracks of the 
supposedly extinct Tasmanian wolf have been found encir- 
cling the caernsites of these lost septs. Many Garou whisper of 
the Bunyip's vengeance, and fear of these ghosts keeps most 
Australian werewolves off the Outback at night. 
Antarctica | 


There are no known Garou caems in Antarctica. Indeed, little 
is known about the continent. Most Garou view the land as a 
barren, icy wasteland, and indeed seem afraid to travel there. 
Certain Garou, claiming that the continent is actually the Thule 
of their myths, urgea massive exploratory expedition. Most Garou 
elders, however, say Antarctica is a land best left alone. 


The Wyrm 


I am the spirit that denies forever! 

And rightly so! What has arisen from the void 

Deserves to be annihilated 

Tt would be best if nothing ever would arise 

And thus, what you call havoc, 

Deadly sin, or briefly stated: Evil, 

That is my proper element 

— Johann Goethe, Faust 

Above all else, Garou hate and fear the Wyrm. God, 
demon, monster-spawner, personification of decay, manifes- 
tation of the Garou’s darker side — whatever the Wyrm’s true 
nature, the Garou have held it in horror since the dawn of 
time. 


— G————A——— XD (REN 


It is ironic, then, how few specifics are known concerning 
the Wyrm. Though the Garou have battled the minions of the 
Wyrm through the eons, the werewolves still know nearly 
nothing about their foe. Certainly, no Garou (save perhaps a 
Black Spiral Dancer) has spoken to or met with the Wyrm 
itself. It is known only through the deeds of its servants. 
Indeed, certain werewolves question the existence of the 
Wyrm as an entity separate and distinct from its legions of 
savage minions. Still, there doesseem to bean evil intelligence 
of some sort guiding the Banes, fomori and other creatures. 
Most Garou accept the existence of the Wyrm, if not on faith, 
then on the horror and destruction it routinely wreaks. 


Recent discoveries imply the existence of three major 
aspects of the Wyrm, each with its own faction and minions. 
These are: Beast-of- War, a savage aspect that seemingly exists 
only to spread violence and entropy; Eater-of-Souls, the 
devourer of matter, energy and spirit alike; and the Defiler 
Wyrm, an insidious aspect that concentrates on the corrup- 
tion of human society. 


@anes 


Skulls are smashed and bones are bending, 

Joints are popping, claws are rending 

Groveling, sniveling, driveling horde 

To worship scaly overlord 

— GWAR, “Gor-Gor” 

The Wyrm most often acts through mortal agents, but it 
also has legions of evil spirit servitors; the Garou have named 
these minions Banes. Some Garou Theurges postulate that 
Banes are actually avatars of certain aspects of the Wyrm; most 
Garou, however, believe Banes to be separate entities with 
individual sentience. This is reinforced by the fact that Banes 
often speak of the Wyrm with dread, and evidently fear it. 

Banes most often dwell in the Umbra, for they are spirits 
and thus indigenous to that realm. Here, they use their spirit 
Charms to corrupt all whom they encounter. Banes may also 
possess mortals or Garou, urging them to commit evil acts. 
Occasionally, Banes manifest physically, most often to fight; 
when they do, they generally create as loathsome a form as 
possible, the better to unnerve opponents. 

There are countless varieties of Banes. Some Banes appear 
to be manifestations or personifications of malevolent forces 
orphenomena; others are freakish monsters seemingly created 


with neither rhyme nor reason. There are Banes of pollution, 
Banes of hate, Banes of terror, and myriad others not so easily 
categorized. Certain human mages have advanced the theory 
that Banes are mere byproducts of the Garou’s shamanistic 
faith, personifications of negative concepts too abstract for the 
Garou to comprehend otherwise. This theory is often dis- 
proved most violently, for Banes are quite capable of attacking 
mages as well, and have no qualms about so doing. 


Chapter Two: Setting 


Wyrm Caerns 


Here are the young men, a weight on their shoulders 


Here are the young men, but where have they been? 

“We knocked on the doors of Hell’s darker chambers 

Pushed to the limit, we dragged ourselves in.” 

— Joy Division, “Decades” 

Just as there are caerns dedicated to Gaia, so there are sites 
dedicated (or perhaps desecrated) to the Wyrm. At these 
unholy places, the vilest magic is evoked, and the very air and 
soil are often poisonous. 


The Wyrm's original caerns lay far underground, in deep 
caverns. Here the Wyrm first spread the poisonous balefires 
that humans have named radiation, biotoxins, et al. In these 
places, the Wyrm’s minions first gathered, oozingand flopping 
around the balefires’ sickly gleam. Here the Wyrm’s priests, 
and later the first Black Spiral Dancers, learned to channel the 
sites’ unholy energies. 


But while Gaia’s interior was riddled with evil, her surface 
remained relatively unmarred, thanks to the Garou's vigi- 
lance. Occasionally a horror, goaded by the Wyrm, crept tothe 
surface on a mission of desecration or a simple killing spree. 
The Garou were ever watchful for such, and great battles were 
fought in the dark. The Veil h: 
fog of myth, and humans hi 
such names as Beowulf and Grendel, Hercules and the Hydra, 


s obscured these fights in the 


handed down the tales under 


and St. George and the Dragon. 


| 


The advent of nuclear and biochemical technology, how- 
ever, proved disastrous to the Garou. The very ichor of the 
Wyrm, so long buried, began to be mass-produced by humans. 
The Wyrm saw its chance to gain a foothold on the surface. 
Careless dumping procedures, “a need for more weapons to 
preserve national security," and suspiciously lax safety inspec- 
tors led to the creation of Wyrm caerns on the surface — 
landfills, atomic test sites, buried waste and the like. 

At these places, the minions of the Wyrm congregate. 
People livingnear these sites gradually disappear. More distant 
residents become suspicious and sullen, if they don't leave 
outright. The energies emitted by the caern often cause defects 
among those born or living near the area; these defects range 
from the subtle to the grotesque. 

The Wyrm loves nothing more than to capture a Garou 
caern and seed it with toxins and balefires. In one fell swoop, 
an already potent mystical site is rechanneled and the Garou 
are further weakened. 


Wyrm Corruption 


Secrets I hide 

They twist me inside 

And make me weaker. 

— The Cure, "Sinking" 

The Wyrm loves to lure one of its implacable foes, the 
Garou, into its service. By and large the Garou stand firmly 
against their enemy, but such treason is not unknown. Indi- 
vidual Garou, packs and even entire tribes (see Black Spiral 
Dancers, below) have succumbed to the Wyrm's allure. 

The Wyrm often begins its temptation by finding a dis- 
graced or disgruntled Garou, one who is more concerned with 
mortal dilemmas than an abstract.battle with evil. Its minions, 
in various cunning guises, then offer the Garou something to 
even the odds — a rite, a minor power, secret lore — in 
exchange for “a little favor" such as seemingly trivial informa- 
tion orafetish "that noone will miss." When the catastrophic 
results of this deed ensue, the Garou in question is now dubbed 
traitor and hunted. Of course, Banes or Black Spiral Dancers 
are happy tohelp the hunted one — for another, slightly larger 
favor...and so on, and so forth. At this point, spiritual decay 
is inevitable. 


Garou who have turned to the Wyrm are perhaps the most 
dangerous threats to the race as a whole, for they know the 
locations of the caerns, the times of the moots, and the secrets 
of the tribes. As the might of the Wyrm waxes, treason 
becomes more and more common. This in turn leads the tribes 
and septs to grow more and more paranoid, more and more 
xenophobic. In their vigilance against hidden foes, the Garou 
alienate potential allies. Misunderstanding breeds misunder- 
standing; irritation turns to hate and then to violence. And in 
its dark dens, the Wyrm hisses its pleasure... 


46 Werewolf: The Apocalypse

Black Spiral Dancers 


He fell into no well, though he did descend into a well he 
found, and came out with a strange expression which has not 
since left his eyes. 

— Robert E. Howard, “The Scarlet Citadel” 

The Black Spiral Dancers are not spoken of in Garou 
society save with a curse, a shudder and a wary glance over the 
shoulder. The Black Spiral Dancers are those Garou who 
turned tothe Wyrm. Once the noble tribe known as the White 
Howlers, the Dancers today are loathsome and evil, delighting 
in torture and pain. They were long ago driven into deep caves 
by their former brethren, but they occasionally emerge from 
their tunnels to murder and devour. They especially delight in 
feasting on the flesh of other Garou. Black Spiral Dancers are 
ferocious in battle, and love to rend and slay, but their greatest 
joy stems from corrupting other Garou to the ways of the 
Wyrm. 

The Dancersserve the Wyrm well. This is not surprising, for 
they are madness incarnate. All werewolves of this tribe are 
taken deep into the Dancers’ cavernous lairs at an early age. 
They are immured deep in the pits and, after suitable priva- 
tion, are brought before a certain pool of slick, still water and 
forced to gaze within. In this pool is reflected the face of the 
Wyrm, in all its loathsomeness. Many Dancers-to-be die of 
horror in that moment. Those who survive crawl up from the 
depths to join their tribe as full members. Hereafter, they see 
the world from a shattered mind. This insanity is the tribe's 
greatest weakness; Black Spirals have been known to attack 
imaginary foes or, laughing, destroy themselves in the midst of 
battle. 

But from madness also comes power. The Black Spirals’ 
tricksters can open gates between this world and the realm of 
the Wyrm. Their mystics can summon horrors to aid the tribe 
in battle. Their judges can blast foes with the Wyrm’s maledic- 
tion, their Moon Dancers can warp reality into the stuff of 
nightmares, and their warriors can rend reality asunder with 
their talons. 

Even the Dancers’ bodies have been befouled by centuries 
of exposure to the underground and the balefires. Dancers 
often display bizarre deformities. Black Spirals’ human forms 
are usually gnarled and albinoid, while their animal forms 
resemble bizarre hybrids of hyenas and bats. Hypertrophied 
eyes and ears; patchy, grayish-green fur; wrinkled, baggy hides; 
and sharklike teeth are common, though hardly uniform, 
among the Dancers. 

When Garou meets Black Spiral Dancer, quarter is neither 
asked nor given. The Dancer is an abomination on the face of 
Gaia, while the Garou knows a hideous end of torture and 
depravity awaits should she surrender. 

The Dancers can be found all over the world, plotting to 
advance the cause of the Wyrm, but most commonly make 
their dens in deep tunnelsand crypts. These underground lairs, 
called Hives, connect to caverns yet deeper, and the Dancers 
use these caves to travel between the humans cities on errands 
of evil. Some Garou whisper that the Dancers have allied with 


^ 


other creatures that inhabit the deepest bowels of the earth. 
The Dancers hold their moots and rites in the deep caves, 
where the balefires glow and strange creatures crawl from the 
depths to join them. The Dancers occasionally kidnap hu- 
mans from the surface world to participate in their rituals and 
"meet their friends"; needless to say, none of the guests 
survives, for there is usually a post-ritual snack. 

The Dancers’ totem is Whippoorwill; they often emulate its 
cry when hunting. 


Pentex, Jnc. 


One of the largest corporations in the Gothic-Punk worldis the 
shadowy fiscal entity named Pentex. This monolithic holding 
company controls countless subsidiaries and producesa staggering 
variety of products — from the computers of Sunburst Enterprises 
to the drugs of Magadon, Inc. to the roleplaying paraphemalia of 
the Black Dog Game Factory. Through its subsidiaries, Pentex 
holds virtual monopolies in certain industries and possesses signifi- 
cant market shares in most others. Pentex is a leader in the global 
economy. It provides jobs for countless people around the world. 
It is also thoroughly riddled by the Wyrm. 

Pentex's vast wealth and powerare merely the meanstoa much 
greater end — planetary corruption in the name of the Wyrm. To 
thisend, the corporation attempts to create as many Wyrm caerns 
as it can. Pentex manufactures, spreads and dumps radioactives, 
pollutants and carcinogens whenever and wherever it can — 
preferably, ofcourse, onaGaroucaem. Pentex relentlessly buysout 
tracts of land containing places sacred to the Garou, subsequently 
transforming those places into blighted wastelands. 

Pentex also seeks to corrupt the human populace as a whole. 
Many of Pentex’s products contain weak Wyrm poisons. The 
effects of these poisons are subtle, but the end result is usually the 
spiritual decay of the human consumer. Certain Pentex products, 
when used repeatedly, even transform humans into fomori. Natu- 
rally, Pentexdoesnot wish tocallattention toitself in sodoing, and 
thus the products’ effectsare very gradual and insidious. Yes, Junior 
hasindeed become more violent, and his grades have dropped, but 
who would attribute this behavior to the Action Bill doll (made 
from Pentex plastics) that he received for Christmas? 

Pentexand itssubsidiaries have often been accused of question- 
able activities, but neither the main branch nor the subsidiaries 
have yet been convicted of any serious ethics violations. This is 
largely because of "real-world" corporate tactics such as good 
lawyers and underworld ties (thus ensuring the disappearance of 
overly curious individualsa la Karen Silkwood). However, Pentex 
mayalsocall upon vastspiritual resources tosilence threats. Pentex 
routinely employs fomori and Black Spiral Dancers as agents and 
guards. It also bonds various Banes to important sites. Garou 
venturing onto Pentex installations are usually unnerved, for they 
can literally smell the taint of the Wyrm. 

Notall of Pentex’s actions are evil, nor are all of its agents tools 
of the Wyrm. Most of its employees and many of its managers are 
ordinary people goingabout ordinary jobs. However, many of these 
“ordinary” jobs do have ulterior purposes unbeknownst to the 
workers who perform them. The contrast between Pentex’s often 


— rd SD INTI ATADO CE 


Chapter Two: Setting 47 


innocent employees and the vileness of the corporation itself has 
led more than one Garou to a moral quandary. 


Fomori 


Thou poisonous slave, got by the devil himself 

Upon thy wicked dam; come forth. 

— William Shakespeare, The Tempest 

In its continuous struggle against the Garou, the Wyrm 
often finds itself in need of foot soldiers. The Wyrm can, albeit 
with difficulty, create monstrous creatures or breed Banes. 
However, the Wyrm is nothing if not a corrupter. The Wyrm 
finds it easiest and most satisfying to take a creature of Gaiaand 
warp it into a monster. The means by which the Wyrm 
accomplishes this are manifold: exposing the creature to 
mutagens or balefire, tricking the creature into ingesting a 
Wyrm-tainted drug or liquid, or seducing the creature to its 
side with the promise of power. 

In the past, when animal life was more plentiful and the 
wilds more extensive, the Wyrm chose its servants indiscrimi- 
nately, mutating all manner of creatures into loathsome 
war-beasts: dragons, manticoras and the like. Thus were many 
myths and legends founded. In the current, rational age, 
however, the Wyrm prefers to use human agents. The Fianna 
have named such creatures fomori. 

Fomori are specifically designed to face Garou in combat. 
While a single fomor is rarely a match fora Garou, packs of fomori 
can be quite deadly. To heighten fomori'seffectiveness, the Wyrm 


bestows various powers upon its tools. These enhancements range 
from superhuman strength to chitinous carapaces to the ability to 
induce mystical paralysis (a list of fomor Attributes, Abilities and 
powers is given in Appendix One). 

Naturally, such power has a price. A human so corrupted 
undergoes a terrible transformation of the soul, and often the 
body as well. The Wyrm does indeed grant power, but at the 
price of eternal damnation. Most fomori are mindless, de- 
formed cannibals who lurk in the woods or near landfills. A 
few, however, retain some semblance of sentience and human 
appearance; these the Wyrm uses to infiltrate human society. 

Wyrm-controlled corporations, Pentex in particular, often 
deliberately plant mutagenic toxins around their worksites 
and offices, thus triggering their employees’ transformation 
into fomori. 


Other Antagonists 


Would that the Wyrm were the Garou’s only foe, for it is 
enemy enough. The Garou are not that fortunate. Countless 
other beings, from mortals to mages to vampires, desire the 
Garou's hides — figuratively and all too often literally... 


Hunters 


For I'm weary with huntin' , and fain would lie doon. 
— anonymous, "Lord Randall" 

Suicidal asthe idea might seem, there exist certain mortals who 
would hunt the Garou. The reasons for so doing are manifold: a 
loved one slaughtered by a Garou's rage, a conviction that Garou 
are creatures of evil, or simple scientific curiosity. A few madmen, 
such as the infamous Samuel “The Skinner” Haight, even believe 
that one can gain the power of a Garou by ritually slaying it. 

Garou huntersare very rare. Most humans refuse even toaccept 
the existence of werewolves. The Delirium clouds humans’ per- 
ceptions to such an extent that they mentally block even a direct 
werewolf sighting. To see the Garou for what they are, a human 
must either be Kinfolk (a human with inert Garou genes) or have 
a will of iron. 

Successful Garou huntersare rarerstill. It is nearly impossible for 
a human to best a werewolf in combat — and combat is what all 
who hunt werewolves inevitably face. Even given werewolves’ 
well-known vulnerability to silver, the strength and speed of the 
Garou virtually ensure victory. 


Developmental Neogenetics 
Amalgamated 


The biotechnology firm incorporated as Developmental 
Neogenetics Amalgamated is on the cutting edge of genetic and 


medicinal research. The corporation maintains a respectable 
facade, butthescientists whorun DNA areruthlessintheextreme. 
Anymeansto DNA’sendofbetteringthe world isacceptable, and 
the scientists of DNA have performed clandestine research upon 
human subjects. 

While DNA is certainly capable of developing such things as 
germ weapons and wide-scale defoliants, the corporation has not 
yet engaged in active environmental despoliation. Thus, DNA 
would normally be of little interest to the Garou. However, two 
years ago a careless Garou was captured by agents of DNA. The 
hapless werewolf was taken to DNA' labs, studied, subjected to 
experiments and vivisected. 

Thus, the corporation is aware of the Garou and desires to learn 
more. In particular, the biological processes governing the Garou’s 
regenerative properties fascinate the scientists. The heads of DNA. 
scoff at superstition and believe the Garou to be mutants respon- 
sibleforthe werewolflegends, notactual werewolves. Nonetheless, 
they know much about Garou physiology. DNA has captured 
another werewolf and fought two more. 

DNA agents are highly trained and have access to advanced 
weaponry; DNA has even developed biochemical weaponry 
capable of inflicting aggravated damage upon Garou. DNA is 
aware of the Garou “allergy” to silver, but prefers to take Garou 
alive. The corporation has developed variants of tear and knock- 
out gas capable of incapacitating Garou. 


Dampires 


You were a vampire, and baby, I’m walking dead. 
— Concrete Blonde, “Bloodletting” 

The vampires are the lords of the cities and the Garou's etemal 
foes. Garou view vampiresas embodiments of the Wyrm’scorrup- 
tion and mockeries of Gaia’s cycle. Thus, Garou attack vampires 
unceasingly. Many a Garou warband has loped howling into the 
city’s heart, seeking vampire heads and skins. 

Still, such missions are dangerous undertakings at best. 
While the walking dead are rarely capable of besting the Garou 
in clean combat, they have great power to beguile, mesmerize 
and corrupt. Furthermore, by trading Gaia’s mantle for the 
Wyrm’s gift of life-in-death, vampires gain the luxury of 
longevity. A single vampire’s plans can encompass whole 
generations of Garou. The shameful howl of a Garou who 
realizes that her “noble” actions were all along the results of a 
vampire’s manipulation is a terrible thing to hear. 


Mages 

The Garou bear little love for human mages. At best, magesare 
seen as arrogant, devious and inscrutable; at worst, they are 
marauders who rape the Garou’s caerns and siphon the very life 
energy of Gaia for their own ends. The Garou have occasionally 
allied with mages, and hold a wary respect for the mage fraternity 
known as the Dreamspeakers, but in general the Garou prefer to 
keep mages at claw's length. The members of the Red Talon tribe 
particularly despise mages, and the tribe often organizes war parties 
for the specific purpose of taking mages’ skins. 


Not that such is accomplished lightly. The Garou know to 
their chagrin that mages are mighty foes, particularly when 
they have time to prepare for an assault. Mages have made 
many pacts with the stranger spirits of the Umbra, and often 
employ these “Umbrood” to attack Garou totem spirits. 


Suggested Books and 
Films 


The following list should provide some beginning sources on 
wolves or the environment. Also given are some recommended 
werewolf books and films, to help provide a good mood for game 
sessions. Most works in the werewolf genre, however, portray 
werewolves as mindless, ravaging beasts — Garou during a frenzy. 
Unfortunately, this is how Garou are perceived by humans who 
witness them, thanks to the Delirium. 


Books 


* Of Wolves and Men, by Barry Lopez. One of the best 
introductory books on wolves and their behavior, proving that 
wolvesare not the monsters they have so long been portrayed to be. 

* Never Cry Wolf, by Farley Mowat (or see the film). A 
naturalist’s first-hand study of wolves. 

* American Indian Myths and Legends, selected and edited by 
Richard Erdoesand Alfonso Ortiz. Anexcellentcollectionoftales. 
This is a good source for the feel and color of Garou myths. 

* Call of the Wild and White Fang, by Jack London. Classic 
books with wolves as protagonists. 

* Moon Dance, by S.P. Somtow. European werewolves 
immigrate to America, and territorial conflict ensues with the 
native werewolves. A very good horror novel. 

+ Earth in the Balance: Ecology and the Human Spirit, by Vice 
President Al Gore. A good, basic book on modern environ- 
mental concerns, well grounded in scientific fact. 


Films 


* The Wolfen (or read the book by Whitely Streiber). 
Native American werewolves secretly living in Manhattan. 

* ACompany of Wolves, directed by Neil Jordan. Werewolves 
in folktales. 

* An American Werewolf in London, directed by John 
Landis. One of the best in the genre. See it. 

* The Wolf Man, screenplay by Curt Siodmak. The old 
classic, wherein Lon Chaney Jr. deals with the curse of 
lycanthropy and ravens across the misty moors of Wales. 

* The Howling (the first one—not the sequels! ), directed by Joe 
Dante. An amusing tale of New Age psychology and werewolves 
—and how they don’t mix. The first major film to feature the half- 
man/half-wolf (Crinos) form, with a wolf head and human body. 

* Wolf, directed by Mike Nichols, starring Jack Nicholson 
as the werewolf. 


Chapter Two: Setting 49 


pmi en ee ee ————À 


Sing in me, Muse, and through me tell the story. 
— Homer, The Odyssey 


Telling stories has always been one of humanity's main 
methods of entertainment. Stories have been incorporated 
into books, songs, movies, poems, art and more. They have 
depicted individuals, groups, events, morals, emotions, nature 
and more. One would think that after 10,000 years of this, 
people would tire of stories, but more appear every day. 

These stories may be fresh and exciting, or repetitions of old 
ideas, but their audiences still enjoy them. They sit in rapt 
attention, absorbingas much ofthe story as they can. They read or 
listen and, provided the storyteller was skillful, they leave with an 
understanding of the point the storyteller was trying to make. 

For the most part, however, these stories have been 
nonparticipatory; that is, one person or group made them up for 
other people to enjoy. This audience played little role in deciding 
how the story went or what the outcome would be. Ifthe audience 
didn't like the end ofa movie, its only choice was to walk out. If it 
didn'tlikethedirectionabook took, its best option was toclose the 
book. In Werewolf, this is not the case. 


Interactive Storytelling 


Stories in Werewolf are interactive. That is, the audience 
(the troupe) plays as big a role in the story's outcome as the 
Storyteller does. While the Storyteller gives it shape, the 
players give it substance. The Storyteller may decide that in 
order tosave their pack, the characters must defeat Zenubis, an 
ancient spirit of the Wyld who is possessing them and forcing 
them to fight amongst themselves. The players, on the other 
hand, decide how the characters solve this problem. 


Chapter Three: Storytelling 


[LE Te ————P 


Do they seek the creature in the spirit world? Do they force 
itto possess something other than the charactersand then lock 
itaway? Do they trick it into possessing their enemies and then 
destroy it? Do they bargain with it? 

No matter how the Storyteller sets the scene, it is up to the 
characters to decide the outcome. The audience is as instrumental 
as the Storyteller. No longer do the players require the Storyteller 
to tell them everything. Now they can create the story they like. 


«Che Storyteller 


Still, characters cannot exist without a world full of people 
and events to define their personalities and existence. For 
characters to come to life, a world must be created. Such is the 
role of the Storyteller. The Storyteller is responsible for 
everything, besides the characters, that exists in the world. 
This may seem like an impossible task, for developing even 
one player character can be a daunting and time-consuming 
endeavor. 

Butstorytelling is really not so difficult as it sounds. Because 
the world of Werewolf is largely based on the real world, 
Storytellerscan permute their own experiences intostories. Of 
course, there are some minor differences between the World 
of Darkness and our own, but these differences are based on a 
few simple concepts. Moreover, the only strange culture in 
which the characters are likely to get involved is the Garou 
culture, and that is described in detail throughout this book. 


51 


N rn err nr rr ann en rra rd 


The Storyteller can draw on everyday mysteries to enter- 
tain the players. Is that old warehouse on Main Street really 
abandoned? Whatactually happened to that old farmhouse by 
the side of the road? Why did the only good radio station on 
the dial go off the air? For whom do the police work? What 
really goes on in that office building after dark? 

Ofcourse, the above are only rudimentary. One of the most 
important and enjoyable aspects of storytelling is the act of 
creation. The Storyteller has an excuse to create more than 
one character and can let her imagination run free to create a 
whole world. The Storyteller develops a plethora of charac- 
ters, from vile minions ofthe Wyrm to noble elders protecting 
a caern, and decides the direction the chronicle will take. 

Though the freedom to create may be the reason someone 
decides to be a Storyteller, the overriding goals should always 
be toentertain the playersand have fun. Certainly, storytelling 
requires the Storyteller to invest both time and effort, but it 
also requires an investment of time on the part of the players. 
Instead of playing the game, they could be reading a book, 
watching a movie, out on a date, or spending time with their 
families. In order to make the storytelling experience worth- 
while for the players, the Storyteller needs to make their 
investment profitable and fun. 


The Story 


Developing a story requires the Storyteller to juggle many 
different elements. Players can be temporarily mollified with 
frills (like an especially diabolical villain they must defeat, or 
a nifty fetish they may add to their belongings), but to 
maintain the interest of the players over the long term, the 
Storyteller must do some hard work. 

The most basic tenet of good storytelling is ample preparation. 
This does not mean the Storyteller should create an inflexible 
agenda that forces characters to perform certain actions. Remem- 
ber that the players must be able to interact with the story through 
their characters, and the players also have a responsibility to help 
make the story succeed. Ifthe Storyteller denies the characters free 
will at the outset, not only will the players enjoy the story less, but 
the story will suffer. 

Instead, the Storyteller should create a flexible outline of 
probable events and characters. Start the story with the first 
event on the outline. Maybe the characters witness a dump 
truck unloading foul-smelling barrels behind an abandoned 
gas station near their caern. The characters’ reactions deter- 
mine the next step in the story. 

When the players’ reactions are not what you, the Story- 
teller, expected, you may either adapt the elements of your 
story or decide to discard some of the immediate notes and see 
where the players can take the story. Neither choice is better 
than the other, though one may work better for you. If you are 
not skilled at changing the story on the spot, then you must 
find a way to get things back on course. If you cannot think of 
a way to repair the story, then you'll simply have to hope you 
can get back on course later. 

Ifthe players don’t seem to be able to keepa story going, you 
must excite the players’ imaginations and get them involved. 


Don’t make them do anything; instead, hold out a carrot and 
see what happens. Tempt the players into action; never force 
them. 

You can also decide to let the story continue without 
immediate intervention on your part. Either follow the play- 
ers’ lead and improvise based on their actions, or just wait until 
the next point on the outline would normally occur. For 
instance, if, when the aforementioned dump truck pulls out, 
the characters wait down the road instead of following the 
truck or checking out the barrels, rule that the Bane-honey 
inside begins to seep out and infect the ground. While the 
characters notice nothing odd that night, tell the players that 
over the course of the next week, the greenery near theircaern 
wilts and begins to die. If they still do nothing, the Banes 
attracted to the honey destroy both their caern and their land. 

On the other hand, the players may undertake another course 
ofaction you had never expected, but which works just as well. For 
instance, maybe the characters decide to contact local environ- 
mental officials about the dumping. You might want to delay the 
effects of the Bane-honey and let the characters discover just how 
extensive the Wyrm’s corruption of the local government is. The 
players will soon discover that battling a bureaucracy can be even 
more frustrating than fighting fomori. 

Storytellers often find stories more entertaining when even 
they don’t know what’s going to happen next. This variety of 
freeform storytelling can be taxing, but it allows players and 
Storyteller great creative leeway. Storytellers may discover 
new levels of storytelling skill while reacting to what the 
players do. Plots the Storyteller would never have otherwise 
conceived become apparent, and the players usually become 
more involved when they feel theiractions affect the chronicle. 

On the other hand, you may find that on-the-spot improvisa- 
tionis too difficult orjustnot the best method for your group. In this 
case, you will have to create detailed outlines, giving a lot of 
thought to possible tangents the characters may pursue. 


Creating a Story 


While Storytellers get their ideas from any number of 
sources, three are most common. These are: the character- 
based story, the event-based story, and the atmosphere-based 
story, so named to reflect their respective inspirations. 

Forthe character-based story, the Storytellercentersevents 
around a character, generally an antagonist or archvillain. For 
instance, the Storyteller might decide he likes the idea of a 
powerful Wendigo who despises all other tribes of Garou and 
wants to drive them from North America. Once the Story- 
teller has a firm grip on what he wants the character to do, he 
develops an accompanying story. Perhaps the Wendigo cuts a 
deal with the Wyrm, promising the Wyrm an important caern 
if the Wyrm gives him a mighty werewolf-killing fetish. 

Of course, the character does not necessarily have to be 
opposed to the troupe. It could be neutral to the characters, 
allied, or even a member of their pack. A Storyteller may well 
craft a story around a player's character if he feels that the 
character has been overshadowed by the rest of the troupe.

Storytellers may even create an atmosphere based on the

On the other hand, if a player likes the social interaction
