rival packs to stop fighting amongst themselves, but this goal 
issecondary to the roleplaying possibilities the story provides. 

White Wolf often includes stories in its supplements; these 
stories are often useful examples of how to design your own. If 
you have trouble with freeform storytelling, these books 
provide complete stories covering many possibilities. Even if 
you prefer to create your own stories, prepackaged stories may 
provide new fuel for your storytelling engine. Not that our 
books a 


> necessary or required. Just watch a movie or read a 
good book and you'll find yourself inundated with ideas. 


Story Elements 


While there are millions of stories, all good ones have a 
number of factors in common. A good story has a single 
theme and a single mood. The setting somehow involves 
the audience. Some sort of conflict takes place. There is a 
beginning, middle and end. There is both a climax and a 
resolution. Finally, the Storyteller had some kind of pur- 
pose in mind when she devised the story 


Theme 


Stories tend to become unraveled if the Storyteller does not 
keep an eye on things. A story in which the characters must 
solve an important mystery can be ruined should the charac- 
ters begin attacking the suspects, the police and each other. 
An easy way to keep events coherent and help the Storyteller 
come up with ideas for the story is to develop a theme for it. 

A theme can be as innocuous as “there is no ‘I’ in team” or 
as sophisticated as “the increasingly industrialized society of 


the 20th century has mechanized mankind.” The former 
theme allows the Storyteller to make the simple sublime, 
showing how the characters can succeed only by working 
together; the latter allows the development of plots wherein 
humans are used as tools by other people. 

While the Storyteller should strive to center most of the 
story’sevents around the theme, most players will never realize 


what the theme is. However, the right theme can give a story 


a lasting value — an internal strength and consistency — that 
it may otherwise have lacked. Don't get carried away trying to 
make the theme noticeable. Players can be easily turned off by 
what they perceive to be a morality lesson from their Story- 
teller. Present the theme and explore it in the story, but leave 
the lesson to the players. 

Werewolf: The Apocalypse itself has an overall theme, 
which can be integrated into stories. The game embodies the 
collision between the self and the outside world. The Garou 
embody the struggle to balance the inner and outer aspects of 
the psyche. Just as people must struggle to realize their inner 
hopesand drives, they must also heed the society around them 
and adjust to some degree. So must Garou heed the dictates 
of their culture and the will of Gaia while simultaneously 
fulfilling their own needs. 


Mood 


Astory witha tangible mood may provide much more than 
entertainment. By creating a mood, Storytellers evoke an 
emotional response from their players. If players both under- 


Chapter Three: Storytelling 53 


——^———^——»——»—»———————— NN 


stand and feel what is happening to their characters, the 
emotion of a scene can transcend the game. 

Different moods enable the creation of different kinds of 
stories. Some Storytellers are adept at creating a particular 
kind of mood, be it dark and brooding or light and fanciful, but 
this should not limit their experimentation. Not every story 
requires a "light" feel, and telling stories that evoke only that 
kind of mood severely limits the chronicle. "Light" wouldn't 
work, for example, when telling the story of a Garou pack's 
tragic destruction. 

Thebest way toestablish the mood ofa story is to evoke the 
desired mood early in the story — preferably during the first 
moments. If you want a light mood, try a trick like playing a 
cheerful song and telling the players that their characters are 
listening to their car radio. Then tell them that they are racing 
down the road in a luxury car on a sunny day on their way to 
a party thrown by another pack. Such an introduction should 
place the players in the right frame of mind to deal with the 
werecoyote who has been playing practical jokes on the local 
Garou. 

Even after the players are immersed in the story, reinforce 
the mood every chance you get. If things are going well, the 
players will perpetuate the mood on their own. Everything the 
characters experience or do will be viewed through the “lens” 
of the mood. 


Setting 


While the players may never know with certainty what the 
theme and mood of a story was, the setting is readily notice- 
able. An interesting, realistic setting makesall other aspects of the 
story seem real and believable; indeed, the players’ imaginations 
will often provide any details the Storyteller may have omitted. 
Conversely, a contrived, boring setting will detract from an 
otherwise acceptable story, forcing the players to focuson its faults. 

Of course, a story will likely have a number of different 
settings. It may begin at a caern, move to a remote cabin, 
meander through the Umbra and conclude in downtown 
Chicago. Telling a story set in just one place can occasionally 
be an interesting experiment or dalliance, but even a short 
story is likely to involve movement from location to location. 

While not all settings require a great deal of detail, the 
Storyteller should accurately and completely describe what 
the characters perceive, thus ensuring that the players have 
few questions later in the story. Physical objects, weather, 
smells, sounds and other factors all play a role in this. 

The fact that the world of Werewolf is so similar to our own 
world facilitates such description. Most settings (forests, buildings, 
etc.) are identical, orat least similar, to their real-life counterparts. 
There’snoneed toleam detailsofsomestrange, make-believe land 
(except when the characters journey to the Umbra, and the 
Storyteller can describe this area however she likes). 


Conflict 


The core of every story is conflict. Note that conflict is not 
synonymous with combat. In fact, the best conflict is often 
resolved without violence. Conflict refers to the opposition 


54 Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


a u + / 


the characters face in accomplishing their goals. When a 
Garou of higher Rank insists that the pack destroy a group of 
human campers, theconflictcomesnotfromanyfightbutfrom 
the pack’s refusal to obey. The characters must find out why the 
elder feels so vehemently about the campers and create an 
alternate solution. While this should involve no combat, it will 
include a great deal of conflict. 

Conflictcan be subdivided into literary themes. In Werewolf 
terms, types of conflict include: Garou versus individuals, 
Garou versus society, Garou versus nature, Garou versus the 
unknown, and Garou versus self. A decision about which type 
of conflict to use makes creating a story many times easier. 

Garou versus individuals is the most common Werewolf 
story —forexample, when the characters fight Pentex hitmen, 
powerful spirits and the undead to thwart the schemes ofa vile 
Black Spiral Dancer. 

Garou versus society is the second most common Werewolf 
story. The society in question is usually, though not always, 
that of humans. Garou culture, strict and regimented as it is, 
can also provide a unique stumbling block. Characters can 
easily find themselves at odds with the mores of their people. 
Battling society can be a frustrating but ultimately rewarding 
experience. 

While Garou versus nature appears contradictory at first 
glance, volcanoes, earthquakes and floods are as fatal to 
werewolves as they are to humans (well, almost). These types 
of conflicts are often subplots of other conflicts — for example, 
when the pack must make its way through a raging snowstorm 
to discover if a mad werewolf has escaped his asylum. 

Garou versus the unknown is a common conflict in the 
Umbra. However, every lupus has experienced such conflict 
upon first entering a city, and imagine the pack’s confusion 
when it meets a wereshark for the first time. 

Garou versus self may well be the least-used conflict, but it 
enables the creation of fascinatingstories. It appears most often 
when a character must subdue the Beast within himself, 
avoiding frenzy to achieve some important goal. It can also 
appear when a character must overcome her own weakness to 
solve some problem. 


Plots and Plotting 


A story does not just move randomly from place to place. 
Every story has phases within it: a beginning, middle and end. 
Like that of any other storytelling medium, be it a movie or a 
book, the plot in games like Werewolf: The Apocalypse is the 
series of events that forms a given story. Plotting is the way the 
plot comes together. 

In most cases, a story develops over a number of scenes; each 
scene somehow advances the story as a whole. As a general 
tule, the opening scene attracts the players’ interest and gives 
them an idea of what is happening. The middle scenes expand 
and develop the conflict. The final scene allows the characters 
to resolve the story in one way or another. 

Thus, if a story can be defined as a series of events, the plot 
is the order in which these events occur. Things should not be 
so simple that the characters merely go from Point A to Point 


B. The difference between a good plotanda bad plot, however, 
is not the difference between complication and simplicity. It’s 
okay to wrap a plot in layers of mystery, but unnecessary 
complications weigh down what could otherwise be a better 
story. 

A good plot also requires proper pacing. Don't feed the plot 
to the characters in an orderly, predictable fashion. Shake 
things up with "excesses" like plot twists or interesting sub- 
plots. Such excesses can often advance the main plot, not 
hinder it. Build up slowly to a climax that resolves the story. 

The bare outlines of one successful plot could look like this: 

First, set the scene, thereby allowing the players to slip into 
the roles of their characters. Then provide a hook — some- 
thing that sets the plot in motion. Perhaps a fomor the 
characters have previously fought appears mortally injured on 
their doorstep and only has time to croak out, *Beware the 
golden mule,” before dying. You've hooked them. 

Next, begin the process of ups and downs that gradually 
increases tension and expectation. Build up thesuspenseas the 
characters discover what has transpired. Using the aforemen- 
tioned example, the characters discover that the Wyrmhole 
the fomor had guarded has become extremely active, and 
Wyrm creatures emerge from it every night. When the time is 
right, you can spring the climax — a Get of Fenris metis with 
a golden coat has taken over the Wyrmhole and plans to 
unleash its fury on a nearby city. 

Now the players decide how they want their characters to 
handle the situation, and the climax determines how well 
their plans work. Do they try and talk the Get out of its mad 
plan, or do they fight it and its army of Wyrm beasts? Do they 
enlist outside help, perhaps discovering the only surviving 
member of the Get of Fenris pack, or do they handle things on 
their own? Do they win, lose or draw? 


Climax and Resolution 


If the plot ofa story is analogous to a roller-coaster ride, the 
climax is the biggest hill ofall. Prime the players with suspense- 
ful hints of what is to come, but don't reveal anything to them 
until the plot requires it. 

The climax is the penultimate moment of the story, juxta- 
posing all the characters, emotions and events and allowing 
the players to realize their significance. Here the characters 
succeed or fail, fight or compromise. There may well have been 
otherhighs in the game, but the climax should surpass the rest. 

Itcan be rewarding to continue play foran additional scene 
after the climax. This restful period at the end of the story 
allows the players to consider the story while they are still in 
the midst of it and to wrap up any loose ends. Known as the 
denouement (de-nu-ma), this is the point where any final 
details are resolved. Of course, there may still be a number of 
loose ends, thus providing the troupe with a host of future 
stories. 


The Goal 


As mentioned earlier, the main goal of any story is to 
entertain the audience and the Storyteller. However, the 


Chapter Three: Storytelling 


fA Um, PA Ts m ———— 


Storyteller and players may also have other objectives. Per- 
haps the Storyteller wants to illustrate the dangers of 
environmental neglect. 

The goal, while in many ways similar to the theme, is the 
actual purpose of the game rather than the thread running 
throughout it. Focusing on the goal as well as the theme will 
make the story easier to develop and tell, and hopefully make 
the game more enjoyable for all. 


Telling the Story 


Afterall thehard work preparingasessionofastorytellinggame, 
nothing is more rewarding than watching the players have a 
genuinely good time. Still, the best-developed story can be ruined 
inthe telling. Emphasis must also be laid on the act of storytelling. 


Work with Players 


The most important storytelling advice concerns the play- 
ers. Dealing with the players can sometimes be difficult 
(especially when they do something that completely disrupts 
your plans), but your goal should be to integrate them as 
smoothly as possible into the flow of the story. This means 
involving everyone in as many aspects of the story as you 
possibly can. 

In most troupes, certain players try to dominate play and 
direct everyone’s attention toward themselves. Do not reward 
this sort of behavior. Try to involve everyone, especially the 
new or quiet players. If you don't involve them, they won't 
have as much fun as they could, and entertaining the players 
is your primary goal. Remember, the characters in Werewolf 
almost always make up a pack; they should have to work 
together to survive. While you may want to base some stories 
on specific members of the pack, everyone should play a role. 

Itcan be difficult to balance the desires of all the players, but 
it is usually a simple matter to give each player a little bit of 
what she most enjoys. If a player is neglected because of the 
events of a given story, try to plan the next story's events and 
situations specifically around that player. 

Players can have very diverse motivations: to accumulate 
power, to become someone else, to gain a sense of accomplish- 
ment, to solve problems, to experience strong emotions, to 
compete, or just to be with friends. You need to balance the 
desires of all the players; if you exclude someone, that person 
will tend to disrupt the game for everyone else. 

The desires of a single player are likely to be a combination 
of twoor more motivations. One player may roleplay primarily 
to be with her friends, but may also want to play a character 
who gains great powers and can combat the Wyrm better than 
anyone else around can. 


Maintain the Mood 


Because storytelling games are designed to be fun, players often 
make light of the situations in which their characters find them- 
selves. Players joke, make bad puns, and soon. While this is usually 
fine, it may not always be what you, the Storyteller, want. 


55 


Forinstance, if youare trying to create an atmosphere of horror, 
you do not want one of the players breaking the tension at the 
wrong moment. If the climax of the story is to be a race out of a 
Wyrm-corrupted mansion with unknown horrors hiding behind 
every corner, the players should not be relaxed and at ease. They 
should be tense and on the edges of their seats. 

If you want to build the tension and drama, you should take 
the lead in setting the mood. Don't start cracking jokes 
yourself. Have the antagonists be dour and somber; describe 
themas vile and malevolent. If you evoke the mood early, the 
players will be less likely to break it later. 


Know the Systems 


It is the Storyteller’s duty to know the game systems. Rules 
can sometimes be very confusing. The minor inconsistencies 
inevitable in every game don't help either. In the end, it's your 
job to be the final interpreter of the rules and to decide in a 
practical way how the rules apply in your game. Remember 
that you control everything save the players’ characters. If you 
decide that the players must score five successes to scale the 
cliff and escape the slavering horde of Banes, then that's how 
many successes it takes, regardless of how any of the players 
may interpret the rules. 

However, as the arbiter of the rules, it's also your duty to be 
fair. Act impartially and reasonably for all involved. A Story- 
teller must be an umpire of clear and sound judgment. 


Sometimes, the story's events will require you to transcend 
the rules, or even break them. Breaking rules is often necessary 
to tell the best story or to make sense out of the story. In order 
to maintain the players' trust, breaking the rules should 
probably not occur regularly; otherwise, the players may rely 
on you to break the rules whenever they are in a jam. This will 
destroy the free will of the characters and eliminate the drama 
of every scene. Of course, you may decide to change the rules 
permanently in some way; this we encourage, so long as 
everyone knows a given rule has been changed. 

Going beyond the rules is just as important as knowing 
when to break them. This book cannot possibly predict every 
eventuality that will arise during play. At times, you must 
create new rules on the spot. You can make a snap decision to 
fill the hole for the moment, but before you play again, 
evaluate the problem and decide whether your solution was 
the best one. If not, change your ruling. Either way, you need 
to tell the players how such situations will be handled in the 
future. Consistency is a major virtue in a Storyteller. 


The Chronicle 


A chronicle isa series of connected stories that collectively 
tell a tale of larger scope and greater content. If a story is a 
chapter in a book, then a chronicle is the entire novel. (Or 
trilogy. Or 10-book series.) Chronicles can continue for sev- 
eral years, and the characters may last for decades of game time. 

A chronicle takes care and inspiration to create. In order to 
succeed, achronicle must have the same vitality asa character. 
The chapters of a book cannot be placed in any random order 


56 Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


y ERR, URP ERIT ID BP ———— À 


ifonedesiresa work worth reading and admiring. Each chapter 
must build on the last, just as the stories of a chronicle must. 

Storiesare obviously important to a storytelling game, but the 
chronicle provides scope and strength to the stories being told. A 
carefully constructed chronicle can helpaplayersuspenddisbelief, 
can fill holes individual stories might create, and can provide 
subsequent reasons for any discrepancies or contradictions. If the 
players trust your chronicle, they will soon trust that most features 
of your story have a reason, or at least a valid excuse. Players will 
not besoquick to point out flaws, for they will trust you to address. 
their concerns sooner or later. 

Additionally, a chronicle helps players see the big picture. 
It enables them to understand the Storyteller's purpose and 
lets the Storyteller build bigger and grander stories. The 
villains become more awe-inspiring. The events become more 
world-shattering. The atmospheres become more compelling, 
and the individual stories become that much better. 

Finally, a chronicle gives both the players and Storyteller a 
sense of accomplishment. The players see the effect their 
characters’ actions have on the world. They begin to make 
plans for the future, perhaps creating and maintaining their 
own caern. The Storyteller sees his stories blossom over the 
long haul and takes pride in what she has nurtured. Indeed, the 
Storyteller may want to name his chronicle, to give the players 
an idea of the scope of the undertaking in which they are 
involved. 


Common Stories and 
Chronicles 


A comprehensive list of the myriad story possibilities for 
Werewolf would be impossible to compile; however, the 
following section details some of the most common ones. 
Some of these concepts can also structure a chronicle, and 
Storytellers should feel free to develop their own ideas. 

* Preludes: Early in the chronicle, the Storyteller and 
troupe may want to explore the characters’ lives before they 
joined their pack. These preludes are usually set before the 
characters even became aware that they were werewolves. 
Preludes increase players’ empathy for their characters and 
allow the Storyteller insight into what the players want out of 
the game. Many groups like to run preludes during the very first 
session of play. 

* Rite of Passage: Another story, one generally set early in 
the chronicle, allows the characters to come to grips with their 
Garou nature. This “Rite of Passage” often takes the form of a 
mission given the characters by their elders shortly after the 
revelation of the characters’ Garou nature. A Rite of Passage 
canalso involve any type of discovery that causes deep change 
in a character. Of course, the Wyrm and other forces often 
attack such young and theoretically helpless pups, so what 
should have been an easy mission may turn into a harrowing 
battle for survival. 

* Garou vs. the Wyrm: This battle is the most important 
to the Garou asa race. Unless the corrupting influence of the 


— IR 


Wyrm can be negated, Gaia Herself will be destroyed. Pollu- 
tion and deforestation from the Weaver and war from the 
Wyld are the results of the corruption of the Wyrm. In many 
cases, battling the Wyrm involves seeking it on its own ground 
— even venturing into the radioactive wastelands of the 
Wyrm caerns. There, bold Garou must face both spirit crea- 
turesand mortal minions suchas Black Spiral Dancers, fomori, 
foul corporations, mortal assassins, vampires and mages. 

Characters may be called upon to invade Wyrm strong- 
holds, defend caerns from attackers, stop the kidnappings of 
young Garou, rescue a werewolf captured by a Bane spirit, or 
anything else the Storyteller can think of. 

+ Garou vs. the Weaver: The Weaver has casther glass and 
steel webs over much of the world. Her human tools have 
inflicted great damage to Gaia in the name of “progress.” The 
spider-spirit must be prevented from growing any stronger 
(and indeed must be weakened) lest the planet asphyxiate. 

While the Wyrm controls many of the human institutions 
the characters will battle, many more are Weaver creations. 
Some Garou argue that the Weaver's encroachment is more 
dangerous than that of the Wyrm, for it is more covert. 

* Garou vs. the Wyld: While the Garou largely support 
the Wyld, some Wyld spirits are simply too uncontrollable and 
must be stopped from spreading random chaos. 

* Garou vs. Humans: This struggle can be traced to the 
Impergium. Even today, some Garou consider themselves the 
rightful masters of the human race, but most know better — 
the humans pose the greatest threat (in a physical sense, 
anyway) to the Garou. The inexorable tide of civilization isthe 
Garou’s greatest enemy. As urban blight eats their lands and 
caerns, the Garou are forced to battle among themselves, like 
starving wolves in winter, for a share of the dwindling re- 
sources. Many Garou advocate outright genocide, and certainly 
all agree that something must be done to quell overcrowding 
and pollution before it is too late. 

* Garou vs. Vampires: In many respects, Garou and 
Kindred are natural enemies. The Kindred actively promote 
urban expansion, the very thing that most Garou dread, in 
order to replenish their human herds. While the Garou- 
Kindred war is not so all-pervading as some believe, it is still a 
common event. Much of the material in Vampire: The 
Masquerade and its supplements applies to Werewolf: The 
Apocalypse. The political wars of the Kindred can involve the 
Garou in any number of ways. 

* Garou vs. Garou: While the Garou supposedly share the 
same goals, this has not stopped them from battling amongst 
themselves. The Native American tribes hate the invaders. 
Black Furies despise the Get of Fenris, and nobody trusts the 
Shadow Lords. These fights often take the form of formal or 
quasiformal challenges, but they can turn extremely violent at 
a moment's notice. 

* Packmate vs. Packmate: The environment of a pack is 
a volatile one, for it is formed from strangers who have 
discovered that they are not who and what they thought they 
were. A pack can be a crucible for stress, and intrapack 
conflicts can be as brutal as any war against the Wyrm. 


* Pack vs. Pack: Instinctual Garou competitiveness fo- 
cuses outside the pack once the packmates have established 
internal order. Each pack wants the duties and quests that offer 
the most Renown. Additionally, most packs have territory 
they consider their own, and they do not like trespassers of any 
kind. 

* Tradition vs. Change: Garou society is based on follow- 
ing and perpetuating the traditions of the past. Some Garou, 
however, demand that this aspect of themselves be discarded, 
foritis obviously why the Garou have failed in their tasks. New 
times have created new traditions and forced the revocation of 
oldones, but the pace of change is always hotly debated among 
the Garou. 

* Exploration: No matter how much the Garou think they 
know, there is always more to learn. The Umbra is an unex- 
plored land of incredible possibilities. Anything can happen 
there, and Storytellers should take advantage of that fact. Still, 
even Earth can provide innumerable opportunities for explo- 
ration. The wilderness is an alien environment to homids, and 
cities are the same for lupus. 

Additionally, some caerns have been lost to the corrupting 
powers ofthe Wyrm. Normally, caerns simply disappear, never 
to return. Sometimes, however, the Wyrm is only able to 
smother a caern temporarily. Such caerns fade ... and out of 
existence either randomly or at regular intervals. Caerns that 
return can hold secrets and powers heretofore thought lost. 

* Love: Garou are emotional beings, and the passions 
evoked by love can be felt as strongly among them as among 


Chapter Three: Storytelling 57 


humankind. Because theirnumbersare dwindling, some Garou 
feel that it is their duty to find a mate and produce offspring. 
Others can’t help but heed these emotions. Stories can be built 
around the active search for a mate or even the happenstance 
of meetingsomeone who can return your love. But what if your 
love is another Garou? 

* Moot: These gatherings of the Garou provide rich oppor- 
tunities for a variety of stories. Not only are there the events 
of the moot itself — the contests, meetings and socializing — 
but strange events could occur to disturb the routine of the 
moot. Perhaps one pack, sept or tribe tries to use the moot as 
a forum to instigate dramatic change in Garou society. Myste- 
rious events like disappearances and escaped spirits can also 
generate excitement. Finally, moots allow characters access to 
elders willing to instruct them in the ancient powers. 

* Nature: Just as there are stories dealing with the human 
half of the Garou, so too may stories be told about Garou in 
their wolf forms. Because the composition of the stories is so 
different from that of other storytelling or roleplaying games, 
the stories themselves need not be so complex as ones set 
within civilization. For example, simply accompanying a 
dying wolf to his final resting place could be a learning 
experience for the players. Multitudinous story possibilities 
can be drawn from the juxtaposition of civilization and nature. 
Why are the animals dying when they drink from the regular 
waterhole? 

* Past Lives: Justas the history, traditions and rituals of the 
Garou affect modern Garou society, so too can individual 
Garou be intimately connected to the past. Garou have a 
tendency to recall their previous incarnations. Discovery of an 
ancestral success or failure can spark an interesting story, or at 
the very least an engaging parallel story or flashback. 

* Visionquest: The spirit world isa vital part of the Garou 
cosmology. Within the Umbra dwell the spirits the Garou 
claim compose the very fabric of our reality. The spirit world 
holds secrets, powers that the Garou must sometimes contact, 
and danger. The visionquest story involves an Umbral search 
for knowledge. The spirit world is vast and untamed; many 
exhilarating discoveries await those who seek its truths. 

* Penance: An especially powerful kind of story, penance 
involves the characters’ attempts to atone for some past 
misdeed. The mistake need not be theirs; they may have to 
bear the sins of the entire sept or fulfill the dying wish of a 
Silent Strider. 

* Becoming a Beast: This type of story usually involves a 
Garou coming to grips with her frenzies and their effects. For 
instance, a werewolf who fled battle in a frenzy of fear might 
later have to deal with the fact that her cowardice caused the 
death of a pack member. Forgiving herself might require a 
penance-type story, but will more likely involve the character 
accepting her animal nature. 

* Insanity: Some Garou never learn of their true heritage, 
instead discovering their horrifying powers without guidance. 
Such Garou are called Lunatics, for they lack the control and 
knowledge that allow Garou to become a part of the environ- 
ment, not deviate from it. This type of story usually involves 


58 Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


(ee ee ee —— ı/ 


the players stopping rogue Garou. On the other hand, a 
Storyteller may have the characters begin the chronicle as 
Lunatics or even go insane during the game. 

* Renunciation: According to the tenets of their culture, 
Garou are allowed to relieve themselves of responsibility for 
who and what they were in the past. This process is called 
renunciation; a Garou who announces it becomes a new 
person. All honors and position held in his previous life are 
voided. The character then has the chance to make herself 
anew. The Storyteller may opt to begin achronicle with all the 
characters having just renounced their pasts. 

* Superheroes: The Garou do not have to fight their 
traditional enemiesall the time. Afterall, they have incredible 
powers and may decide to fight crime, corruption or whatever. 
Who knows why those supervillains keep popping up? 

* Uncles: All successful Garou are expected at some point 
to provide for the support and development of a new genera- 
tion of Garou. As the character was once kidnapped and 
shown her true heritage, so must she now become an Uncle. 
The formation of a new pack is an important task and 
obligation in Garou society. Because the Garou "gene" some- 
times skips many generations, and Garou are often not alive 
whenchildren of their makingare born, this isa fine substitute 
for raising a family. 

* Dying Breed: The Garou are dying. This is the sad truth 
inany chronicle, but in this story the situation is driven home. 
The pack of player Garou may well be the last pack of 
werewolves left on Earth. The pack is the last hope to save 
Gaiaand the Wyld. The characters will have to be bolder and 
more outrageous in their methods, and this will force them 
into conflict with the older Garou who still live (if any). The 
characters will also be more heavily targeted by the enemies of 
Gaia. 


Storyteller Characters and 
Antagonists 


No elements of a chronicle are more evocative than the 
characters the pack encounters. Of course, not all characters the 
pack meets will prove memorable, nor should they. After all, most 
ofthe characters will only have bit parts and appear infrequently. 
Some will not survive their encounter with the characters. 

This does not mean the Storyteller can ignore these minor 
characters. The morereal he makes them, the more the players will 
enjoy the story. So what if the only function of the gas station 
attendantistogive the pack directions? He hashisown history and 
background. He can be helpful or rude, talkative or silent. Maybe 
he has a New England accent or a habit of never looking anyone 
in the eye. Give him a spark of life and a bit of individuality; the 
story will be that much more interesting. 

The more important thecharacter, the more the Storyteller 
should develop her. A good starting point is the character's 
motivation. Why is she doing what she does? Why is that 
banker financing a team of mercenaries to kill the characters? 
What reason could the Black Fury possibly have for asking that 
the pack stop its investigation of a human hunting lodge? 


Once the Storyteller has the character's motivation, other 
details can be constructed to support it. Perhaps the Black Fury 
is nervous and fidgety, looks around a lot, and smokes a 
cigarette. Sheacts very concerned about children and goes out 
of her way to help them. When the characters discover that 
hersonisoneofthe hunters, they will begin to understand why 
she does not want them involved. 

Most characters the Storyteller introduces are not evil. 
Indeed, many antagonists are simply individuals or groups 
whose goals conflict with those of the characters. Other 
characters will not oppose the characters, but will have their 
own reasons for doing what they do. 

The antagonists that are usually the most fun, however, are 
the villains — individuals the pack knows are malevolent or 
evil. Some villains should recur time and time again, becom- 
ing greater and greater threats each time. This provides 
continuity tothe chronicle and gives the playersa familiar face 
that they may well love to hate. Players will always remember 
the rogue Silver Fang who began his strip-mining company 
with the proceeds garnered from selling his old pack to the 
Wyrm, or Deysered, the corpse-spirit who sent legions of 
undead against them. 

Villains in Werewolf can take many forms. Some of the 
most likely villains include Kindred, mages, fomori, other 
Garou, and humans, especially CEOs or small-minded politi- 
cians. Other antagonists can include faeries, spirits, and other 
supernatural beings such as mummies. 

See the Appendix for examples of antagonists. 


Advanced Storytelling 


The above gives the basics of being a Storyteller. Every 
Storyteller develops his own techniques and style, doing what 
is most necessary to improve his stories. This section details a 
number of ways the Storyteller can transcend the norm and 
thereby make his stories even more memorable and exciting. 


Flashback 


A flashback is a scene from the past that relates to the 
present. Flashbacks are especially popular in movies, but 
storytelling can also take advantage of this technique. The 
flashback technique is often used to explain the history of 
some element of the story at hand. 

During the flashback, players take the roles of characters 
involved in the flashback. These characters will usually not be 
the players’ regular characters, but the participants should 
have immediate relation to the main story. If the players’ true 
characters are not involved in the flashback, the players 
should not use any information gained therein to affect the 
“teal” story. The flashback is designed to give the players a 
glimpse of the behind-the-scenes incidents that spawned the 
current events. 


The flashback may also be from one of the true characters’ 
pasts. In that case, how well the characters do will havea direct 
bearing on the game, for at least one of the characters will 
know exactly what led to the current situation. 


Parallel Story 


Parallel stories differ from flashbacks in that they are not 
connected to the “real” story. Only the theme need stay 
constant. In a parallel story, the players take control of a 
completely new group of characters (often similar to their 
original characters), usually ones created by the Storyteller. By 
playing through the parallel story, the players will get a better 
grasp of what is transpiring in the main story. 

Players often enjoy parallel stories because they give them the 
chance to play characters they would otherwise never have used. 
They are usually set in completely unexpected environments, and 
the players uncover surprises everywhere they tum. While Story- 
tellershave tobe freer with information ina parallel story, there will 
be plenty of new things for the players to discover. 

Every story has a parallel story waiting to be told, but don’t 
overuse this technique. Parallel storieshave the most impact when. 
they are used infrequently to impart a new facet of the theme. 


(Dream Sequence 


Many fantasy stories have been told asdream sequences. In fact, 
the clichéd ending, “...and then he awoke to discover that it had 
only been a dream...” may have soured this advanced story 
concept. Still, dream sequences can be extremely effective, espe- 
cially in the context of storytelling games. 

A dream sequence is actually just what the cliché says. It's 
adream that is either shared by all the characters or is specific 
to one of them. In the dream, the characters are either 
themselves or parodies of themselves. If the dream is that of 
only one character, the other players may still participate in 
the dream by assuming the roles of their own characters or, as 
in parallel stories, entirely new characters. 

Adreamisan interesting format for storytelling, for itallows 
the Storyteller to be much more liberal in her treatment of 
storytelling conventions. For instance, the Storyteller can 
exert more control over the characters, or she can nullify the 
laws of physics and ignore the Werewolf systems. Characters 
may suddenly demonstrate new Gifts or forget old ones. 

The dream need not be that of a character. A person 
completely unknown to the characters may have a vision that 
somehow relates to the characters. The players need never 
know whose dream they entered, but the story of the dream 
should always be important to their characters. 

The dream should somehow reflect the "real" story, illumi- 
nating an aspect of the story deemed important by the 
Storyteller. For example, if the "real" story involves the 
characters’ hunt fora human who indiscriminately kills beings 
of all races, including humans, then perhaps the dream story 
is one of the hunter's own dreams. His dreams are likely to be 
frightening, as he lashes out against everything in his environ- 
ment. The players may be amazed to see their characters as 
villains—grotesque monstrosities chasing the hunter through 
a surreal landscape. 

Dreams are very important to Garou, who see them as 
primordial connections to the spirit world. Garou, particularly 
those with the Background Trait of Past Life, often have 


Chapter Three: Storytelling 59 


Y/O TIA EN A A —————— MÀ 


precognitive or otherwise important dreams, and an entire 
pack may share dreams. Consequently, these dreams should 
have great impact on the characters. 


Foreshadowing 


Haveyoueverbeenreadingabookorwatchingamovieand 
suddenly gotten a sense of what is going to happen next? This 
has happened to everybody at some time or another, and 
there's more to it than seeing through a poorly constructed, 
clichéd plot. It’s called foreshadowing, and authors, at least the 
good ones, do it on purpose. 

When you gain a sense of what's going to happen, you are 
at the mercy of the Storyteller. Even though you know 
something is going to happen, you don’t know exactly when. 
This timing is the power the Storyteller has over you. By 
wielding this power well, the Storyteller can hold you inastate 
of suspense. When the expected is finally sprung, you are still 
surprised. 

Foreshadowing is a wonderful element to use in storytelling 
games, The characters will often know in advance that things 
are going to happen, so you, the Storyteller, need to use your 
power of timing to keep the excitement at a peak. You should 
make a conscious effort to foreshadow impending events or 
situations by giving subtle hints to the characters. If they pick 
upon the hints, then great. If they don't, well, they had their 
chance. Now they'll be surprised not by the timing, but by the 
event itself. 

You don't want to foreshadow everything that's going to 
happen. When used with restraint, however, it's an effective 
technique. The characters may even know at the very begin- 
ningofthestory exactly how things are going to end. Sure they 
know Pentex is using kidnapped children as bait. They still 
have to go rescue them. 


Repetition 

Repetition is more than just the blatant recurrence of certain 
events or characters. The most innocuous elements, when re- 
peated, may help provide depth to a story. At first, only the 
Storyteller may be aware of the repetition. Something as minor as 
speech patterns or an ever-present corporate logo can get the 
players thinking and involve them that much more in the story. 

Repetition is also a great way to instill paranoia in the 
players. Why are so many people "accidentally" spilling sodas 
on them? Everyone apologizes profusely. No one tries to pick 
a fight. The characters just keep getting spilled on. Maybe 
there is some greater conspiracy. More than likely there isn't, 
and the Storyteller is simply having fun at their expense. 


Pack Conflict 


Intrapack fighting should usually be discouraged. Nothing 
slows down a game or is so likely to upset players as constant 
friction within the group — unless the Storyteller hasan ulterior 
motive. 

Sometimes, however, the story demands such strife. Get the 
characters insulting one another, staring each other down, and 


60 Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


Ama. UR, EPA SEDA D E ————Á—74 


throwing punches. Why do this? Because it will pay off at the end 
of the story. 

Perhaps the story centers around a spirit that is possessing 
one of the characters. Maybe some other Garou is using a Gift 
to provoke such animosity. Maybe one of the characters is 
being blackmailed into destroying the pack. In these ex- 
amples, one player must be in on what the Storyteller is doing. 
Of course, if one player fails to show up for a story, then her 
character is fair game for Storyteller manipulation. 

There are a number of ways to encourage such discord. 
Begin passing secret notes to select players. Surreptitiously 
inform one character that another has been criticizing him 
behind his back. Forceasituation where one character frenzies 
and attacks another. Remember, however, that pack conflict 
should not be a common event; in almost all cases, the pack 
should actually become stronger in the end. When the char- 
acters understand the cause of the strife, they will realize that 
they must work together as never before. 


Symbolism 


A powerful element in literature, symbolism can also be used 
effectively in storytelling. Whilesymbolscan work onasmall scale 
withinasinglestory, theirtrueusefulnessbecomesapparent during 
anextendedchronicle. Withinasinglestory, afomorcan represent 
the price someone will pay for power. In a chronicle, the sheer 
numbersoffomorican represent the alienation somany peoplefeel 
and their need to find identity — any identity. 

Symbols can connect otherwise disparate stories, but cer- 
tain symbols have a more metaphorical aspect. The dove 
symbolizes peace. A torch or flame often represents the quest 
for knowledge. Sand can symbolize time. The Garou them- 
selvesare an importantsymbol, for they represent the instinctual 
aspect of human nature, the Beast humans have not yet 
completely overcome. What a Garou does, he does to survive; 
he is as unblemished by this life, as heedless of “higher 
morality,” as Nature herself. 

If we humans are savages who have adopted society to temper, 
or sometimes further, our aggressive tendencies, then the Garou 
are “humans” who never accepted society. They are savages who 
denied that the dawning of intelligence and reason necessitated 
the conquest of the environment. Werewolves’ lives are still very 
ritualized, for this is the form through which society has en- 
croached upon them. There are Garou who treat these rules with 
disdain, just as there are people in our world whorebel, but the elder 
Garou accept this as the ever-honored Garou philosophy of 
balance being maintained. 

Ofcourse, all symbols are open to interpretation. The moon 
can symbolize the inner self or soul of the Garou, or madness, 
ora number of other things. The spirits can be likened to our 
consciousness, so when the moon is full, spirits are most 
accessible to shamans. Garou born under the new moon can 
most readily hide from the harshness of Garou culture. Thus, 
when Garou howlat the moon, they honor not only its nature 
but their own nature as well. 

Silversymbolically represents the brightest of truths. These 
are the elements of our lives that can most hurt us, even when 


we fancy ourselves invulnerable. Silver is the weapon we use 
against one another, but which can also be turned against us. 
In caring hands, silver can be gloriously beautiful and nobly 
useful, but in hurting hands our most intimate secrets can also 
sear our hearts. 

The meanings of the Wyld, Weaver and Wyrm are very 
accessible, for the Triat asa whole deals with one of the greater 
symbolic elements in the game — spirits. Spirits form the basis 
for how Garou structure reality. Such categorizations auto- 
matically include a cultural bias; thus, spirits can be seen as 
reflective of the deep thoughts of the Garou. Each spirit 
representsa very particular aspect of reality. The nature of the 
aspect varies from spirit to spirit, but it is something specific, 
like greed, strength or compassion. The interaction between 
these spirits and the Triat speaks volumes. 

The Wyld is an optimizing of reality. It is the aspect of reality 
that permits freedom, or mutability, to the rest of reality. So long 
as the Wyld exists, change is possible. No system, no matter how 
vain, practical or evil, can long exist where others have hamessed 
the Wyld. No matter how good the Wyld seems, though, it must 
be stabilized. Otherwise, its dynamic functions will quickly under- 
mine the capacity for anything at all to exist in a discernible form. 
Only chaos would remain. 

The Weaver is just the opposite. It represents tradition, ritual, 
and practice — the immutable elements of reality. The Weaver 
attempts tocodify everything that exists or that could exist. In fact, 
the very process ofexistence and nonexistence is what the Weaver 


S 
Pan 


/ Wy 


A 


seeks to control. Only those things the Weaver has structured can 
exist. While life requires stabilizing factors lest everything run 
amok, the Weaverseekstoo muchstability. There mustbe change, 
for without change there is stagnation. 

The Wyrm is the worst of both of the others. It iscorruption, 
stagnation and eventually the nothingness of the void, for the 
Wyrm twists and catabolizes otherwise pure functions. The 
Wyrm is what happens when a system cannot properly defend 
itself from either too much or too little form. 


Advanced Chronicles 


Just as stories have advanced concepts that can be utilized 
once the basics have been mastered, so too do chronicles. 
Advanced concepts in chronicles, however, require a great 
deal of planning and preparation to use effectively. 


Historical 


Though this book assumes that a Werewolf chronicle will be 
setinthe WorldofDarkness, there isnoreasona Storytellercannot 
set a chronicle in the past. What role did the Garou play in the 
American Civil War? For that matter, what were tribal conflicts 
like during the prehistory of the Impergium? While this requires 
theStoryteller to learn something about the period during which 
thechronicle isset, italsogiveshim greater freedom, for the players 
know less about their characters’ world. 


Other Realms 


Though the stories of Werewolf: The Apocalypse are 
intended to be set against the backdrop ofa world much like 
ourown, the Garouare vital and interesting enough to offer 
possibilities in other settings as well. Stories can be set on 
a post-holocaust world; here, the Garou's battle is truly 
desperate, for the machinations of mankind's wars have 
brought the world perilously close to ruin. Perhaps the 
troupe prefers a fantasy setting wherein the Garou are but 
one of many strange races of the world. Still other stories 
can be set in a science fiction setting where the Garou have 
the opportunity to thwart the power of the Weaver on 
other planets before it even poses a threat. 


Troupe-Style Play 


In troupe-style play, players control more than one 
character and, usually, share the storytelling duties. For 
instance, one member of the troupe may be interested in 
telling Umbra-oriented stories, while another prefers more 
physical ones. Thus, the players create two packs within the 
same sept, and while they have many opportunities to mix, 
usually each is off doing its own thing. 

Another way to handle troupe-style play is to have each 
character create both Garou and Kinfolk characters. The 
Kinfolk can be the basis of the story, investigating odd 
occurrences and battling the Wyrm, but they may call on 
the Garou in times of trouble.

It must have a competition with us, my preciouss! If precious

— J.R.R. Tolkien, The Hobbit 


All games have rules. Some have only a few and are fairly 
simple, such as Chutesand Ladders. Others have many andare 
extremely complicated, like bridge. Werewolf has something 
in common with both types — it has only a few simple rules, 
but these few rules have a large number of permutations. You 
need only learn the basic rules, but their permutations evoke 
the flavor of the game, allowing it to simulate the complexity 
of real life. This chapter provides the basic rules of Werewolf; 
the number of permutations is for you to decide. 

Rules are like the myths that shape and describe a culture. 
They define what is important and delineate the possibilities 
of existence. Though these rules may seem somewhat strange 
and exotic, they really aren't all that complicated. Once you 
understand them, you'll understand how to play this game. Just 
concentrate on learning these basics; everything else will 
come naturally. 


Chapter Four: Rules 


ee en a 


Time 

A word of the faith that never backs, 

Here or henceforth it is the same to me, I accept Time 

absolutely. 

It alone is without flaw, it alone rounds and completes all. 

That mystic baffling wonder alone completes all. 

— Walt Whitman, "Song of Myself" 

The first thing you need to learn is how time passes in 
Werewolf. There are five different ways to describe time, 
progressing from the smallest unit to the all-encompassing 
one. 

* Turn — One unit of time within a scene, anywhere 
from three seconds to three minutes in length. A turn is 
enough time to take one action (discussed below). 

* Scene — One compact period ofaction and roleplaying 
that takes place in a single location. A scene is made up of 
a variable number of turns (as many as it takes to complete 
it); it can also be completed strictly through roleplaying, 
which requires no use of turns. 


65 


* Chapter — One independent part of a story, almost 
always played in one game session. It is made up ofa number 
of scenes connected by periods of downtime. 

* Story — A complete tale, with an introduction, 
buildup and climax, that often takes several chapters to 
complete. 

* Chronicle — A whole series of stories connected by 
the lives of the characters and perhaps a broadly conceived 
theme and plot. It is simply the ongoing story told by you 
and the players. 


Actions 


Besides acting out their characters' speeches and con- 
versations, players will want their characters to perform (or 
at least attempt to perform) actions they describe to the 
Storyteller. An action can be anything from jumping over 
a gorge to glancing over one's shoulder to see if anyone is 
following. The player tells the Storyteller what her charac- 
ter is doing and details the procedure she uses. 

Many actions are automatic — for instance, when a 
player tells the Storyteller that her character walks across 
the street toward the warehouse. All the Storyteller needs 
to do is keep track of where the character is and what she 
is doing. However, certain actions require a dice roll to 
determine success or failure. 


Rolling (Dice 


There is always chance in life. There's a chance you'll 
win the lottery, a chance you'll be audited, and a chance 
you'll die in a plane crash. Chance plays a role in Werewolf 
aswell. However, Werewolf players use dice to simulate the 
duplicity of Lady Luck. 

Werewolf requires the use of 10-sided dice, which you can 
buy in any game store. If you are the Storyteller, you will want 
a lot of dice, at least 10, all to yourself. As a player, you'll also 
want dice, but you may share dice with other players. 

Whenever the success of an action is in doubt, or the 
Storyteller thinks there is a chance your character might 
fail, you will have to roll dice. This gives your character an 
opportunity to let weaknesses and strengths exhibit them- 
selves, thereby revealing something of the character's true 
nature to both you and the other players. 


Ratings 

A character is described by her Traits — the innate and 
learned abilities and aptitudes she possesses. Traits are defined 
by numbers; each Trait hasa rating from 1 to 5, which describes 
the character’s ability in that particular Trait. A 1 is lousy, 
while a5 issuperb. This scale of 1 to 5 is the “star” rating system 
made famous by movie and restaurant critics. 

The normal human Trait range is from 1 to 3, with 2 
being average. However, exceptional people can have Traits 


———^^^(——Ó— rra 


of 4 (exceptional) or 5 (superb), or even have a zero in a 
Trait (which is extremely rare, but not unheard of). 

x Abysmal 

. Poor 

Average 

Good 

Exceptional 
* Superb 

For each dot your character has in a particular Trait, you 
get to roll one die. Thus, if you had four dots in Strength, 
you would get to roll four dice. If you had one dot in 
Perception, you would only get to roll one die. However, 
you almost never simply roll the number of dice you have 
in an Attribute, which defines your intrinsic capabilities. 
Usually you get to add the number of dice you have in an 
Attribute to the number of dice you have in an Ability — 
things that you know and have learned. 


SoiftheStoryteller wants the players to roll to see if they 
notice the patrol car creeping up behind them, he would 
have them roll Perception + Alertness — an Attribute + an 
Ability. They would take as many dice as they had dots in 
Perception and put them in their hands. Then they would 
take as many dice as they had dots in Alertness and put 
those in their hands also. 

These dice are collectively called the Dice Pool. A 
character's Dice Pool delineates the total number of dice a 
player may roll in a single turn — usually fora single action, 
though a player can divide a Dice Pool in order to allow her 
character to perform more than one action. A player almost 
always rolls a number of dice equal to a Trait's permanent 
rating (the circles), not its current score (the squares). 

Certain actions don't require or even have an appropri- 
ate Ability. An example of this is when a player soaks 
damage from an attack. In such cases, the player uses only 
an Attribute, rolling the number of dice listed for that 
Attribute — in this case, Stamina. 

There is absolutely nosituation where more than two Traits 
can combine to form a Dice Pool. Only one Trait can be used 
ifithasa potential value of 10 (suchas Willpower). Thismeans 
that a Trait like Willpower can never be combined with 
another Trait. It is generally impossible for a normal human 
being to have more than 10 dice in a Dice Pool. 


Difficulties 

It is easy, the descending down to Avernus. 

But to climb again, 

To trace the footsteps back to the air above, 

There lies the task, the toil. 

— Virgil, The Aeneid 

Now you've got to figure out what you need to look for 
when you roll the dice. The Storyteller assigns each task a 
difficulty rating, a number that quantifies the challenge 


posed by the task. A difficulty is always a number between 
2 and 10. You need to roll that number or higher on at least 


u 127 SS ee 


one of the dice in your Pool in order to succeed. Each time 
you do so, it's called a success. If the difficulty is a 6 and you 
rolla2,3,5, 6and9, you have scored two successes. Though 
you usually need only one success to succeed, the more 
successes you score, the better you perform. Scoring only 
one success is considered a marginal success, while scoring 
three is considered a complete success, and scoring five is a 
momentous event. 


Difficulties

Exceptional

You can see that if the difficulty is lower, it becomes easier 
toscoreasuccess, while if it ishigher, it becomes more difficult. 
The Storyteller will assign high difficulties whenever the 
action you have decided to take is difficult, and will either let 
your character do something automatically (because her At- 
tributes and Abilities are so high) or assign a low difficulty if 
the desired action is particularly easy. 

Though they are not on the list above, you, as the Story- 
teller, can also assign difficulties of 2 or 10. However, these 
should almost never be used. Difficulty 2 is so pathetically easy 
that you might as well let the player succeed without wasting 
time ona roll. Difficulty 10 is so difficult that there is an equal 
chance to botch (described below) as there is to succeed, no 
matter how many dice the player rolls. A 10 is pretty near 
impossible. On the rare occasions when you do announce a 
difficulty of 10, be sure you realize how impossible you are 
making the chance of success. If a player ever rolls a 10, the 
result is automatically a success, no matter what. 

Unless the Storyteller says otherwise, the difficulty for a 
particular task is always 6. This is the standard difficulty, 
and 6 is assumed if a difficulty number is otherwise un- 
stated. 


The @ule of One 


The last thing you need to know about rolling dice is the 
“rule of one.” Whenever you olla 1, it cancels out a success. 
It completely takes it away. You remove both the "success! 
die and the “1” die and pay them no more heed. If you roll 
more “1's” than you do successes, a disaster occurs; some- 
thing called a “botch” takes place. Don't count the “1's” 
that canceled out successes, but if even a single "1" is left 
after all the successes have been canceled, a botch occurs. 


Chapter Four: Rules 67 


y mem. am, 


—————Z 


Getting a single “1” or five “1's” has about the same result 
in most ca: the circumstances surrounding the botch 
determine if it is catastrophic or a minor mishap. If there 
aren't any “1’s” or successes left, you've simply failed. 


Automatic Successes 


You don't want to be rolling dice all the time; it can get 
in the way of the roleplaying. Werewolf employs a very 
simple system for automatic successes, allowing players to 
avoid making rolls for actions their characters could per- 
form in their sleep. 

It works like this: if the number of dice in your Dice Pool 
equals or exceeds the assigned difficulty, your character 
succeeds automatically. Such a success is considered mar- 
ginal (the equivalent of scoring only one success), so a 


player will sometimes want to roll anyway in an attempt to 
gain even more successes. But for very simple and often- 
repeated actions, automatic successes can eliminate a lot of 
wasted time. (Note that certain actions, such as combat, are 
always problematic and should not be handled with this 
system.) 

The automatic success rules can be used to eliminate 
dice rolling completely, something you will want to do 
during Live-Action roleplaying. In such situations, auto- 
matic successes aren't a matter of choice. Either you are 
good enough to succeed or you are not. It is simple, but so 
was Cops ‘n’ Robbers and we liked it just fine. The story was 
what was important; the rules didn't matter. 


This simple system even has a twist, making it not quite 
so black-and-white. A Willpower point (see the Traits 
Chapter) can be spent to earn an automatic success. You 
won't want to do this often, but for certain actions it can be 
very advantageous to do so. Of course, the Willpower 
expenditure only counts for one success if multiple suc- 
cesses are required. 

When we play, we usually combine dice rolling and 
automatic successes. During mostscenes— especially when 
we're deeply involved in the story — we don't even roll 
dice, preferring to roleplay through scenes without inter- 
ruptions. However, when we get in the mood for 
playing-a-game rather than telling-a-story, we make lots of 
dice rolls and add many complications to the rules. 


Complications 


You may have already realized that it is quite easy to score 
a single success, even when you roll only one or two dice. 
You have a 7596 chance fora marginal success when you roll 
only two dice and the difficulty is 6. While that may sound 
too easy, there are various ways to complicate matters, some 
of which are discussed below. For troupes heavily into 
roleplaying, simple rolls and automatic successes are enough. 
Generally, complications are needed only if the players or 
you wanta break from the roleplaying, if you wanta realistic 
result or if you want to make a game out of the scene. 
Complications add drama to the story and create a depth of 
passion and focus. 


Extended Actions 


In order to succeed fully, you will sometimes need more 
than one success — you will need to accumulate three, or 
seven, or even (rarely) 20 successes. An action that requires 
only one success is called a simple action. An action that 


requires more than one success is called an extended action. 

An extended action allows you to roll over and over on 
subsequent turns in an attempt to collect enough successes 
to succeed. For instance, your character is climbing a tree. 
The Storyteller announces that when you roll a total of 
seven successes, your character has climbed to the top. 
She'll get there eventually, but the more times you roll, the 
more chances your character has to botch and injure 
herself. If she is attempting to climb down the tree because 
it is on fire, the amount of time it takes becomes exceed- 
ingly important. 

During an extended action, you can keep trying to 
obtain successes for as long as you want, or at least until you 
fail to score even one success. If you botch, your character 
may have to start over from scratch, with no accumulated 
successes. The Storyteller may decide not to let the charac- 
ter try again at all. 

This type of action is more complicated than a simple 
action and should not often be employed in the middle of 
intense roleplaying. As the Storyteller, you decide what 


68 Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


e ————— MANN 


type of action is appropriate. A little bit of experience will 
serve you well when employing these rules. 


Resisted Actions 


Sometimes you will act in opposition to another charac- 
ter. Both of you make rolls, with a difficulty often indicated 
by a Trait of the other character, and the person who scores 
the most successes succeeds. However, you are considered 
to score only as many successes as the amount by which you 
exceed your opponent’s successes. The opponent's suc- 
cesses eliminate your own, just as “1’s” do. Therefore, it is 
very difficult, and rare, to achieve an outstanding success 
onaresistedaction. Even if your opponent cannot beat you, 
she can diminish the effect of your efforts. During actions 
that are both extended and resisted, one of the opponents 
must collect a certain number of successes in order to 
succeed completely. Each success above the opponent's 
total number of successes in a single turn is added to a 
success total. The first opponent to collect the designated 
number of successes wins the contest. 


Teamwork 


Sometimes characters can work together to collect suc- 
cesses, mostoftenduringanextendedaction. At theStoryteller's 
discretion, two or more characters can make rolls separately 
and combine their successes. They may never combine their 
separate Traits for one roll. Teamwork is effective in some 
circumstances, such as when engaging in combat, shadowing 
prey, collecting information and repairing devices. During 
others, it can actually be a hindrance, such as in many social 
actions (where it can confuse the subject). 

The chart below may serve to dispel your confusion regard- 
ing some of the different types of rolls that can be made. 


Trying Jt Again 

It can often be frustrating to fail. If you are having trouble 
with your computer and can't figure out the source of the 
system error, then you're in for an angst-ridden time. This 
frustration is reflected in Werewolf by increasing the difficulty 
of any action if it is tried again after it's already been failed. 

Whenever a character attempts an action she has previ- 
ously failed, the Storyteller has the option of increasing the 
difficulty of the action by one. Consider a character who 
tries to intimidate someone. If the first attempt failed, it's 
going be harder the second time around, so the difficulty is 
one greater. If tried a third time, then the difficulty is two 
greater. In cases like this, though, the Storyteller might 
simply rule that the character cannot even make another 
try — how do you intimidate someone who has already 
called your bluff? 

Other examples of when to use the rule are: picking a 
lock (Repair), scalinga wall (Athletics), and remembering 
a word in a foreign language (Linguistics). 

Sometimes the Storyteller shouldn't invoke this rule. A 
notable example is during combat. Missing someone with 
a first gunshot doesn't necessarily mean that the gunman is 


p/m. am, 


Chapter Four: Rules 


The Golden Rule 


Remember that in the end there is only one real rule 
in Werewolf: there are no rules. You should fashion 


this game into whatever you need it to be — if the rules 
get in your way, then ignore or change them. In the 
end, the true complexity and beauty of the real world 
cannot be captured by rules; it takes storytelling and 
imagination to do that. Indeed, these rules are not so 
much rules as they are guidelines, and you are free to 
use, abuse, ignore and change them as you wish. 


frustrated and hasa better chance of missing again. But after 
the gunman has missed a couple of times, especially if they 
are easy, close-range shots... 

Other examples of when not to use the rule are: seeing 
something out of the corner of the eye (Alertness) and 
dodging an attack (Dodge). 


Try Jt Out 


Well, that's it. These are the rules. This system for dice 
is all you really need to know in order to play this game. All 
the other rules are just clarifications and exceptions. So 
long as you understand what’s been discussed here, you 
won't have any difficulty understanding anything else. If 
you don't think you've caught everything, just read the 
above again; you'll find it makes more sense the second time 
around. 

Now go ahead and make a few rolls, using the example 
character from Chapter Five. Walks-No-Road is scanning 
the room in an attempt to detect a malevolent Bane that he 
thinks has entered the physical world from the Umbra. The 
Storyteller decides the action has a difficulty of 6. Take 
three dice because of Walks-No-Road's Perception of 3, 
and three dice because of his Alertness of 3. You should now 
have six dice in your hand —a fair amount. You don't have 
a large chance of failing (you could even decide to accept 
an automatic success, because the number of dice you have 
matches the difficulty), but go ahead and roll; you never 
know. Tally your number of successes, making sure to 
subtract a success for every “1” you roll. Did you make it or 
did you botch? The more successes you score, the better and 
faster Walks-No-Road sees the Bane. Only one success 
might mean that, while Walks-No-Road senses that the 
Bane is nearby, he can’t really get a fix on it. Several 
successes could indicate that Walks-No-Road sees it clearly 
and can even identify it. 


Next, try out an extended and resisted action. An 
example of this is an arm wrestling match. It requires an 
indefinite series of rolls, each requiring different difficul- 
ties. You need to accumulate five successes more than your 
opponent in order to win. A botch eliminates all of your 
accumulated successes. 


SS A 


| 


* First roll: Each player rolls Strength; the difficulty is 
the opponent's Dexterity + 3 (speed is important at first). 

* Second and third rolls: Each player rolls Strength; the 
difficulty is the opponent's Strength + 3. 

* Fourth roll (and all subsequent ones): Each player rolls 
Strength; the difficulty is the opponent's Willpower. 


Examples of Rolls 


Followingare some examples of rolls, to provide you with 
some ideas on how to incorporate these rules into your 
roleplaying. Please note that each Attribute can work with 
each Ability, so there are 270 potential types of simple rolls 
that can be made. Admittedly, you will not often roll 
Stamina * Computer, but it might come up. 

* Youare standing watch while your companions catch 
a few hours of sleep. Make a Stamina * Alertness roll 
(difficulty 7) to see how awake and alert you are when 
intruders finally approach in the pre-dawn gloom. 

* A Black Spiral Dancer is creeping up behind you; roll 
Perception * Alertness (difficulty 9) tosee if you notice her 
approach. 

* A tough street punk refuses to take your commands. 
Roll Strength + Leadership (difficulty 7) in an attempt to 
dominate him physically and get him to do what you say. 

* Can you convince the gathering crowd to do as you 
have asked? Roll Charisma + Leadership (difficulty 7) as 


you attempt to give an off-the-cuff speech. You'll need four 
successes to convince them completely. 

* Your archrival is giving a speech to the assembled 
elders of the moot. Roll Perception + Leadership (difficulty 
6) to evaluate how good a leader she is. If you somehow 
score five successes, you'll know her exact rating. 

* After being questioned for hours, roll Stamina + 
Acting (difficulty 8) to see if you can maintain your story 
successfully. Five successes and you'll finally convince 
them. 

* You threaten the young man by trying to lift him up by 
his collar; roll Strength + Intimidation (difficulty 8). 

* Yelling and screaming at the taxi driver, you try to get 
him to drive even faster. Roll Charisma + Intimidation 
(difficulty 6). 

* You ask a series of rapid-fire questions in order to 
discover what threats will intimidate the subject. Roll Wits 
+ Intimidation (difficulty 6). 

* You attempt to use what you know about human 
feelings to calm the crazed woman down. If you can under- 
stand the meaning of that strange expression on her face, 
perhaps you can stop her from screaming. Roll Manipula- 
tion + Empathy (difficulty 6). 

e In order to stop the motor from blowing up, you've got 
to rip the whatchamacallit out of the thingamajig. Roll 
Strength + Repair (difficulty 6). 

* You try to decipher what's wrong with the car engine 
from the strange sounds it is making. Roll Perception + 
Repair (difficulty 6). 

Reining in the terrified horses takes a lot of force and 
expertise. Roll Strength + Animal Ken (difficulty 9). 

* You attempt to decipher why the ravens are crying so 
loudly and suddenly. Roll Intelligence + Animal Ken 
(difficulty 9). 

* You motion to the truck driver to pull over, pointing 
at his wheels and pretending to yell something out the 
window. Roll Manipulation * Drive (difficulty 4). 

* Suddenly, a man pushesa crate out of the van you have 
been chasing — roll Wits + Drive to see if you can avoid 
hitting it (difficulty 6). 

* How long can you remain motionless in the bushes as 
the two guards chat for hours on end? Roll Stamina + 
Stealth (difficulty 7). Each success indicates the passing of 
10 minutes. 

* You try to follow the intricate paper trail to the 
company that manufactured the biological contaminants 
in the first place. Roll Intelligence * Investigation (diffi- 
culty 9). 

* Isthestore clerk lying about what he remembers? Roll 
Perception * Investigation (difficulty 7). 

+ You need to add precisely 2.3 mg of nitrous oxide to 
the solution — no less, no more. Roll Dexterity * Science 
(difficulty 4).

* You foolishly attempt to break into Southern Bell's
