(Disconnection 


Garou are meant to migrate between the Umbra and the 
physical world. If they stay in one, they begin to disconnect 
from the other. 

For each full year a Garou spends in the Umbra, add one 
to the difficulty of returning to the physical Realm. A 
similar penalty is levied for each full year spent in the 
physical world; the longer a Garou stays in physical reality, 
the harder it will be for her to return to the Umbra. A quest 
in the other Realm can undo this disconnection. 

For non-Garou who find themselves in the Umbra, such 
as those taken there via Grasp the Beyond, the risk of 
disconnection is greater. After a few months, they will 
gradually forget their life on Earth. Over the years, they 
become more and more ephemeral, eventually losing all 
physical form and becoming spirits. 


Umbral Travel 


Once a Garou has successfully stepped sideways, he 
arrives in the Penumbra. The Penumbra is the spiritual 
representation of the physical place in which he was stand- 
ing when he stepped sideways. He can physically walk 
though the Penumbra to other areas that correspond to 
otherpartsof Earth, orhecan travel deeper into the Umbra. 
If he walks through the Penumbra to a new area and then 
travels back to Earth, he will emerge on the physical world 
in the place that corresponds to the new area. 

When traveling in the Umbra, Garou move as they 
normally do — usually by walking, although some Gifts 
may allow them to fly. Once out of the Penumbra and into 
the Near Umbra, distances are no longer set. There are no 
maps, milestones or directions. A Garou simply decides 
where she wants to go — a Near Realm, for example — 
steps onto a Moon Path, and begins walking. The time it 
takes to travel to certain locations varies — seemingly 
without rhyme or reason, although some Theurges say this 
fluctuation involves moon phase, season and environment. 
Travel times are entirely up to the Storyteller. 


Moon Paths 


To go deeper into the Umbra, the Garou must find a 
Moon Path to his destination. Moon Paths are easier and 
safer to use during a full moon, because Lunes guard them. 
However, Lunesare at their most fickle and wrathful during 


——— 


the full moon. If the traveling Garou dares to step off the 
Moon Path, his fate israndom and unpredictable; the Lunes 
may ignore him or play pranks on him. Lunes are tricksters, 
and their pranks range from the annoying to the deadly, at 
the Storyteller's option. 

During the crescent moon, Garou must roll Perception 
+ Enigmas (difficulty 6) to be certain of their route. During 
the new moon, Moon Paths are all but unwalkable, and 
utterly deadly. 


Spirit Tracks 


Garou can also travel the Umbra by walking the Spirit 
Tracks made by spirits using Airt Sense. Lunes do not 
protect these paths, which are difficult to find without a 
spirit guide. These paths are also temporary and may disap- 
pear while a Garou is walking them, leaving him lost in the 
trackless Umbra. Should this occur, a spirit with the Airt 
Sense Charm must be bargained with to lead the Garou 
back to a Moon Path or another Spirit Track. 


Spirit Gates 


Many Umbral Realms are connected by Spirit Gates. 
Garou who find such a portal can instantly appear in the 
Realm to which it connects. Many Spirit Gates are guarded, 
appropriately enough, by spirits. Anchorheads are a form of 
Spirit Gate. 


Other Forms of Umbral Travel 


Rumors abound of other forms of Umbral travel avail- 
able to brave or foolhardy travelers. Glass Walkers are 
rumored to know how to traverse the Webs ofthe Weaver, 
which connect all of reality. The Wyrm is rumored to have 
bored tunnels throughout the Umbra. Wyldlings seem to 
have a talent for simply ceasing to be in one area and 
appearing in another. 


Peeking 


Dwellers in the Umbra cannot automatically see the 
physical world on the other side of the Gauntlet, just as 
dwellers in the Realm cannot automatically see the Umbra. 
Even though humans have spirits, their un-Awakened 
spirits have no counterparts on the Penumbra. 

To see into the physical world from the Umbra, the 
Garou must make a Gnosis roll (difficulty of the area’s 
Gauntlet). If she succeeds, her vision of the Umbral land- 
scape is replaced by a shadowy version of the corresponding 
physical site, including the people, buildings and objects 
occupying the space. The Garou cannot discern fine de- 
tails, like newsprint, unless she scores four or more successes. 
Garou do have nearly full access to smells and sounds from 
the Realm. 

Peeking is considered dangerous, for the Garou is un- 
aware of the Umbral environment while peeking. Peeking 
does not reveal spirits in the Umbra, but it does reveal 


Chapter Seven: The Spirit World 


POL EN LT TR -————— 


spirits in the physical world — even those locked into 
objects such as fetishes. 

Note that many spirits can Peek at will, and often switch 
back and forth between the two forms of sight. 


The Nature of Spirits 


The Umbra houses a staggering variety of spirits. They 
are creatures of raw soul force and are not intertwined with 
flesh and blood. Some are closely related to beings in the 
Realm, but many are unique to the Umbra and are difficult 
to describe in physical terms. 

The denizens of the spirit world have a clear hierarchy. 
The very greatest spirits exude/create lesser spirits, which 
in turn devolve into still lesser spirits. These greater spirits 
are called patrons of the lesser. Though most spirits appear 
to have patrons, the Garou suspect that certain rogue spirits 
exist outside the chain of spirit patronage. 

The greatest spirit is Gaia. Below Her is the Triat: the 
Wyld, the Weaver and the Wyrm. Below the Triat are the 
Celestines, who are akin to gods. Below the Celestines are 
the Incarna: the lords and kings of the spirit world. Their 
servants, the Jagglings and Gafflings, are like knights and 
vassals. 

Examples of individual spirits can be found in the Ap- 
pendix (pp. 259-273). 

Gaia 

The Realm-system begins with Gaia and is bounded by 
Gaia. All things that exist within the Tellurian are consid- 
ered to be of Gaia, though some Garou would refute the 
notion that evil beings are truly a part of Gaia. Gaia’s 
growth and development are inextricably linked to the 
growth and development of the living beings within Her. 
Gaia loves all of Her creations, and extends to them a pure, 
unconditional acceptance and respect. Life is both a mani- 
festation of Gaia anda celebration of her glory. Death is but 
a transfiguration of Gaian energy, as the dying being as- 
cends to a new state in the cosmological cycle. This natural 
cycle of death and life has been altered by powerful intelli- 
gences, and this in turn weakens Gaia. She is also greatly 
weakened and degraded by the ongoing clash of the Triat. 
The Garou rage at the violence that the Weaver and the 
Wyrm inflict on Gaia, and have pledged their lives and 
souls to defending, upholding and restoring Her. They fear 
that the impending Apocalypse may signal her ultimate 
destruction. 


The Triat 


Below Gaia in cosmic power are the mysterious, personi- 
fied forces called the Wyld, the Weaver, and the Wyrm. 
According to the Garou, these entities, collectively called 
the Triat, shape and control eternity. The interplay of these 
impersonal, spiritual forces makes up the Tellurian and 
comprises all within it. 


177 


At a base level, the members of the Triat represent the 
forces of creation, growth, and destruction, but they are far 
more than that. They represent potential, materialization, 
and unraveling. They also embody chaos, order, and bal- 
ance. 


The Wyld 


Creation begins with the Wyld. The Wyld is pure change. 
It is not so much undifferentiated chaos as it is elemental 
transmutation. It constantly swirls with change, adapta- 
tion, and change again. The Wyld is alive with possibility: 
the Wyld IS possibility itself. Every ant and tree contains 
within its spirit a particle of this chaos of possibility. No 
Garou Theurge or human mage or caretaker spirit has ever 
been able to quantify that tiny drop of eternity. Gaia comes 
first and foremost from the Wyld; indeed, She could not 
exist without it. 

The Wyld is a complete entity, but without the Weaver, 
the Wyld loses all the forms it spawns. They return to the 
primal forge at the very moment of birth. To be all forms at 
all times is to be no form at all. Life without bounds cannot 
know itself inall parts. This means that the Wyld is the least 
personified of the three. Its constant mutability precludes 
true form or nature. The Wyrm is also essential to the Wyld, 
because the Wyrm destroys select aspects of the Weaver's 
Web and returns the uncreated matter to the Wyld. 

In the Deep Umbra, the Wyld has the potential to be the 
most powerful member of the Triat — almost as powerful as 
Gaia. In the physical Realm, however, the Wyld is the least 
powerful of the Triat. Its very essence, limitless possibility, 
is daily forced from the physical world by humanity's focus 
upon "logic" and "reason." As logic is forced upon an 
illogical world, there is less and less room for the magic of 
uncaused change. Only a few scattered sites of pure Wyld 
energy still exist; these the Garou guard with their blood 
and the blood of their offspring. Though the Wyld steadily 
loses sway in the physical world, it is unassailable in its 
home in the Deep Umbra. No danger can threaten it there, 
forany enemy is dissolved into primordial protoplasm upon 
coming into contact with the Wyld. 

The Garou venerate the Wyld, seeing it as a symbol of 
their struggle against the Apocalypse and a promise of a 
brighter day. Its Realms teem with countless forms of life. 
In the world that grows from the Wyld, anything can 
happen. Outnumbered, outfought, outmaneuvered Garou 
may even be able to prevail against the forces that threaten 
to devour Gaia. The Wyld is a bright hope, a promise of 
change from a wicked world of evil matter and entropic 
destruction. 

Though the Garou can expect no direct aid from this 
unfathomable force, the Wyld may prove the greatest ally 
to the Garou and Gaia. 


The Weaver 


From the heedless change of the Wyld came ordered 
growth. The Weaver selected sections of the turbulent 


178 


Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


OS GE BEUTE, SS MÀ 


creation and kept them from dissolving into the boisterous 
whole at the instant of their birth. Undifferentiated cre- 
ation was thereby structured and locked into form. Thus did 
the Weaver spin the first strands of that structure which 
would become the fabric of the universe — the Pattern 
Web. 

This changed everything. Where there was form, there 
could be growth and progress. Meaning was now imposed 
on meaningless potential. Inconstant infinity had yielded 
to enduring eternity. Then the Wyrm arrived and pruned 
away sections of the Weaver's creation. The Weaver's 
perfect patterns were now imperfect, but balanced. Ac- 
cording to the Garou, this is the true cosmological cycle of 
chaos, creation, and destruction. It lasted an eternity, but 
was ultimately shattered when the Weaver gained con- 
sciousness. 

The Garou disagree on exactly what happened. Some 
say that only the Triat can completely comprehend it. 
Nonetheless, there are theories. Some say the Weaver tried 
to spin the entire Wyld into full, patterned existence. This 
created an explosion of creation, which drove the Weaver 
insane. She looked into the Web and saw only madness. 
The Wyrm, exhausted from trying to maintain the balance, 
became ensnared in creation. The Wyrm is still there, these 
theorists say, struggling to free itself and destroying all 
creation from the inside. 

Otherssay the Weaver was far more calculating, and that 
her only madness is power-lust. The Weaver, say these 
Garou, attempted to make logical advancement and per- 
manence the cornerstones of the Tellurian. Once she 
established causality, she set out to impose causality on 
everything. The Wyrm was an obstacle to this process, 
because it destroyed by its own rules rather than the rules of 
the Weaver. So the Weaver ensnared the Wyrm in the 
Pattern Web and directed its destruction along the lines of 
causality. But her control over it is not absolute, and it still 
manages to destroy blindly, along pattern other than hers. 
This limits her power, which is cosmologically helpful, but 
injures Gaia, which is not. 

Still other Garou, like the Glass Walkers, claim that the 
Wyrm is the source of trouble, because the Wyrm at- 
tempted to destroy the Wyld altogether. If the Wyld were 
gone, nothing more could be created, and the Wyrm would 
emerge victorious. The Wyrm tried to use the Weaver to 
weaken the Wyld by ensnaring it, but the Weaver could not 
bind all of infinity. Instead, she spun herself into madness. 
The Wyrm was caught in a trap of its own devising, and 
remains there to this day. Meanwhile, the eternal Wyld 
endures. The Glass Walkers insist that the Weaver is 
simply trying to defend herself, and that she holds the key 
to stopping the Wyrm. 

Most Garou agree that the Weaver was the first of the 
Triat to gain intelligence. Whether this drove her mad or 
is a product of her madness is unknown. 

The Weaver is now powerful beyond her station. The 
ancient balance of pattern and chaos has been replaced by 


NS 


stagnation and decay. When her Webs are finished, all the 
Tellurian will be bound in rigid, motionless, changeless 
strands. 


The Wyrm 


The Wyrm is the third and last in the Triat. It was once 
the restorer of balance, bringing harmony where there was 
none and ensuring that neither the order of the Weaver nor 
the chaos of the Wyld prevailed throughout reality. Sus- 
pended between Chaos below and the Pattern Web above, 
the Wyrm removed all that was not harmonious. 

Then the Wyrm became ensnared in the Pattern Web. 
By looking into the madness of the Weaver's Web, it gained 
sentience and became trapped in the Weaver’s deadly 
Apocalyptic game. The Wyrm fractured into three person- 
alities and as a result is not always able to coordinate its 
actions. 

Where the Wyrm was once the bringer of harmony, it is 
now the harbinger of the Apocalypse, spawning entropy, 
decay and corruption. Unable to destroy overtly and hon- 
orably, it destroys from within. It destroys all those weak 
enough in spirit to succumb to the temptations of hatred 
and envy. 

Some say the Wyrm began the great imbalance by 
seeking to use the Weaver to calcify the Wyld into nothing, 
thereby freeing the Wyrm to destroy all of creation. Now 
the Wyrm is caught ina trap of its own devising —a tribute 
to the perils of greed. 

The Wyrm found many sentients weak enough to sur- 
render to its corruption; it now has many servants. Because 
its decay is in all things, it is able to whisper to the dark 
places inside all intelligent creatures. Thus its disease 
spreads in the physical and spirit worlds, where it has won 
many battles and conquered many Realms. 

Garou and spirit pathfinders have traveled to the Realms 
of the Wyrm — places that blind destruction has left utterly 
devoid of Gaia. Those who dwell there are enslaved or 
destroyed by the most wicked of Banes and Incarna. If the 
Wyrm has its way, all the world will be thus remade — until 
all is destroyed. 


Celestines 


Below the Triat in the cosmological totem pole lie the 
Celestines. The greatest of the Celestines are Luna, the 
spirit of the Moon, and Helios, the spirit of the Sun. Gaia’s 
most directly comprehensible manifestation is a Celestine 
form. The true form of Gaia is so much larger than the Triat 
as to be completely unknowable by any means other than 
the transcendent bliss of mystical union. Other Celestines 
are powerful servitors of the Triat, but their forms are all but 
unknown to the Garou. They are sentient and highly 
intelligent. Most Celestines abide in Realms of their own 
design; here they are omnipotent and omniscient. They are 
usually visited only by Incarna. 


Chapter Seven: The Spirit World 


A 


NL 


5A 93 


Celestines sometimes send avatars to communicate with 
Garou. These avatars are aspects of themselves that are 
approachable and understandable by Garou. The true form 
ofa Celestine is unimaginable; it is only through an avatar 
that communication between them and lesser beings can 
take place. 

Tocreate an avatar, the Celestine wills itself to appear in 
a finite, limited form. Because of its near-infinite nature, a 
Celestine may have many avatars active at one time. 
Celestine avatars cannot be destroyed or adversely affected 
in any way by beings of lesser potency than Celestines. 


Jncarna 


One step below the Celestines are the Incarna. Incarna 
are minions, consorts, advisors and warriors who serve the 
Celestines and derive power from their patrons. Some of 
them have Domains of their own, but most of the Domains 
they inhabit were created by Celestines. When Celestines 
die, their Incarna often survive. These powerful spirits seek 
both Gnosis and a purpose. Many of them seek to become 
Celestines. 

Totem spirits are the Incarna most familiar to Garou. 
These beings, most often servants of Gaia, can create many 
avatars to communicate and interact with the Garou. Pack 
totems are totem avatars. (See Totem, pp. 259-264). Totem 
avatars resemble Jagglings (see below) in form and powers. 

While Incarna are less powerful than Celestines, they 
are still immensely potent and vast, existing on many 


179 


levels. Usually, only their avatars can be interacted with, 
although Theurges tell legends of great seers who encoun- 
tered Incarna in the Umbra and came away with a truer 
understanding of power. 


Jagglings 

Jagglingsaresimplerspirits that serve the Incarna, though 
some Jagglings serve a Celestine directly. They are formed 
from a part of the spiritual essence of their patron, and are 
usually quite loyal. Some develop (or are given) free will by 
their patron. The more advanced Jagglings can duplicate 
this process and thereby create Gafflings to serve them- 
selves. Garou can, and often do, interact with Jagglings. 
Some Jagglings teach Gifts to Garou, while others, such as 
Englings, can provide an entire sept with Gnosis. 


Gafflings 


The lowest spirits are Gafflings — semi-sentient or 
insentient servants of the Jagglings. They are used as tools 
by their masters and by the Incarna, who don't regard them 
as intelligent beings. Gafflings are used to power Garou 
fetishes and to send messages through the Umbra. They are 
in constant communication with their patron and often 
allow their patron to assume complete control over them. 
Many of them feel most "whole" when they allow their 
patron to dominate them. Some Gafflings are fully intelli- 
gent, but these are the exceptions, and are often the work 
of mysterious higher forces. Garou interact with Gafflings 
more than any other spirit type. Gafflings can teach Gifts 
to Garou and be bound into fetishes. 


Spirit Traits 


Spirits differ from physical beings in many ways. They do 
notshare the same Traits; spirits do not have Attributes and 
Abilities. Instead, spirits have the following Traits: Will- 
power, Rage, Gnosis, Power, and Charms. How they use 
these Traits is detailed below. 


Willpower 
Willpower allows a spirit to take “physical” actions: 
attacking an enemy, racing after another spirit, or even 
flying through the Umbra. Contests of this nature between 
spirits are resolved by opposed Willpower rolls. 
Difficulty Action 
easy action 
fairly simple action 
normal action 
difficult action 
virtually impossible action 


| 


————— r— € 


un SAL 


Rage 

Rage is a spirit's anger and anguish. Spirits can destroy 
and harm other spirits or Garou with their Rage. For each 
success on a Rage roll, one Health Level of damage is 


inflicted, orone point of Power is lost if the target is a spirit. 
(See Combat in the Umbra, pp. 238-239.) 


Gnosis 


Gnosis is what a spirit uses for any sort of Social or 
Mental roll, or any roll to transform the parameters of a 
situation. For instance, a riddle contest with a spirit could 
be resolved using the questioner's Wits * Enigmas resisted 
by the spirit's Gnosis; whoever scores the most successes 
wins. Likewise, a spirit would roll its Gnosis when trying to 
intimidate, scare or fool a target. 


Difficulty Action 


3 huge target 

5 sitting target 

6 normal target 

8 moving target 

10 tiny target 
Power 


Unlike Garou, spirits rarely use their own Gnosis in 
attacks; instead, they use “batteries” of mystical energy, 
which they harness from the Umbra to sustain themselves. 
A spirit's "battery" is known as its Power, and it is depleted 
through the use of special abilities and through taking 
damage. When a spirit's Power reaches zero, the spirit 
dissipates into the Umbra for a number of hours equal to 20 
minus its Gnosis, after which it Reforms with one Power 
point. Optionally, a Garou who knows the proper rite can 
bind the spirit into a fetish; however, the fetish will not be 
usable until the spirit's Power is recharged (see Recharging 
Power, below). A Garou who reduces aspirit’s Power to zero 
may also elect to siphon up to five points of Gnosis from the 
spirit in order to recharge his own Gnosis. This kills the 
spirit if it has fewer than six Gnosis points. Needless to say, 
this is a good way to make lots of spirits very angry. 


Charms 


Each spirit possesses special powers, known as Charms. 
Charms generally require a certain amount of Power to 
employ. Unless otherwise stated, a Charm lasts for one 
scene. Combat-oriented Charms, however, last one turn 
per use. 


Charms 


Common Charms 


* Airt Sense: Most spirits have a natural sense of the airts 
(directions) of the spirit world and are able to travel about without 
much difficulty. It costs one Power to find any particular thing. 

* Armor: This Charm providesa spirit one soak die per Power 
pointspent. Thisistheonly way aspiritcansoak damage. Thespirit 
mayusethis Charm atany time in the combat turn before damage 
is rolled. (See Combat in the Umbra, pp. 238-239.) 

*Healing: Thisallowsa spirit to heal physical beings (such 
as Garou). The spirit spends one Power point per Health 
Level, or three per Health Level if the damage is aggravated. 

* Materialize: A spirit with this Charm may materialize 
and affect the physical world. To do so, the spirit's Gnosis 
must equal or exceed the Gauntlet for that area. When a 
spirit Materializes, it must spend Power to create a physical 
shape and give itself bodily Traits. However, a spirit still 
rolls its Gnosis for Social or Mental activities. The Power 
point costs are as follows: 

Power Cost Trait 
Per one Physical Attribute level 
Per two Ability levels 
7 Health Levels (as a mortal) 


Per additional Health Level (each extra 
Health Level also increases size) 

1 Per one Health Level healed (regenerate 
damage to the physical form) 

1 Weaponry: Per die ofaggravated damage 
done in addition to Strength (Bite is one 
die, Claws are two, etc.) 

Spirits have no limits on their Attribute and Ability 
levels; itis possible for them to form extremely strong or fast 
bodies if they spend enough Power. 

For example: a Bane spirit wants to Materialize into the 
physical world, the better to terrorize mortals. It wants the 
following characteristics: Str 3, Dex 4, Sta 3, Brawl 4, 
Dodge 3, Stealth 3, and seven Health Levels. This costs it 
16 Power points. 

A spirit may stay Materialized as long as it desires, but it 
cannot enter an area with a higher Gauntlet than its 
Gnosis. While Materialized, the spirit may not recharge its 
Power unless it has a Charm that allows it to do so. When 
a Materialized spirit is attacked, damage is applied to its 
Health Levels. If a spirit is reduced to zero Health Levels, it 
dissipates into the Umbra and may not reuse this Charm for 
(20 hours minus its Gnosis). 

Note that aggravated damage suffered by a spirit is 
applied to Health Levels and Power. Thus, a spirit cannot 
always escape its sojourn on Earth unscathed. 

* Reform: This Charm allows a spirit to dissipate and 
Reform somewhere else in the Umbra, usually faraway from 
its enemies; this costs 20 Power. 


182 


Specialty Charms 


* Blast Flame: The spirit can blast a gout of flame at 
opponents. The Power cost is two per die of damage. 

* Break Reality: The spirit can disrupt the reality of a 
substance, and thereby modify its Umbral form, by making 
a Gnosis roll. For example, the spirit could, with a success- 
ful enough roll, create a door in a wall, enabling the spirit 
to pass through. The difficulty is determined by the extent 
of the attempted change and how interesting, sensible and 
clever the action is. The number of successes obtained 
determines how much change is actually accomplished. A. 
botch on this rolls is extremely harmful and causes the spirit 
to lose a Gnosis point. The Power cost ranges from two to 
10 points (again, depending on the extent of the change). 

* Calcify: This Charm is possessed only by Weaver spirits. 
It allows the spirit to bind a target into the Pattern Web. A 
Willpower roll is made against the target's Rage; each success 
subtracts one from the victim's Physical Attributes (or Will- 
power, in the case of spirits). When Attributes or Willpower 
is reduced to zero, the victim is bound fast into the Pattern 
Web until freed (rescuers must score a number of damage 
successes with attack or Rage rolls equal to the successes of the 
Weaver spirit). The Power cost is two. 

* Cleanse the Blight: This Charm is similar to the Rite 
of Cleansing. It purges spiritual corruption in the vicinity. 
Power cost is 10. 

* Control Electrical Systems: The spirit can exert 
control overan electrical system. The spirit rolls its Gnosis 
(difficulty from 3 to 9 depending on the system's complex- 
ity). Power cost is from one to five points. 


* Create Fires: By succeeding with a Gnosis roll, the 
spirit can create small fires. The difficulty varies (from 3 for 
small fires to 9 for conflagrations). The Power cost varies 
from one to five points. 

* Create Wind: The spirit can create wind effects. Power 
cost varies — from one for a breeze to 20 for a tornado. 

* Disorient: Possessed only by Wyldings (usually Vorti- 
ces). Thespirit may completely alter landmarks and directions 
with a successful Gnosis roll (difficulty 6 or the Gauntlet 
rating, whichever is higher). The Power cost is two. 

* Flood: The spirit can cause all the waters in a given 
area to rise rapidly, causing flooding. The Power cost is five 
per one-mile radius. 

* Forest Sense: The spirit can sense all that transpires 
in its earthly, wooded domain. Power cost is 10. 

* Freeze: The spirit can drastically lower the temperature 
in the immediate area. The cost is three Power points for every 
10-yard radius, and three additional Power points per die of 
damage; anyone in the area suffers this damage. The first three 
points spent reduce the temperature in the area to freezing; 
each additional three-point increment reduces the tempera- 
ture by an additional 10 degrees Fahrenheit. 

* Frozen Breath: The spirit exhales a breath of bitter 
cold air. The cost is one Power point per die of damage.

* Ice Shards: The spirit can fling sharp shards of ice at a 
target. The cost is five Power points per three dice damage. 

* Lightning Bolts: The spirit can generate lightning 
bolts and target them at opponents. The Power cost is two 
per die of damage inflicted. 

* Open Moon Bridge: Creates a Moon Bridge to a 
desired location; there does not have to be a caern present. 
The total distance is 1000 miles. Power cost is five. 

* Shapeshift: The spirit may take the form of anything 
it desires. It does not gain the powers or abilities of its new 
shape, only the form and visage. The Power cost is five. 

+ Shatter Glass: The spirit can cause all glass in the vicinity 
to break (Gnosis; difficulty 6). The Power cost is three. 

* Short Out: The spirit can cause electrical systems to 
short out (Gnosis; difficulty 6). The Power cost is three. 

* Solidify Reality: This charm is possessed only by Weaver 
spirits. Itenables the Weaver spirit to spin the Pattern Web, thus 
reinforcing the laws and rules of the Weaver upon aspects of the 
Umbra. Thepowerrequiresonlya Willpowerroll. Thespiritcould, 
with a successful enough roll, make a spiritual wall so solid that it 
could not be bypassed. The difficulty is determined by the extent 
of the solidification and how interesting, sensible and clever the 
description of the action is. The number of successes obtained 
determines how much solidifying is allowed. Power cost ranges 
from one to 20, depending on the magnitude of the feat. 

Success makes the object or spirit more solid. An object's 
effective "Health Levels" are increased by one per success. 
The effect lasts for about a day. Each spirit can make only 
one roll for each object. 

* Spirit Static: This charm is possessed only by Weaver 
spirits. The spirit may raise the Gauntlet in a given area by 
one. The Power cost is 10. 

* Throw Glass: The spirit can direct shards of glass at 
intruders. Three dice of damage can be inflicted. The 
Power cost is five. 

* Tracking: The spirit can unerringly track its prey. 
Power cost is five. 

* Umbraquake: The Garou can cause the Umbra to 
shake with such force that all those standing are thrown to 
the ground. Everyone within the radius suffers damage from 
the spiritual concussion. The cost is five Power per 10-foot 
radius, and two Power per die of aggravated damage. 

* Updraft: The spirit can lift a human-sized creature 
into the air. Power cost is three. 


Gane Charms 


+ Blighted Touch: The spirit can deliver the Blight onto 
a target. If the spirit successfully attacks, the target must 
immediately make a Willpower roll. If she fails, her nega- 
tive characteristics dominate her personality for the next 
few hours. A botch on the Willpower roll causes this Blight 
of personality to become permanent. The Power cost is two. 

* Corruption: The spirit can whisper an evil suggestion 
in a target's ear; the target is inclined to act upon that 
thought. The Power cost is one. 


Chapter Seven: The Spirit World 


* Incite Frenzy: The spirit can cause a Garou to enter 
frenzy. Roll the spirit's Rage (difficulty of the target's 
Willpower). The Power cost is three. 

* Possession: The spirit (usually a Bane) may possess a 
living being or inanimate object. Possession requires a 
successful Gnosis roll (difficulty ofthe victim's Willpower). 
The number of successes equals the speed with which 
possession occurs; refer to the chart below: 


Successes Time Taken 
1 six hours 
2 three hours 
3 one hour 
4 15 minutes 
5 five minutes 
6+ instantaneous 


During the time it takes to possess its victim, the spirit will 
find a dark, isolated part of the Umbra (usually a Blight) and 
remain there, concentrating on the possession. During this 
time a spirit can take no other action. If it engages in spirit 
combat, the possessive link is broken. Possessing spirits are 
often guarded by others of their kind, to ensure that the 
possession process remains undisturbed. 

A spirit that has possessed a victim is able to manifest certain 
characteristicsandabilities through the vessel of the victim'sbody. 
Such hapless humans are known as fomori (see the Appendix).

Recharging Power 

When a spirit is low on Power, it begins to look translu- 
cent, as if it is not fully there. If the spirit has lost its Power 
because of combat damage, it will look ragged, with jagged 
slashes riddling it. 

Spirits can replenish their Power by entering a com- 
pletely inactive state called Slumber. During this time the 
spirit finds a secluded spot in the Umbra and floats there, 
entering a deep sleep. For each hour that the spirit does 
nothing whatsoever, it regains one Power point. Many 
Theurges argue about whether or not spirits dream during 
this time. 

When a spirit is in Slumber, it may easily be bound 
through the use ofa rite, regardless of its current Power level 
or willingness. When a spirit is bound into a fetish, it 
automatically enters Slumber and stays in that state until 
released; the fetish's powers are activated by the user, not 
the spirit. A newly created fetish will not work until the 
spirit has regained its full Power (which can take along time 
for the more powerful spirits). 


Movement 


All spirits can fly (and float) in the Umbra. The maxi- 
mum distance (in yards) they can move in a turn is 20 + 
Willpower. 

The Umbra does not always have a strict geographical 
equivalent to the physical world; sometimes yards and feet 


184 


just don't add up in the spirit world. The Storyteller is free 
to warp distances as she pleases when running stories in the 
Umbra. However, the Penumbra (the zone directly sur- 
roundingphysical reality) does maintain distances analogous 
to the physical world (one yard always equals one yard). 


Communication 


Spirits speak a different tongue from physical beings. 
Spirit communication is not so much a language as a form 
oftelepathy, a comprehension by both parties of the other's 
voiced intent. Not everyone can understand spirits; the 
Gift: Spirit Speech is required to speak with and understand 
spirits. 

Spirits allied to the Garou (such as Falcon's Jagglings or 
Gafflings) may speak the tongue of the Garou if they 
choose. Likewise, many other spirits also know human or 
Garou tongues. Unless these spirits choose to speak so to a 
Garou, she must have the proper Gift to speak to them. 
Gifts that allow control over or interaction with spirits do 
not require the user to understand spirit speech or that the 
spirits understand the user. For example, the Gift: Com- 
mand Spirit works magically, regardless of what the 
commander actually says. 


Fetishes 


A fetish is an object containing the essence of a spirit. 
The spirit is bound into an object and can subsequently be 


Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


called upon to perform tasks for the wielder of the fetish. 
What special tasks a fetish can perform depend on the type 
of spirit bound into it. 

A fetish is almost always a natural object made from 
wood, clay, etc. (although the fetishes of the Glass Walkers 
are often made from technological objects), and can often 
be held in the hand. Many fetishes are adorned with 
feathers, beads, braids and carvings depicting the spirit 
contained within. Some are actually weapons, such as 
spears and knives. 

Fetish powers are legion, for there are countless spirits 
within the Tellurian. All fetishes are sacred to the Garou, 
containing as they do the essences of spirits. Thus, fetishes 
are held in high regard and treated with respect. Agents of 
the Wyrm constantly seek to steal or destroy these fetishes, 
and they have some particularly vile items of their own as 
well. 

A fetish is created through the Rite of the Fetish (see 
Rites, pg. 146). Such creation almost always involves a 
willing spirit. However, certain mystics bind spirits into 
fetishes permanently, against the will of the spirit. These 
fetishes are almost always rebellious and are viewed by the 
Garou as “cursed.” 

To use a fetish, a character must first attune herself to it 
by making a Gnosis roll. Attunement effectively binds the 
fetish to the wielder, for it creates a spiritual bond enabling 
the wielder to take the fetish anywhere in the Tellurian and 
providing empathic knowledge of the fetish's powers. The 
difficulty for this roll is the fetish’s Gnosis rating; so long as 
a single success is scored, the wielder may use the fetish. If 
no successes are rolled, that character may not use that 
fetish, or even attempt to attune it again, until she has 
somehow made accord with the resident spirit. How this is 
done is up to the Storyteller. 

Each time the wielder wishes to use one of her fetish's 
powers, she must make a Gnosis roll (difficulty of the 
fetish's Gnosis rating) to "activate" the power. Alterna- 
tively, she may just spend a Gnosis point to activate the 
power automatically. 


Chapter Seven: The Spirit World 


In order for a Garou to create a specific kind of fetish or 
talen, he must first procure a spirit affiliated with the item's 
intent. For example, a spirit of Healing would not enter a 
fetish like a Fang Dagger or a talen like a Bane Arrow. A 
spirit of War, Pain or Death might. Fetish spirits are almost 
always Gafflings. 

A list of sample fetishes can be found in the Appendix 
(pp. 273-275). 


Talens 


Talens are far easier to create than fetishes; some are 
fashioned by non-Theurges. Talens are similar to fetishes in 
many ways — they are bound into objects, require a Gnosis 
roll to activate (but not to attune), and contain the living 
essence of a spirit. The real difference between talens and 
fetishes is that talens may be used only once. After one use, 
the talen's spirit is released into the Umbra, and the object 
becomes mundane once again. Unlike fetishes, which are 
usable only by those who are attuned to them, talens may 
be used by anyone (including non-Garou). The Rite of 
Binding is used to create a talen (see Rites, pg. 144). Garou 
with this rite may force spirits into objects through success- 
ful use of spirit combat, wherein the spirit is bound rather 
than destroyed. Most talens come into being this way. It is 
not considered immoral to force a spirit into a talen, 
because the use is only temporary. 


A talen receives Gnosis equal to the bound spirit's 
Gnosis. One extra talen of the same type can be made for 
each success received on the Rite of Binding roll. For 
example, three successes allow the creation of four Bane 
Arrows. Talens are almost always created with Gafflings, 
but more powerful spirits can make the creation of multiple 
talens easier. Use of these spirits adds an automatic two or 
three extra talens to the total number. There is no binding 
time limit, but the talen may be used only once. 

A listofsample talens can be found in the Appendix (pp. 
215-216). 


185 


| 


This chapter discusses the different ways a character can 
change during the course of the chronicle. It describes 
many different systems for resolving changes to characters, 
whether the change in question is the accumulation of 
experience or the accumulation of wounds. 

This chapter is subdivided into three sections, each of 
which discusses a number of different systems for imple- 
menting character changes. Character Development 
describes how Traits can increase (and decrease) and also 
includes Renown. Physical States includes systems for 
injuries and recovery from injuries. Mental States includes 
systems for frenzy and the Delirium. 

Oneofthe most exciting things about playing characters 
is seeing them change over time. Watching a character 
develop and grow is like watching a child grow up before 
your eyes. In Werewolf, however, development doesn't 
always mean the character gets better. It often means the 
character slowly and steadily sinks into the abyss. Such is 
the nature of this game. Focus on getting better and surviv- 
ing the rough periods, and try to appreciate the artistic 
impact of losing your humanity or your mind. 

This is a chapter of permutations, not rules. There is 
nothing contained in the next several pages that you need to 
know, but a few things about which you might want to 
know more. Only use the systems that make sense to you; 
ignore all the rest. 


Chapter Eight: Systems 


yrm€——má————À 


Character (Development 


This section discusses the ways a character can increase 
(or decrease) in power and abilities or in the esteem of 
Garou society (Renown). 


Experience Points 


We humans are learning machines, and we learn con- 
stantly — almost despite ourselves. By acquiring not only 
facts and figures, but new ways of being, we can make 
ourselves into what we want to be. Change occurs in 
werewolves as well. 

During a story, characters learn many things. Much of 
what they learn is not the type of thing that can be recorded 
on character sheets, but rather something the players sim- 
ply keep in mind. They may have learned never to leave a 
car door unlocked or never to walk into a dark alley with a 
light behind them. Sometimes, however, what they learn 
can be recorded. 

At the end of each story, the Storyteller awards experi- 
ence points to each character, normally giving the same 
amount to each one. The players then simply record how 
many experience points they gained. Experience points 
can be used to increase Traits. The cost for raising Traits 
varies widely; see the chart below for specifics. The cost is 


187 


La. 


almost always based on the present rating times a certain 
number (yes, you have to do multiplication). Thus, if the 
character has an Alertness rating of 2 and the player wants 
to raise it to 3, it costs four experience points to do so. If the 
character does not have the Trait at all, the cost is listed as 
a"new" Ability. A Trait can only be raised one dot per story 
— never more.

Roleplay Jt 


As the Storyteller, you should not let a player spend her 
experience points to raise any Trait she wishes— it'sa little 
more involved than that. The increased Trait must be 
somethingthe character had a chance to learn or use during 
the st achieved great success 
through use of the Trait, or made a big mistake from which 
she can learn. In the case of Willpower, something must 
have actually occurred to bolster the character's self-confi- 
dence. 

You should only allow Trait increases if they have been 
or can be woven into the story. At the very least, the 
changes need to make sense in terms of the story and not 
simply be changes the player makes because she wants her 
character to be a certain way. This experience system can 
beas realistic as you make it. The more you force the players 
to make sense of their experiences, the more it will add to 
character development as a whole. 


Awarding Experience Points 


Assigning experience points requires a careful balance 
between rewarding the players and maintaining game bal- 
ance. If you follow the guidelines below, you probably 
won't get into too much trouble, but feel free to experiment 
as you see fit. 


End of Each Chapter 


Give each character one to five experience pointsat the 
end of each chapter (game session). One point is given 
whether or not the pack succeeds or fails, as a function of 
simply participating (remember, sometimes we learn de- 
spite ourselves). 


* One point — Automatic: Each player gets one point 
after every game session. 

* One point — Learning Curve: The character learned 
something from his experiences during the chapter. Ask 
the player to describe what his character learned before you 
award the point. 

* One point — Acting: The player roleplayed well — 
not only entertainingly but appropriately. Award for ex- 
ceptional roleplaying only; your standards should get 
increasingly higher. In most cases, only award this to the 
person who did the best roleplaying in the troupe. 

* One point — Concept: The player acted out her 
character's concept very well. 

* One point — Heroism: When a character risks herself 
for others, such as when she suffers multiple aggravated 
wounds fighting the Bane while the rest of the pack escapes, 
give her an experience point. Don’t let characters take 
advantage of this; there is a fine line between heroism and 
stupidity. 


End of Each Story 


At the end of each story, you can assign each player one 
to three additional experience points over and above the 
one to five points earned for completing the chapter. 

* One point — Success: The pack succeeded in its 
mission or goal. Perhaps it was not a complete success, but 
at least a marginal victory was achieved. 

* One point — Danger: The character experienced 
great danger during the story and survived. 

* One point — Wisdom: The player (and thus the 
character) exhibited great wits or resourcefulness, or came 
up with an idea that enabled the pack to succeed. 

If you want to award even more points, thus allowing the 
characters to develop even more quickly, simply invent 
new categories in which to award experience. These can 
even vary from story to story, and can be based on the 
specific circumstances of that story. 


Spending Experience Points 


The costs for raising the Traits listed below are listed on 
the Experience Chart. 


Backgrounds 


Background Traits never change through the use of expe- 
rience points (except for Totem; see below). Changes to 
Background Traits happen during the normal course ofevents 
in the chronicle. For example, a character loses big on Wall 
Street, depleting his assets. His Resources Trait decreases in 
this case. Likewise, he may win big in Vegas, raising his 
Resources. Eventually, the Storyteller will note the changes, 
and the character's Traits will increase (or decrease) appropri- 
ately. A player may wish to ask the Storyteller if one of her 
Background Traits should be changed, but this should not be 
done too often. 


Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


— ————À 


TheStoryteller may design a list of things characters must 
accomplish in order to increase each Background Trait, and 
the players may or may not be shown the list. To gain a new 
Contact, for example, a Garou has to find the right subject and 
befriend him. 

For the most part, Background-raising decisions take place 
over the course of a story. Backgrounds generally increase one 
dot at a time, but major victories or upsets in a story can lead 
to the gain or loss of more than one Background dot at a time. 

The one exception to these rules is the Totem Background; 
itcan be raised through experience points, though roleplaying 
is encouraged as a requirement before experience can be spent. 
Just as every member of a pack can share in the Background 
Cost ofthe Totem, every membercan likewise choose tospend 
her experience on the Totem. 


Gaining Rage 

Characters can buy permanent Rage with experience points. 
Although this raises a character's rating, allowing him more 
potential Rage points to spend, it also raises his chance of 
frenzy, for Rage is the Trait rolled when checking for frenzy. 


Gaining Gnosis 


Characters can buy permanent Gnosis with experience 
points. This improves their ability to step sideways and 
allows them more potential Gnosis points. 


Gaining Willpower 

Characters can buy permanent Willpower with experience 
points; sometimes the Storyteller may give a player a specific 
chance to raise his Willpower. The opportunity to gain 
Willpower isa great motivation for stories, especially the more 
bizarre ones. 

Characters can lose permanent Willpower as well. This 
occurs whenever a player botches a Willpower roll. Luckily, 
this does not occur often, for Willpower is rarely rolled. Gifts 
are exceptions to this rule; a character cannot lose Willpower 
when a Gift requires a Willpower roll to activate. 


Awarding Renown 


Besides experience points, characters will also accumulate 
Renown, both temporary and permanent. Renown is very 
important to Garou. Without it, they are unable to move 
upward in their society; indeed, they will find it difficult to 
establish a place within it. Renown is gained simply through 
the normal course of events, for it reflects others' attitudes 
about a character. However, Renown can actively be sought 
as well. Garou sometimes seek out circumstances and events 
that lead to increased Renown. 

The Storyteller awards Renown in one of three specific 
categories: Glory, Honor or Wisdom. The character must 
accept the award in the category it is given. Glory awards 
cannot be changed to Wisdom simply because the player feels 
he needs more Wisdom to reach the next Rank; Renown is 


Chapter Eight: Systems 


p/m. am, um s A no ——————— // 


awarded based on his actions. If he slew a Wyrm beast, he gains 
Glory. If he upheld the Litany against violations, he gains 
Honor. If he outsmarted a spirit, he gains Wisdom. Thus, 
characters must make sure that they roleplay within their 
character concepts if they want to rise in Rank quickly; 
Ahroun will always strive for Glory over Wisdom, while 
Theurgesare much moreconcerned with Wisdom than Honor. 

Whenever two characters work together to accomplish a 
feat, they share the Renown. If two werewolves cooperate to 
destroy a Bane, each receives Glory for the act. 


Rewarding Renown 


Renown is awarded at the end ofa game session, or, optionally, 
at the end of astory, when the characters are at a moot and can be 
recognized for their actions. Another option, for Storytellers 
comfortable with the rest of the Storyteller System, is to hand out 
temporary Renown awards or punishments during play. In this 
way, aplayercan mark a Renownawardonhissheet when he gains 
it. It is easier on bookkeeping, but the Storyteller must be facile 
enough with the system to award Renown without stopping the 
game to look up a proper reward. 


Gaining Temporary Renown 


Temporary Renown is gained only through roleplaying. 
Temporary Renown is represented by marking the squares 
below each Renown rating, one square for each point 
gained (see the character sheet). It can (and usually does) 
grow larger than the permanent Pool. This is an easy way for 
Storytellers to reward players who roleplay their characters’ 
auspices, breeds, and tribes well. Temporary Renown has 
no game effect except to indicate when a permanent score 
may increase. 

When a character has acquired 10 temporary Renown in 
a category, he may attempt to gain a point of permanent 
Renown (see below). If he succeeds, he gains the perma- 
nent point and loses all his temporary points, starting over 
with zero. When he once again gains 10 temporary points, 
he can try again to gain a permanent point. In this manner, 
characters eventually rise in Rank. 

Refer to the Renown Awards Chart for sample Glory, 
Honor and Wisdom awards. This list is in no way exhaus- 
tive and should be used as a guideline; circumstances can 
greatly change the rewards. Storytellers should not worry 
about memorizing this list or awarding Renown every time 
a character performs some activity from the list; these are 
recommendations only. 


Gaining Permanent Renown 


In order for a character to gain one dot in a particular 
permanent Renown rating, she must first accumulate 10 
points of temporary Renown in that category. She must then 
convince another Garou of equal or higher Rank to perform 
aRite of Accomplishment for her (see Rite of Accomplishment, 
pp. 148-149). This Garoucannotbeamemberofthe character's 
pack.

Another option is to challenge an elder. This can only be

to those who cannot convince another to perform the Rite of

The Storyteller can simply decide to award the character 
the extra dot of permanent Renown without the Rite of 
Accomplishment. This should only be done in the most 
extreme circumstances, such as when a character performs a 
particularly valiant or wise deed — one that is unquestionably 
worthy of reward. 


Losing Renown 


Losing Temporary Renown 


Itisespecially easy foraGaroutolose temporary Renown. Inthis 
way may the Storyteller simulate the “pack mentality” of the 
Garouand cause players to realize that their actions have repercus- 
sions in Garou society. 


193 


Storytellers should consider the character's breed, auspice and 
tribe when deducting temporary Renown from a character. 
Ragabash can get away with more extreme trespasses against 


Honor than can most characters, for they are expected to behave 

badly in this respect. Likewise, however, it should be harder for 

them to gain Honor, for even if they perform an honorable act, I 
others will suspect ulterior motives. 

Losing Permanent Renown 

A much more serious penalty occurs when a Garou loses 
permanent Renown. This happens only when a character 
heinously violates some basic dictum of Garou society. For 
example, a Garou frenzies and eats his human prey alive. This is 
a horrible breach of the Litany, but even this may be forgiven 
depending on the circumstances of the frenzy (the presence of 
a Nexus Crawler at the time may cause the elders to excuse the 
incidentas an “unavoidable circumstance of our war against the 
Wyrm”). Nonetheless, the Garou will lose temporary Honor 
Renown. However, should the Garou acquire a taste for human 
flesh and subsequently be caught with anew snack, he will surely 
lose permanent Honor Renown. 

To maintain one’s Renown in the face of extreme societal 
censure, thecharacter must undergoa test of some sortorotherwise 
prove to the elders that the loss of face was undeserved. The 
Storyteller should devise a story in which the character undergoes 
an ordeal to reacquire her lost Renown. He then decides whether 
ornot the character has "learned her lesson” and rules whether or 
not the character has "passed the test.” His decision in this is final. 

Ifa character receives a permanent Renown loss that drops her 
permanent score below that required for the Rank she currently 
holds, she loses all benefits and privileges of that Rank, although 
she does retain any Gifts she leamed at that Rank. | 


Advancing in Rank 


To gain Rank one needs: 
* Renown: A character needs to have attained the number of 


> permanent Renown points listed next to the Rank (see Renoun 
- (fl [ 4 Chart) even to be considered for that Rank. The primary category 
N 4 TIBIAE \ | AUS of Renown vades by auspice. 
AWRY * Challenge: A Garou's Renown is what qualifies her for higher 
Yi Rank, but advancement is not an automatic process. Just because a 
Philodox Garou has achieved Glory 1, Honor 5 and Wisdom 1 
doesn't mean that she automatically progresses to Rank Two. The 
assistance of another Garou who is already of the Rank you wish to 
attain (orhigher) isessential. You mustfirst challenge and then best 
this elder in a contest of some sort. Though you issue the challenge, 
theeldergetstochoose the type ofcontestandcan make itasdifficult 
oras easy as she pleases. If you win the contest, she is honor-bound 
to accept you and recognize you as a Garou of that Rank. There are 
different standard contests for each Rank, but the eldercan make up 
anything she desires. The challenge can even be one of the 
dominance contests: facedown, gamecraft or combat challenge. 
You can challenge a single elder only once. An elder will 
not accept pupils whom she has already beaten (at least not at 
this same Rank). 


Example of Gaining Renown 
and Rank 


Winter’s Heart is a Garou Ahroun of Rank Two. He 
currently has 6 Glory, 4 Honor and 1 Wisdom. If he gains one 
more temporary point in both Glory and Honor, he may 
challenge an elder to attain Rank Three.

Honor 


Chapter Eight: Systems 


Winter’s Heart, upon gaining 10 temporary Glory points, 
wishes to be recognized for them. He asks an elder to perform 
a Rite of Accomplishment for him. Because Winter’s Heart 
hasprovedhimselfa valiant warriorand islikedbyall, theelder 
agrees. At the next moot, the rite is performed. Winter's Heart 
gains a permanent Glory point, giving him a total Glory of 7. 
He loses all his temporary Glory and must collect 10 more 
before he can again try to gain a permanent Glory point. 

Throughout the next few months, Winter's Heart collects 
10 temporary Honor points and wishes to gain a permanent 
point. He again asks for the Rite of Accomplishment. The 
elders readily agree, and at the end of the next moot, Winter's 
Heart has 5 Honor. 

He can now challenge for Rank Three. He seeks out an old 
elder who he believes likes him, and challenges the old wolf to 
recognize him. The old one smiles — he has seen many young 
ones come before him like this throughout his years — and 
nods. "But first," the elder says, "you must prove your worth. It 
is my right to choose the task, and I choose it so: a riddle." The 
elder has chosen to challenge the young Garou with a bout of 
gamecraft. The Storyteller can either devise an actual riddle 
and challenge the player to guess it, or he can use the gamecraft 
tules given on pg. 223. 

Winter's Heart, surprised by this tactic, is worried. He is a 
warrior, not one to unravel enigmas. The elder is trying to 
teach hima lesson by challenging him with such a test — even 
Ahroun need wisdom. Luckily, Winter's Heart answers the 
riddle successfully. The elder nods, smiling at the Garou, and 
says, "Then goforward, Winter's Heart, and know that youare 
recognized by your People and are now a Garou of high rank.” 

s into the air, whooping with joy. He 
has done it— he is now Rank Three! He rushes off to the sept’s 
ritemaster, hoping to learn a new Gift. 


Renunciation 


A Garou who wishes to renounce her current position and 
take a different auspice may do so. However, she must first 
adopt a new name and lose all but three of her permanent 
Renown points. She then performs (or has another perform) 
the Rite of Renunciation (see pg. 140). 

Afterward, the Garou starts over as a new werewolf, with 
new possibilities and a new auspice. She still possesses any 
Gifts previously learned, but she may not learn new Gifts 
except those available to her new Rank, nor may she ever 
again learn Gifts of her old auspice. Some elders might require 
her to undergo a Rite of Passage, usually one much more 
difficult than her original. At the end of this rite, she may ask 
a spirit to teach her one Level One Gift of her new auspice. 

It is considered disrespectful for others who once knew the 
Garou to speak to her with familiarity (except for her 
packmates). Only when a Garou once again attains her 
previous Rank may she reestablish old friendships and the like. 

Renunciation is performed for a variety of reasons: 

* Sometimes criminals are offered the option of renuncia- 
tion or exile. 


+ Self-loathing can sometimes be so intense that the char- 
acter finds renunciation to be the only solution other than 
suicide. 


* Lack of a sense of purpose and meaning can also lead one 
to such a fundamental step. 

* [n the ballads, it is lost love that always drives someone 
into renunciation. 

+ Sometimesa Garou will dedicate himselfto a purpose and 
renounce his name in order to focus upon his purpose more 
intently. This tradition has long been honored by the Garou. 
A renunciate who manages to accomplish his task usually 
regains his old Rank and perhaps even a Rank above this 
(Storyteller's discretion). 


Physical States 


This section discusses the parameters of health. Injuries 
and healing are discussed, and aging is mentioned. 


Jnjury 

Wounds are all I'm made of. 

— Blue Oyster Cult, “Veteran of the Psychic Wars" 

There are as many different ways a character can sustain an 
injury as there are injuries, but in Werewolf injuries are 
described in one way: the Health Trait. A player records 
injuries in terms of Health Levels; each wound causes the loss 
of one Health Level. Simply check off Health Levels as the 
character loses them, so the last box checked delineates the 
character's current Health Level. 


196 


Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


pamm am, mrt m R, -———— // 


Think of Health asa spectrum with Bruised at one end and 
Incapacitated atthe other. Asa charactersuffers more wounds, 
hetravels down the spectrum until he finally reaches Incapaci- 
tated. When he heals, he simply removes these checks one by 
one, until he is again in perfect health. 

Each success on an opponent's damage roll indicates a loss 
of one Health Level. Thus, if a foe scored two damage 
successes, the player would check off two Health Levels, 
starting with Bruised and going down to Hurt. If a werewolf 
suffers damage beyond the Incapacitated Health Level, she is 
critically wounded (though not dead) and is out of action for 
at leastan hour. A critically wounded werewolf does not regain 
a Health Level each turn, but only one per hour until she 
surpasses Incapacitated. Furthermore, she must make a roll on 
the Battle Scars Chart (pg. 199). 

However, a critically wounded werewolf may try tochannel 
her Rage and remain active. The player can make a Rage roll 
(difficulty 8); the character heals one Health Level per success 
— even those lost to aggravated wounds. This may be tried 
only once, however, and if it fails, she does not recover. Even 
success has its penalties: the character runs the risk of frenzy 
(see Frenzy, pp. 200-201), and the player must still roll on the 
Battle Scars chart, adding one die to the roll. 


Healing 


Werewolves recover from wounds at a very rapid pace, 
healing one Health Level per turn unless the damage is 
aggravated (see below). There are two exceptions: homid and 
lupus Garou in their natural breed forms heal no faster than 
normal humans (wolves). Thus, ifa homid was in human form, 
or a lupus in wolf form, he would heal damage at the normal 
human rate (see Human Death, below). Metis do retain their 
regenerative abilities in their natural Crinos form. Thus, while 
they have many disadvantages, they do heal well in all forms. 

Normally, a Garou must not exert himself when healing, 
but he can attempt to heal while performing stressful actions, 
such as combat. Ifa character chooses to attempt this feat, the 
player must make a Stamina roll (difficulty 8). Success indi- 
cates that the character is able to heal himself while engaged 
in other activities. 


Aggravated Wounds 


Werewolves occasionally suffer wounds so severe they 
cannot regenerate them quickly. These injuries, known as 
aggravated wounds, are commonly inflicted by silver, fire, 
radiation, or the claws and teeth of other supernatural crea- 
tures. Aggravated wounds require time to heal. Garou can soak 
aggravated damage, except for silver (see Silver, pg. 198). 


Aggravated damage can only be healed at the rate of one 
Health Level per day of rest. Aggravated wounds should be 
indicated on the character sheet with an X rather than a 
check. The Storyteller can also deem any particularly severe 
injury (such as falling out of an airplane at 10,000 feet) to be 
an aggravated injury. 


^ 


Human (Death 


When a human or animal reaches Incapacitated, she is one 
Health Level away from death. If she is injured one more time, 
orifitisimpossible to stem the flow of blood from her body, she 
will die. 

Of course, humans heal differently than werewolves do. 
With proper medical attention, humans recover based on the 
following chart. Note that the time given is how long it takes 
torecover that particular Health Level —other Health Levels 
must be healed as well. Thus, ifthe human takes three months 
to recover from being Mauled, he must still take the time to 
heal Wounded, Injured and so one. 


Health Level Time 

Bruised One Day 

Hurt Three Days 
Injured One Week 
Wounded One Month 
Mauled Three Months 
Crippled Three Months * 


*Not only do humans have to heal this Health Level, but 
they lose one point from one of their Physical Attributes as 
well. Humans who reach Incapacitated heal at the 
Storyteller's discretion; some enter comas for the rest of 
their lives. 


Sources of Jnjury 


Despite the Garou's innate toughness, there are many 
ways to inflict harm upon a werewolf. Some are common to 
humans, and thus readily understandable to us, while 
others are specific to werewolves. These sources of injury 
are described below. 


Combat 


Combat wounds are dealt with at length in the Melee 
and Firefight sections of the Drama chapter. Each success 
on an opponent’s damage roll causes the character to lose 
one Health Level. 


Falling 


Occasionally, characters will fall. Use the chart below to 
calculate damage. Characters, human or werewolf, can make 
Stamina rolls (difficulty 8) to "soak" damage. Each success 
indicates one fewer Health Level is lost. Each botch means an 
additional Health Level is lost. 


Distance (in feet) Injury 

5 One Health Level 
10 Two Health Levels 
20 Three Health Levels 
30 Four Health Levels 
40 Five Health Levels 
50 Six Health Levels 
60 Seven Health Levels 


-..and so on, to a maximum of 10 Health Levels. 


Chapter Eight: Systems 


p/m. am, EN mar ET ER -————— 


Fire 

Fire is hazardous to werewolves. Fire always causes aggra- 
vated damage and therefore can potentially kill werewolves. 
Fire, however, holds a deep fascination for the Garou. Any 
size flame can potentially harm Garou, but they can resist 
the effects with Stamina. Have players roll Stamina — the 
difficulty depends on the severity and size of the flames. 
The player must roll each turn her character is in the flames 
to see if the character can resist the damage. If the roll fails, 
the character suffers from one to three Health Levels of 
damage (see the second chart below). If the roll succeeds, 
the character suffers one fewer Health Level of damage per 
success than she normally would. If the roll botches, then 
the character is harmed in some special way — perhaps she 
loses her eyesight or her limbs are maimed. 


Difficulty Heat of Fire 
3 Heat of a candle (first-degree burns) 
5 Heat of a torch (second-degree burns) 
7 Heatofa Bunsen Burner (third-degree burns) 
9 Heat of a chemical fire 
10 Molten metal 
Wounds Size of Fire 
One Torch; part of body burned 
Two Bonfire; half of body burned 
Three Raging Inferno; all of body burned 


Extreme Heat 


Extreme heat (200 degrees +) can injure werewolves in 
much the same way fire can. Use the same system for 
sustaining and taking damage, but modify it according to 
the situation. Normally, heat is not nearly as deadly as fire 
unless it is terrifically intense. 


(Disease 


Werewolves can catch and even transmit human and 
canine diseases, but generally do not die from them; their 
healing abilities and high Stamina ratings protect them. 
Lost Health Levels from disease are assumed to be normal 
wounds; once they are healed, the Garou is cured. 


Poison 


In general, poison acts much like disease — while it 
affects Garou, werewolves’ regenerative abilities enable 
them to heal from it as though the effects were normal 
wounds. Certain poisons of the Wyrm might cause aggra- 
vated damage. 


Suffocation and Drowning 


Werewolves can die by drowning. The length of time a 
Garou can hold his breath is determined by his Stamina 
rating, per the following chart:

One minute

Four minutes 
Eight minutes 
15 minutes 


M 0 Uno Qs tS 


20 minutes 
8 30 minutes 

Garou may expend Willpower to continue to hold their 
breath; each point expended allows them another 30 sec- 
onds if their Stamina is 3 or lower, or fora full minute if their 
Stamina is 4 or higher. 

When a Garou can no longer hold her breath, she begins 
to suffocate or drown as appropriate. A drowning character 
suffers one Health Level of damage per turn; this is not 
aggravated, but may not be healed until the Garou is out of 
the hostile environment. When the Garou reaches Inca- 
pacitated, she will die in one minute per point of Stamina. 


Radiation and Toxic Waste 


Certain of the Wyrm’s caerns are built on sites contain- 
ing various foul substances, and Garou often battle unethical 
corporations and the like in their role as Gaia's protectors. 
Garou exposed to radioactive substances and biochemical 
weapons take aggravated damage roughly equivalent to a 
fire of equal size; because of the cellular mutation and 
destruction induced by these substances, however, such 
wounds take twice the normal time to heal, and +10 is 
added to any roll on the Battle Scars Chart (pg. 199). This 
damage cannot be soaked. 


Silver 


Silver causes Garou one level of aggravated damage per 
turn of contact. A successful attack roll with a silver 
weapon inflicts at least one Health Level of damage no 
matter what the result of the damage roll is. Damage caused 
by silver cannot be soaked. 

Homid or lupus Garou do not take special damage from 
silver when in their natural breed forms, nor does any 
Garou when in Homid form; it is treated as a normal 
weapon against them. 

Each item of silver carried by a Garou reduces her effective 
Gnosis rating by one. This is not permanent, though the effect 
lasts for about a day after the silver has been discarded. In 
addition, for every five silver objects carried by the members 
ofa pack, each member of that pack suffers the loss of one point 
of Gnosis (effectively). For this reason, Garou sometimes 
resent those pack members who use klaives. Use the chart 
below to calculate the penalties for some objects. 

Object Gnosis Loss 

Silver bullets 1 point each 

Klaive 1 point 

Grand Klaive 2 points

Critical Wounds and Battle Scars 


When a character is wounded to below the Incapaci- 
tated Health Level, she is considered critically wounded. A 
normal human dies if he drops this far, but a werewolf only 
dies if all her wounds are aggravated. When critically 
wounded, the Garou is either unconscious or nearly so (she 
cannot act, but may speak for a short time by spending a 
Willpower point). 

She no longer heals at her normal rate, instead regener- 
ating only one Health Level per hour. Once she has 
regenerated sufficiently to rise above Incapacitated, how- 
ever, she can act again and begins to heal one Health Level 
per turn. At this point, she must roll on the Battle Scars 
Chart below. 

A critically wounded werewolf can attempt to channel 
her Rage to resuscitate her and activate her regenerative 
powers. This recovery attempt may be made only once. The 
player must make a Rage roll (difficulty 8). Each success 
heals one Health Level, even a Health Level inflicted by 
aggravated wounds. If she rises above Incapacitated this 
way, she is back in action. If she fails the roll, she does not 
recover. If successful, however, she must not only check for 
frenzy (see Frenzy, pp. 200-201), but must roll on the Battle 
Scars Chart, adding one extra die to the roll. 

A. battle scar is a permanent injury or disfigurement 
received through grievous wounding. Normally, one die is 
used to make the roll, but certain actions can change this, 
such as when making a Rage roll to recover from critical 
wounds (roll two dice). For particularly severe injuries, the 
Storyteller can add even more dice to the roll. Also, certain 
events can modify the roll, adding to the result. Radiation, 
biotoxins, etc. add +10 on the chart. 

Each time a character gains a battle scar, he receives one 
temporary Glory point. Garou respect those who have 
proved their courage in battle. If the scar is ever healed in 
any way, the character automatically loses two temporary 
Glory points.

Aging 

Garou, despite all their powers and regenerative abili- 
ties, are mortal; they age and die. While werewolves age 
moreslowly than humansor wolves do, age can nonetheless 
drain their powers. With old age (65+ for Garou) comes the 
possible loss of Physical Attributes. Senility is also a danger, 
reducing a character's Wits or Intelligence. An old Garou 
also finds it harder to Rage, and runs the risk of losing the 
wolf unless she chooses euthanasia before this time comes. 
The effects of age are up to the Storyteller to devise. Most 
Garoudie in battle, commit suicide or retire before time can 
appreciably erode their power. 


199 


Retirement 


Sometimes a character gets too old or weary to continue 
the pack life and the active fight against the Wyrm. These 
Garou, usually of high Rank, simply don’t have enough 
ambition to continue seeking more Renown. They return 
to their families and lives, whether they be among wolves 
or humans, and take part in tribal activities only during the 
yearly rituals and in time of need. This retirement is known 
among Garou as “The Homecoming” and is often marked 
by arite enacted by the Moon Dancers. Retiring Garou are 
usually old enough and of high enough Rank to contain the 
Rage in them, making it easier for them to live among 
humans or wolves (see The Curse, pg. 202). 


Mental States 


This section discusses the changes that can overcome a 
character’s psyche or the minds of those around him. Also 
discussed are problems Garou have when interacting with 
human or wolf society. 


Frenzy 


Violent, more violent, his hand cracks the chair 
Moves on reaction, and slumps in despair. 
— Joy Division, “I Remember Nothing” 
All Rage rolls should be considered attempts on the part 
of the Garou to “awaken the Beast.” Properly harnessed, 
this Beast enables the Garou to perform mighty deeds. 


Sometimes, however, too much of the Beast is awakened, 
and the character falls into a mad, berserk rage known as a 
frenzy. She becomes a creature of intense emotion, running 
on instinct alone with little cognitive control. Four or more 
successes on a Rage roll incite a frenzy. 

Frenzied Garou immediately change to Crinos or Hispo 
form and either blindly attack those around them or flee 
into the wild. A character who is about to enter frenzy may 
spend a Willpower point and halt it. If so, she does not 
frenzy, but loses any actions that turn. 

The instincts of “flight or fight” are very strong in a 
frenzied Garou; she is completely overcome with one (or 
even both) of these impulses. The player can decide which 
is prominent, but that decision will last the full duration of 
the frenzy — she cannot change her mind later. If she runs, 
she is said to be overcome by the “Fox”; if she stays and 
fights, she is called “Berserk.” 

A Berserk werewolf might actually turn on his own pack 
members, or anyone else (including helpless humans) in 
Berserking Garou 
sometimes lapse into unconsciousness immediately follow- 
ing the Berserk. Garou whose Rage scores exceed their 
Gnosis do not remember anything that happened to them 
during the Berserk. 


the vicinity, if no enemies are left. 


While in a frenzy, Garou may not employ special brawl- 
ing combat maneuvers, nor may they employ weapons or 
Gifts. Ripping and biting are the extent of their tactics; 
they may not use strategies like ambush or pack maneuvers. 


Bt fon roy 


(M 


While in a Berserk frenzy, the Garou must run up to a foe 
and attack; while in a Fox frenzy, the Garou must run 
directly away. In either case, frenzied Garou will fight 
anything in their way. 

The duration of a frenzy is highly variable and depends 
on how long the stressful situation lasts — so long as the 
character senses danger, he remains in a frenzy. If the Garou 
can escape from the scene and flee into hiding, he will 
recover from his frenzy as soon as he can catch his breath 
(an absolute minimum of three turns). Frenzies last twice as 
long if the Garou is hungry... 

It can be difficult to roleplay a frenzy, but if the Story- 
teller feels that the character is displaying too much 
self-control, he can remove a Willpower point from the 
player — after all, the character was obviously fighting to 
keep control. Just think of yourself as a panicked animal 
that has found itself in a terrifying situation from which it 
is trying to escape — either by killing the danger or running 
away from it. 

The primary advantage of frenzy is that the character 
does not need to apply wound penalties to his actions; his 
Rage is so great that he simply ignores pain. A frenzied 
Garou has his full Dice Pool whether he is at Injured or 
Crippled on the Health Level Chart. 


Rage Rolls 


When any of the following conditions occurs, the Story- 
teller may call for a Rage roll to see if a character goes into 
frenzy. 

* Embarrassment 

* Humiliation 

* Any strong emotion, even lust, passion and envy 

* Extreme hunger 

* Confinement; helplessness 

* Taunting of an enemy 

* You've been wronged 

* Silver is in the vicinity 

* (Optional) Thefirst wound taken in combat; difficulty 
decreased by one if it is from a silver weapon 

* (Optional) You botch an important roll 


Difficulty for Rage Rolls 


The difficulty for a Rage roll depends on the phase of the 
moon. The legends of werewolf attacks during a full moon 
are no mere coincidences. 


Difficulty Moon Phase

If the Garou is in Crinos form, the difficulty is decreased 
by one. 


Chapter Eight: Systems
