Belowaresome guidelinestouse when 
creating special maneuvers. These 
rules are entirely optional; begin- 


ning Storytellers should feel free to 
ignore them or wait until they are 
familiar with the regular rules. 

Dice Rolls: There should only be 
twodice rolls involved in any combat 
maneuver: an attack roll and a dam- 
age (or effect) roll. All effects from the 
maneuver should be figured through 
these two rolls. An exception to this rule is 
a movement-based maneuver (see below). 

A hand-to-hand attack is made with a 
Dexterity + Brawl roll, whileamelee 
attack is made with a Dexterity 
+ Melee roll. Whenever a 
charactertries tooutsmart 
or fool an opponent, such 
as with the Taunt ma- 
neuver, the roll would 
instead use Manipula- 
tion plusan appropriate 
Ability (such as 


action or using another maneuver. The Storyteller should 
decide whether a combatant should receive a resistance roll. 
Theresistance roll will often require the combatant to split his 
Dice Pool if he also wants to attack that turn. 

The exception to this is resisting Gifts. Characters can resist 
Gift attacks without splitting a Dice Pool. See the particular 
Gift write-up for details. 

Successes: Generally, an attack needs only one success to 
hit; damage is then rolled. In some instances, however, a set 
number of successes is required, such as when a character tries 
to grapple an opponent; he must gain more successes than the 
opponent's Strength score. 

Damage (Effect): Use the Brawling Chart to determine 
damage and adjust from there for special conditions. A claw 
rake normally does Strength +2, butclaws only do Strength +1 
when performing a fur gnarl, as they are aimed mainly at the 
opponent's armor rather than vitals. 

The damage is aggravated if inflicted by werewolf claws or 
teeth. The claws and fangs of other supernatural creatures 
(Gangrel vampires, fomori, etc.) inflict aggravated damage, 
but normal animal bites are not aggravated. 

If the effect is to fool or confuse an opponent, the general 
tule is that each success on the attack roll subtracts one die 
from the opponent's Dice Pool. In thiscase, only the attack roll 
is made; there is no separate damage roll. 

Multiple Actions: As always, unless a Rage point is spent, 
acharacter will have to split his Dice Pool to perform multiple 
actions in one turn. Many special maneuvers require a Rage 
expenditure in order to be performed at all. These maneuvers 
usually take place during the first Rage action, after everyone 
has taken their normal actions and before any second or 
successive Rage actions. 

Movement: Normally, a character may not move and 
attack in the same action. However, some maneuvers, such as 
Body Slam and Leaping Rake, do permit this. The Storyteller 
can allow other movement-based maneuvers to be performed 
with the following guidelines. 

If a character is performing some acrobatic feat, such as 
leaping, swinging from a chandelier, etc., then a Dexterity + 
Athletics roll may also be required. The difficulty depends on 
the complexity of the maneuver. A simple roll to determine 
leaping distance has a difficulty of only 3 (see Jumping, pg. 
212), while a leap from a hurtling train onto a running horse 
may have a difficulty as high as 9. Unless the character spends 
aRagepoint, he mustsplithis Dice Pool between theacrobatic 
roll and the attack roll. However, the Storyteller should use 
the Automatic Success rule whenever possible. 

There are some exceptions to this rule, in the interest of 
dramatic license. If a character has seen many swashbuckler 
movies and practiced the flamboyant moves she has seen, the 


Storyteller might allow her to swing from a chandelier and 
attack without having to spend a Rage point or split her Dice 
Pool. Alternately, the Storyteller may require her to "pur- 
chase" this as a special maneuver (see Special Maneuvers, 
above). 

Frenzy: Generally, a character cannot perform a special 
maneuver during frenzy. Only berserk actions, such as ripping, 
tearing and biting, are allowed. The Storyteller should be very 
conservative about letting a frenzied character perform a 


special maneuver; the answer should, more often than not, be 
no. See Frenzy, pp. 200-201, for some guidelines. 


Combat in the Umbra 


By "stepping sideways,” a Garou can physically enter the 
Umbra. In the Umbra, a Garou can attack spirits and Banes 
with all the powers he possesses in the physical world. Because 
the Garou are as much spiritual as they are physical, their 
natural weaponry can affect and harm spirits. This includes 
punches and kicks. 

Garou are the exceptions to the rule. Not all beings can 
physically affect spirits; à human who has somehow become 
trapped in the Umbra may swinga punchata spirit only to find 
his hand passing harmlessly through it. A supernaturally 
treated weapon or magical attack is required to affect spirits. 

A Garoucan use weaponry, but the weapon must have been 
mystically treated in order to damage a spirit. All fetish 
weapons can harm spirits; this includes klaives. The Garou 
must still make a Gnosis roll to activate the fetish, but the 
difficulty istwo lower in the Umbra. A Garou can take into the 
Umbra anything that has undergone the Rite of Talisman 
Dedication (see pg. 144). 

See Chapter Seven for more details on the Umbra, and 
Appendix One for examples of spirits. 

Spirits 

Spirits do not have Physical Attributes in the Umbra. 
Instead of attacking with claws or fists, they use their Will- 
powerandRage. Spirits “strike” by rolling Willpower (difficulty 
6). Ifsuccessful, the spirit has hit its target. Then roll the spirit's 
Rage (difficulty 6); one Health Level of aggravated damage is 
inflicted per success. A Garou can soak this damage by rolling 
Gnosis (difficulty 6); the number of successes is the amount of 
damage soaked. If the target is another spirit, the attacking 
spirit inflicts one Power point of damage per success on the 
Rage roll. Use the Spirit Combat Table (on the Combat 
Summary Chart, pg. 246) to help run spirit combats. 

A spirit is not actually swinging punches, throwing kicks or 
slashing with claws, although it might appear to do so. A 
spirit’s attack isa mystical attack of pure Rage; the spirit usually 

flies about its enemy, engulfing him in its anger. 
A spirit cannot soak damage; it must take 
whatever is dished out to it. Only those 
spirits with the 


m ruf SL om rr arms 


Charm: Armor (pg. 182) can soak damage. There is no difference between 
normal and aggravated damage for a spirit. 


Note: When a spirit Materializes onto the physical plane, it attacks using 
its Materialized Attributes and Abilities. Combat is handled normally. (See 
the Charm: Materialize, pg. 182.) 


Garou Maneuvers 


When Garou attack spirits in the Umbra, they can use any attack 
maneuvers they choose. The difficulty of a physical attack in 
the Umbra is increased by one. For example, 
Gnasher uses a claw attack against a Bane. 
He rolls his Dexterity + Brawl versus a 7 
rather than a 6. A maneuver such as 
Taunt, however, is unaffected, for it is not 
aphysicalattack butanattempttounnerve V 
an opponent. 

Any maneuver with a difficulty figured 
against an Attribute (Wits, for example) is 4 
instead figured against the spirit's Willpower, 
and the constant modifier is not used. 

Example: Gnasher tries an evasive action to 
avoid the Scrag’s attack. The difficulty is nor- 
mally the opponent's Wits + 4, but the Scrag has 
no Wits Attribute. Instead, the difficulty is the 
Scrag's Willpower of 6 (the +4 modifier isnotused). 


Damage e 


Damage for Garou attacks is figured normally, bue V ` 
it is applied to the spirit’s Power; spirits have no Health 


Levels. Garou punches, et al., work as well as Garou claws; 
attacks do not have to be aggravated. When a spirit has 
no Power left, it dissipates, dissolving out of 
existence. A Garou can choose to bind the 
defeated spirit (see Rite of Binding, pg. 
144). 

For this reason, most spirits flee 
when they are reduced to a quar- 
ter or less of their Power. Many 
Banes, however, will simply stay 
andrabidly attack until eitherthey 
or their opponents are dead. 


Oursuit in the Umbra 


When aspirit or a Garou tries to 
flee the battle, use the Pursuit rules 
on pg. 213; the fleeing or chasing spirit 
rolls its Willpower. Spirits begin with an auto- 
matic three successes because of their ability to t 
fly in the Umbra. If a fleeing spirit scores 10 successes more 
than its pursuer, it gets away, outdistancing its pursuer. If 
the pursuer matches the spirit's successes, he moves 
alongside the spirit and may attack it. A spirit with the 
Charm: Reform may simply dissipate instead, 
recoalescing elsewhere.

Combat Summary Chart 


Stage One: Initiative 


* Roll Wits + Initiative (difficulty 4). The winner declares her action last (after she has heard 
everyone else's actions) and performs it first. 


* Declare Dice Pool division if performing multiple actions. 
* Declare any Rage point expenditures (maximum of character's Dexterity rating). 


Stage Two: Attack 

* For firearms combat, roll Dexterity + Firearms. 

* For melee (with weapons) combat, roll Dexterity + Melee. 

* For hand-to-hand (without weapons) combat, roll Dexterity + Brawl. 


* Dodge: roll Dexterity * Dodge. A character can forfeit some or all of his Dice Pool to dodge at 
any time; each success subtracts one from the opponent's successes. 


Stage Three: Resolution 
* Roll damage, determined by weapon or maneuver (difficulty 6). 
* Soak damage: roll Stamina (difficulty 6). 


General Complications 


* Changing Actions: The difficulty increases by one. 
* Immobilization: The difficulty to hit an immobilized target is decreased by two. 


* Stunning: When Health Level damage exceeds Stamina rating, the target is stunned and 
cannot act next turn (a Rage point will counter the effect). 


Spirit Combat Table 


Stage One: Initiative 
* As above. Spirits roll Willpower for initiative. 


Stage Two: Attack 
* Roll Willpower (difficulty 6) unless a Charm is being used (refer to the Charm description) 
* Dodge: Willpower (difficulty 6), or split Willpower Dice Pool between attack and dodge. 


Stage Three: Resolution 

* Roll Rage (difficulty 6); one Health Level of aggravated damage is inflicted per success (Garou 
can soak this with a Gnosis roll, difficulty 6); one Power point per success is lost if the target isa spirit. 

* Soak damage: spirits cannot soak damage.

Miniatures and 
Werewolf 


At some point, every Storyteller deals with player confu- 
sion and complaints, especially during combat scenes. Where 
is my character? How far away am 1 from the Black Spiral? Is the 
Leech in range of my crossbow? What do you mean didn't see the 
fomor? How did the Pentex goons see me? Bloody Jaws needs to 
retake his last action — he knew the hunters were standing right next. 
tohim, IH justdidn' thear you. Callme when someone figures out how 
many Banes are left. 

Does any of that sound familiar? 

Miniatures enhance combat scenes by helping players and 
Storytellers visualize the encounter. A map allows a player to 
answer many of her own questions. Storytellers have an easier 
job keeping track of everything, and play proceeds more 
smoothly. Some groups fear that miniaturesare too hard to use 
and cost too much. Others think that setting up miniatures 
interrupts a game too much. Ifa map can alleviate arguments, 
then the time spent setting up is worth it. As far as cost goes, 
adequate counters, etal., can be acquired for under two dollars. 

Miniatures can make Werewolf games more fun. Some 
players really love having small painted pieces represent their 
characters. Also, miniatures help players visualize some of the 
special combat maneuvers. With a map, movement becomes 
more important, and Gifts like Leap of the Kangaroo are much 
more impressive. The range of guns has meaning. Further- 
more, destroying terrain features and physically removing 
enemy pieces provide an immediate sense of satisfaction. 

All ofthe rules in this section are suggestions. If they make the 
gametoocomplexordetractftomtheatmosphereofyourchronicle, 
don't use them. Each group has its own playing style. 


The Materials 


If you can't afford miniatures and can't find hex paper, don't 
despair. With a few pieces of paper (or dice) and a good ruler, you 
can run the War of the Amazon. The scale of all Werewolf 
miniatures rules is: 1" hex = one yard. If characters move off the 
map, use the ruler to keep going. If you make paper pieces, 
rememberthat Garouin Hispoand Crinosformsoccupy twohexes 
(see Space, below), and use an arrow to indicate the direction that 
each piece faces. If you use dice as miniatures, make a quick key on 
scrap paper and try to choose dice of different colors. For extra

dramaticeffect,theStorytellercanchangethenumbersonthedice 
to reflect damage, lowering them for each wound a character 
suffers. Dice and paper work well for extras in massive battles 
wherein the combatants exceed group's miniatures supply. Clear 
plasticrulershave dozens ofapplicationsin miniatures battles, such 
as determining range and areas of effect, creating terrain, and 
establishing line of sight. 

Most stores that carry gaming materials stock at least a few 
miniatures. Ral Partha puts out a line of miniatures for 
Werewolf: The Apocalypse and Vampire: The Masquer- 
ade. The Werewolf line includes Garou (in all forms), fomori, 
Black Spiral Dancers, and Wyrm beasts. Most models meant 
for use with near-future or cyberpunk games also work for 
characters in Homid form, and there are other werewolf 
models available for Garou in Crinos or Lupus forms. Fantasy 
monsters make wonderful Wyrm spawn, especially when 
given suitably toxic paint jobs. Most stores that sell miniatures 
also sell paints, brushes and primer, or at least can order them. 
Model and hobby shops also sell paints and brushes. 


Maps 

When choosing a map, make sure that it can represent the 
needed terrain. Investing in a reusable map saves the most money 
inthe long run. Hex maps of 1" scale are available in many gaming 
stores, and many mail-order companies sell them. If you can't find 
1" hex maps, 1" square maps work fine. In case you can't find 
anything in 1" scale, any surface can be made into terrain by using 
a ruler to measure movement and ranges. 

Mapsare made from different materials. Make certain that you 
purchase markers that wash off your map. Use water-based markers 
for acetate maps and overhead projection markers for vinyl maps. 
Dry-erase boards (used with rulers to measure distances), which 
have the advantage of letting you draw terrain, are available in 
most office-supply stores. Special dry-erase markers are sold for use 
with the boards. Always check with the store or mail-order 
company to find out which markers to use. 

Cleaning maps is the key to ensuring their life. Always clean 
maps immediately after finishing with them. Glass cleaner makes 
removing old markings fairly easy. A great cleaning trick that 
workseven on maps left uncleaned for months is coloring over old 
lines, then wiping or using glass cleaner. 

Some Storytellers draw planning maps before their games. 1/4" 
hexagonal grid paper makes a good scale for planning maps. This 
paper is both cheap and widely available. A planning map lets a 
Storyteller designa huge area without having toconstructaplaying

map. The planning map should be at the one hex = one yard scale. A 
planning map aids in consistent storytelling, especially ifa certain site 
provides the backdrop for multiple combats. Drawingaplanning map 
of the pack's caern for permanent reference is handy. 


Terrain 


Industrious groups may want to build their own terrain 
instead of drawing it on maps. Buildings and trees (primarily 
made for model trains), on sale at hobby shops, add a lot of 
atmosphere to battle scenes. A little imagination can turn a 
variety of household objects into scenery. Boxes can become 
buildings, and old toy cars or bulldozers make wonderful props. 
Cloth, construction paper, poster board, even old socks can be 
hijacked for use as terrain. True miniatures lovers may go all 
out and build a sandbox for their games. 


Putting Maps to Use 


When you want to use miniatures, have the characters set 
up on the playing map — either on an edge or in the center, 
depending on the scene. Some Storytellers like to draw maps 
before a scene, while others draw features as the characters 
perceive them. The first option has the advantage of expedi- 
ency, while the second keeps characters from being aware of 
things or NPCs that they can’t sense. Experiment and use the 
method that works best with your group. 

If you draw the map once characters are positioned, remember 
thatGarou in Crinos, Hispo, and Lupusformshave preternaturally 
sharp senses. A werewolf can identify objects using hearing and 
smell. A fun way to get a feel for how much a Garou can sense is 
totakeadogforawalkatnightand compare hisawareness to yours, 
such as when he growls at things you don’t even notice. 

Remember, when you draw a playing map, it’s not impor- 
tant to be exact, but it is important to be consistent, and all 
players should be able to see the play map. Ifa player can’t see 
the map, then the advantages of using miniatures are lost. 


The Rules 


A few of the rules need to be adjusted or clarified to 
survive the transition from imagination to concrete figures 
and terrain. Most changes are slight. When in doubt, run 
the combat exactly as you would without the miniatures. 
As always, if a rule doesn't work for you, throw it out. If the 
rules don't cover something you'd like, embellish them. 
Miniatures should enhance play, not detract from it. 


Space 


All figures take up space on the playing map. A human 
occupies a single hex, as does a Garou in Glabro form. Hispo 
and Crinos forms occupy two hexes. A Lupus fills one to 
two hexes, depending on how long it is. It is possible to 
move without penalty through a hex containing a Homid 
or Lupus figure. Glabro, Hispo, and Crinos figures fill their 
entire hex or hexes. Only by flying, leaping or using some 
other special maneuver can another figure pass through a 
hex containing a werewolf in one of these forms. 


248 


Facing 

You must be certain of the facing of all miniatures involved 
in a battle. For most miniatures, the direction of the head 
determines the facing, but some miniatures have the heads 
pointed in odd directions. Forclarity, you may mark each piece 
with asmall piece oftape on the forward facing. The tape helps 
ensure that everyone knows who is facing what. Characters 
can normally attack only those targets in their front three 
hexes. Most groups have characters face only hex sides, but 
some will want to use points as well. 

When a Garou transforms, her facing remains constant. For 
miniatures that occupy more than one hex, try to keep the rear 
legs planted in the original hex. Hispo and Lupus miniatures 
expand to the forward hex, while a Crinos extends to either 
the right or left side hexes. 

Characters have a triangular field of vision, extending 
outward from the hex in front of the head. Line of sight 
depends on situational modifiers such as daylight, fog, smoke, 
etc. Walls, trees, cars and other objects may also block line of 
sight. Garou using other senses, such as smell or hearing, sense 
outward in a radius around their head. Factors such as wind, 
burning rubber, or heavy machinery may require Perception + 
Alertness (or Primal-Urge depending on the form) rolls to use 
these other senses effectively. In all cases, common sense 
should be the ultimate guide. 


Movement Calculation 


Movement is the most important element in miniatures 
rules. Garou may always choose movement as an action. 
Beforea battle, calculate and record the movement rates forall 
characters involved. Garou have three movement modes: 
walking, jogging, and running. See the Movement Rates 
Sidebarfor the amount of hexes/yards a character can move in 
one turn . For more information, see Moving, pg. 209. 

No roll is required to move, but movement is the only 
action the character can perform in that turn (the exceptions 
to thisare special maneuvers such as Body Slam and Leaping 
Rake; see below). 

When walking or jogging, characters may turn one hex- 
facing to the right or left for each hex they move. A character 
may turnan extra hex-facing by reducing his movement by 1" 
per facing change. Characters who walk backward may only 
move 4" per turn, regardless of form. 

Running characters may only change facing once for every 
3" they move. 

Characters may only move in one mode in a given turn. 
Characters who stand in place may turn to face any direction. 
A character never has to use all of her movement, but she 
cannot save it for another turn. 

Terrain may drastically affect movement rates. A deep 
marsh reduces walking and jogging movement to one-quarter 
normal, and prevents running altogether. Some surfaces, such 
as a wet tile floor, may require Dexterity + Athletics rolls to 
avoid slipping and losing any remaining movement. A slope 
or grade may reduce a character's movement rate by up to 10". 


Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


p/m. am, EEE BEER c————À 


Other obstacles may also shave hexes off a character's move- 
ment. Dexterity * Athletics rolls made by running characters 
to avoid terrain difficulties have difficulties of 8. 

Ifaplayer character slams into an obstacle, the Storyteller may 
rule that the Garou suffers from one to three Health Levels of 
damage, depending on her speed and the strength/shape of the 
object. The character receives a Stamina roll to soak the damage. 
A glass window would inflict only one Health Level, and a 
werewolf would shatter it as she leapt through. Running into a 
large construction crane at breakneck speed in Lupus form might 
inflict three Health Levels of damage. Damage from obstacles is 
optional and completely up to the Storyteller. 


Dodges and Evasive Actions 


When a werewolf dodges or evades, she moves behind 
nearby cover or away from her opponent. In brawling or melee 
combat, a character who successfully dodges may move one 
hex, regardless of whether or not she is hit. 

In a firefight, a character may move up to three hexes in 
search of cover. The difficulty of her dodge depends on the 
availability of cover (see Dodging, pp.226-227). The facing of 
adodging character shifts to the direction in which she moves. 

A character using the Evasive Action maneuver may shift 
his facing in whatever direction she desires, or not at all. 


Hand-to-Hand Combat 


Characters may engage in brawling combat when they are 
within one hex of each other. Ifa character want to attack an 
opponentat his flank, his difficulty increases by two. Toattack 
acharacter directly to the rear, the difficulty increases by three. 
Some combat maneuvers and Gifts modify these rules. 

Melee combat may occur at a range of one or two hexes, 
depending on the length of a character’s weapon. A long, 
hand-held weapon, such as a spear, whip, pole, or two-handed 
sword, gives a character the advantage of attacking while 
standing two hexes from his opponent. 


Movement-Based Combat Maneuvers 


Body slams and leaping rakes both require that the character 
move. In order to perform a body slam, a Garou must run toward 
hisopponent; walkingorjoggingdoes not build sufficient momen- 
tum. A character can body slam a target only one hex away from 
her, but the Storyteller may raise the difficulty or lower her Dice 
Pool because of her low momentum. The character ends her 
movement in the same hex as her target. Ifshe fails this maneuver, 
she falls to the ground in the target’s hex. 

The Leaping Rake maneuver lets a character move through a 
hexcontaininganother figure. The player picksa target hex where 
he wantsto land, and then leaps. He rolls Dexterity + Athletics (or 
uses the Automatic Success rule) to see if he can reach his target 
hex. His successes are compared to the Jumping Chart (see 
Jumping, pg. 212). A character must leap in the direction he faces, 
and his facing doesn’t change when he lands. 

Players may design other movement-based combat maneuvers 
using the freeform combat rules. Keep new maneuvers plausible, using 


Chapter Nine: Drama 


ES ae e 


the Body Slam, Leaping Rake, and Dodge maneuvers as guidelines. 
Remember to account for facing changes. So long as a Garou with a 
new maneuver doesn't ruin the fun of combat, let players enjoy. 


The Umbra and Spirit Combat 


Spirits can fly a maximum distance of 20 yards + Willpower per 
turn. Because spirits fly, terrain doesn't modify how fara spirit may 
move. Attacks from spirits in the Umbra take place at brawling 
range. Whenaspirit Materializes, it is treated like any other figure. 

Some Garou like to step sideways during combat. To 
represent characters in the Umbra, the Storyteller can move 
their miniatures toanother mapor placea piece of black paper 
underneath the figure. Spirits and other beings lurking in the 
Umbra should also stay on a separate map or have some 
marking to show their presence outside the physical world. 


Painting Miniatures 


‚At some point you may decide to paint your miniatures. Many 
people are intimidated by the thought of trying to paint a miniature. 
All it takes is some practice anda little bit of knowledge. 

First, wash the miniature. Then file down any extra material and 
wash itagain. Some peopleattach apiece of cardboard with two-sided 
tape to the bottom of the miniature after it dries. This piece of 
cardboard isused to handle the piece while painting it. Youthen need 
to prime the piece. Primer helps the paint stick to the miniature and 
makesthe whole painting process much easier. We suggest using gray 
or white primer. Following the directions on the primer, give your 
miniatures an even coatand enough time to dry. If you leteverything 
dry ovemight you should be safe. 

There are different types of paints for use with miniatures. We 
recommend water-based acrylic paints. Good colors to start with are 
black, white, a flesh tone, a medium shade of brown, and blue or red. 
Other good Garou colors include gray, silver and green. Purple, 
orange, yellow, black and green can make sickening Wyrm creatures. 
Mixing small amounts of white and black with other colors creates 
lighter or darker shades. Plastic counter trays for wargames are good 
placesto mix paints. Ifyouseal the trays, the mixed colors willstay wet 
fora few days. 

Nylon bristle brushes with sharp points are good. Buy at least two: 
avery fine size anda medium size. Paint out ofthe lids of the paint jars 
and coat only the tips of the brushes. Do not let the paint reach the 
roots of the bristles; this ruins brushes. 

Cover the painting area with newspaper or paper towels. Have a 
cup of water handy, one from which people will never need to drink. 
Make sure the area is adequately illuminated. Have astack of napkins 
or paper towels ready for drying your brush. Always be gentle with 
brushes; bristles are easily destroyed. 

Paint light colors first; you can paint over light colors more easily 
than dark ones. If you completely mess up, water-based paints wash 
off with a little effort. If you want to preserve a favorite paint job, use 
some sealant, available wherever paints are sold. 

There are many advanced painting techniques: for example, 
highlighting, shading, and dry-brushing. As you continue paint- 
ing, develop your own style. You will soon realize that most 
painting suggestions are just expressions of personal preference. 


249 


Antagonists 


Fomor (plural Fomori) 


Fomori are humans who have turned to the Wyrm. In the 
process, they gain great power, but are marked or deformed 
in some way. Many fomori are mindless, deformed canni- 
bals who lurk in the woods and near landfills. Some, 
however, retain their sentience and appearance; these are 
used by the Wyrm to infiltrate human society. 

A fomor is created when a Bane possesses a body. Most 
often, the person's personality and consciousness remain 
the same, but are now fused with a malevolent spirit. If the 
person was already corrupt and evil, the resulting fomor 
may be a truly psychotic creature. 

Pentex (see Chapter Two) has an active division dedi- 
cated to the creation and training of fomori. This division, 
called Project Iliad, "recruits" employees from Pentex sub- 
sidiaries and uses them in horrific experiments, hoping to 
create fabulous new kinds of fomori. Pentex uses these 
"promoted" workers as its front-line defense against Garou 
assaults. 

Attributes: Strength 3+, Dexterity 2+, Stamina 3+, 
Charisma 1*, Manipulation 1+, Appearance (usually) O, 
Perception 2, Intelligence 1+, Wits 1+ 

Abilities (typical): Brawl 1 to 3, Dodge 1, Firearms 1, 
Melee 1 or 2, Stealth 1, Survival 2, Occult 1 


Appendix 


p/m. am, EN amar n -—————— //, 


Powers: All fomori have one or more special abilities: 
"gifts" from the Wyrm's corruption. See the list below for 
examples of powers, or feel free to make up your own. 

Equipment: Pentex fomori are often equipped with an 
array of military weaponry: assault rifles, combat knives, 
flak jackets, radios, etc. 


Fomori Powers 


Most common fomori have only three powers; some 
have fewer and some have many more. The fomori created 
by Pentex usually have three to five, in addition to Immu- 
nity to the Delirium. 

* Berserker — The fomor has five Rage points and can 
use these just like any Garou. However, the fomor is also 
susceptible to frenzy. 

* Claws and Fangs — The fomor possesses natural 
weaponry similar to Garou claws and teeth. He may attack 
using claw or bite maneuvers, and he inflicts aggravated 
damage. 

* Extra Limbs — Fomori often have a number of extra 
limbs, usually in the form of tentacles or masses of tendrils. 
Such extra limbs often sprout from awkward places: for 
example, an extra arm growing from a fomor's thigh. 

* Eyes of the Wyrm — The eyes of the fomor are weird 
and can actually dilate, revealing images of the Wyrm's 
damnation. An opponent who gazes into the fomor's eyes 
must make a Willpower roll (difficulty 8) or be frozen in 
horror for (five turns minus Wits rating; minimum one 


251 


turn). The fomor itself cannot attack its victim, but its 
friends can. 

* Fungal Touch — The inside of the fomor's body has 
been replaced by a foul-smelling fungoid substance. The 
fomor may infect an opponent by touching him — the 
victim must make a Stamina roll (difficulty 7) or begin 
losing one point from all Physical Attributes, as well as 
Appearance, per day (as the fungus slowly covers him...). 
The infection may only be cured by supernatural means 
(such as with the Gift: Resist Toxin or a healing fetish). 
Also, thefomor may exude the fungoid mucus over its body, 
causing all who attack in melee to subtract two from their 
Dice Pools because of the revolting stench. 

* Immunity to the Delirium — Most fomori are im- 
mune to the Delirium. The Wyrm-taint has erased the Veil 
along with their humanity. Notall fomori are thus immune, 
and the degree of immunity seems to depend on the amount 
of Wyrm-taint possessed. Pentex Inc. injects its fomori with 
a special serum that destroys the part of the brain suscep- 
tible to the Delirium. Assume that all fomori created by 
Pentex will not be affected by the Delirium. 

* Poison Tumors — The fomor is covered in tumors 
filled with a noxious pus — whenever the fomor is hit with 
a claw, the attacker is splattered with pus and must imme- 


diately attempt to soak three dice of damage (five dice if the 


fomorisbitten). Ifthefomor is hit with a melee weapon, the 
attacker must make a Dexterity roll (difficulty 6) to avoid 
the flying pus, or take damage as above. Firearms are, of 
course, safe. 

* Voice of the Wyrm — The fomor's tongue is long and 
sluglike, and the fomor may speak in the Wyrm's own 
language. When this fomor chants the vile syllables of the 
Dark Litany, all in hearing range (save Wyrm creatures) 
must make a Willpower roll (difficulty 8) or lose half their 
Gnosis points. This power may only be used on a given 
victim once per encounter. The tongue may also lick 
opponents in close combat, inflicting two dice of damage. 


Black Spiral (Dancers 


Also known as the Lost Tribe, the dreaded Black Spiral 
Dancers are those Garou who turned to the Wyrm. Once 
the White Howlers, a noble tribe akin to the Fianna, they 
were corrupted by the Wyrm into the foul, vicious things 
theyare today. The Dancers have lived underground among 
horrors for ages, and all are quite insane; however, the 
Wyrm has given its slaves terrible powers of their own, as 
well as a violent hatred for the Garou. 

Black Spiral Dancers roughly resemble other Garou; 
however, many of them are malformed, either through 
metis birth or close proximity to the radioactive balefires of 
the Wyrm. The heads of their Crinos forms are often huge 
and slaver-jawed, resembling a hyena's, while their ears are 
hairless and pointed like a bat's. Their eyes are huge and 
round, glowing with a red or green luminescence, while 
their fur is patchy and usually either albino-white or gray- 


ish-green. Black Spirals’ human forms are usually twisted 
and deformed, but some are quite beautiful. 

The Dancers’ totem is Whippoorwill, whose mad call 
the Dancers emit during their hunts. They name them- 
selves after a mysterious labyrinth that exists in the realm 
of the Wyrm; they are said to “dance” this Black Spiral to 
gain dark powers and wisdom. Indeed, to dance the Black 
Spiral and survive is considered by the Black Spiral Dancers 
to be the most sacred of feats. 

Black Spiral Dancers should be generated like any other 
Garou, but most of them are metis, having inbred for ages 
in the deep darkness. Their “Gifts” often resemble muta- 
tions, and their nature is up to the Storyteller; some 
suggestions follow: 

Sense Wyrm (Level One) — Same as the Metis Gift. 

Ears of the Bat (Level Two) — Black Spiral Dancers 
with this Gift have large, batlike ears in their wolf forms; 
even in their human forms, their ears are abnormally large. 
This Gift enables the Black Spiral Dancer to use sonar like 
a bat, allowing him to sense objects and foes even in total 
darkness. 


Patagia (Level Three) — The Dancer has flaps of skin 
under her arms, resembling the membranes of a pterodactyl 
or flying squirrel. By outstretching her arms and leaping 
from a height, she may glide at 25 mph. The Dancer has 
these patagia in all forms. 

Foaming Fury (Level Three) — The Dancer’s mouth 
bubbles and foams with a greenish fluid. Anyone bitten 


must succeed in a Stamina roll (difficulty 8) or fly into a 
rabid frenzy. 

Crawling Poison (Level Four) — This Gift enables the 
Black Spiral Dancer to infect other Garou with a slow 
poison. This poison, when injected into a Garou via claw 
or bite, inhibits her regenerative powers. The Dancer rolls 
its Gnosis (difficulty of the victim’s Stamina); the effect 
lasts for one hour per success 

Balefire (Level Five) — The Dancer can hurl spheres of 
sickly green flame at her opponent. If she hits (Dexterity + 
Athletics; difficulty 6 — use the Firearms Chart for compli- 
cations), the victim must roll Stamina (difficulty 8) and 
match or exceed the Dancer’s number of successes. If he 
fails, he is mutated in a manner decided by the Storyteller. 
These mutations are always harmful, and each success on 
the Dancer’s roll is treated as a level of aggravated damage 
for the purpose of healing/rejecting the mutation. 


Governments 


I hear much support for the monarchy 

I hear the Union Jack’s to remain, 

I see Namatjira in custody 

I see Truganini’s in chains. 

— Midnight Oil, “Truganini” 

How much do the world governments suspect? How 
much do they know? It is hard to say. Many governments 
have agencies or departments devoted to the investigation 


Appendix 253 


| 


of paranormal occurrences, but many of those, especially 
on the military end, seem to be devoted to extrasensory 
phenomena, such as ESP, clairvoyance and telekinesis. In 
general, it seems clear that the Veil has remained intact 
and that humans know very little. 

Britain has such an organization, but it is very difficult 
to trace. Some suspect that it is actually of a quasi-mystical 
nature, possibly with ties to similar organizations dating 
back hundreds of years. British Garou have reported in- 
stances of unnerving accuracy in the investigations of 
Scotland Yard following unfortunate Garou-related occur- 
rences. Some say that this group is actually controlled by a 
vampire and used by her to combat her enemies. 

In the United States, interest in Garou activity can be 
traced to two agencies: the Federal Bureau of Investigation 
and the National Security Agency. 

The FBI might contain several individuals who suspect 
the truth. There is even a special department devoted to 
the investigation of the paranormal. Originally formed to 
neutralize the impact of suspected "Communist Thought 
Control" research, this department, known generally as 
Special Affairs (though its members rarely identify them- 
selves as such) is involved in continuing investigations. 
Some of Special Affairs’ investigations during the '50s and 
'60s may have uncovered some Garou-related information. 
Despite this, Special Affairs has dwindled significantly in 
power and membership over the years. Proof of suspected 
activities is demanded by the FBI before action can be 
taken, and proof is what has thus far eluded the depart- 
ment. Circumstantial evidence of werewolf activity no 
doubt abounds, but that last, necessary piece of tangible 
evidence has escaped Special Affairs — so far. 

It is believed that the NSA keeps an active file on 
supernatural events, but treats them as a subclassification 
ofterrorism. The agency has not yet made the connections 
that would reveal the whole picture. The NSA is a giant 
fact-sifting agency concerned with national security from 
an internal perspective. The NSA flags police and news 
reports that contain interesting or anomalous facts. Inves- 
tigation only occurs after the computer, or a reviewer, 
notices undue occurrences that may be related. Should the 
NSA actually deduce any significant Garou-related con- 
nections, the resources that could be brought to bear are 
truly frightening. 

Police Officer: At one time or another, werewolves will 
find themselves on the wrong side of the law, whether 
through their own folly or some devious plan of the Story- 
teller. Most local cops patrol in police cruisers. Help isonly 
aradio call away; usually one to five other cars arrive within 
minutes of an emergency call. In extreme emergencies, up 
to 50 other police officers can be summoned within 10 
minutes (at least in a city).

Suggested Abilities: Alertness 3, Athletics 1, Brawl 3,

Intimidation 2, Investigation 4, Law 3, Leadership 3, Police 
Procedure 5, Politics 1, Stealth 3, Subterfuge 1, Science 2 

Equipment: Lt. Revolver, Hvy. Auto. Pistol, Submachine

Portable Lie Detector, Bugs, Class II Armor, Mirrorshades 

SWAT Officer: These officers are trained in the use of 
high-powered weapons and military tactics. If things ever 
get out of hand with the Garou — a gun battle, for instance 
— they will certainly be called in.

«Che Jnquisition 


These loathsome parasites that cling 
To the cross — the cloth and the skin 
Soaked in the blood of men — NOT the body of Christ! 

— Christian Death, "This Is Heresy" 

It is generally acknowledged that the Roman Catholic 
Church learned of the Garou during the years of the 
Inquisition. Instituted in 1229, the Inquisition concerned 
itself with the active suppression of the various heresies 
spreading through Europe. Partially in response to the rise 
of the Catharist heresy in southern France and northern 
Italy, Pope Innocent IV approved the use of torture in 1252. 

There are tales that the Catharist beliefs were actively 
supported by many Garou Kinfolk of the time. It is said that 
a few Garou fell into the hands of the Inquisition when 
their Kin were forced to confess their heresy. If this is so, it 
could explain the rapid escalation in the tyrannical prac- 
tices of the Inquisition. Perhaps they had seen proof, with 
their own eyes, of evil incarnate in the world. 

Whatever the truth of those events during the 13th 
century, all indications are that the Church remains aware 
of, and concerned about, the Garou. There are rumored to 
be two orders within the Church that are the focus of those 
concerns. Indeed, the Inquisition continues still, albeit in 
a different form. 


Today the Inquisition is an organization of scholars and 
researchers of the occult, as well as a clearing house for 
many of the greatest hunters of the supernatural. Though 
the Inquisition is no longer supported or sanctioned by the 
Church, mostof its membersare from the Catholic Church. 
It is a loose confederation of scholars and high-ranking 
priests who keep in touch mainly through letters and rare 
conferences. Though the Inquisition has taken a new 
name, "The Society of Leopold," and though its members 
say they are only interested in research (they keep most of 
the oldest records), they are preeminent among hunters of 
vampires, Garou, and even mages! 

Witch-hunter: These are the agents of the Inquisition, 
most often members of one of the various holy orders. They 
act without the formal knowledge of the Church. 

Character Creation: Attributes 8/6/3, Abilities 21/12/7, 
Backgrounds 6, Willpower 10 

Suggested Attributes: Assume ratings of 2, except for 
Intelligence, which should often be 3. Most successful 
witch-hunters have high Physical Attributes. 

Suggested Abilities: Alertness 2, Enigmas 4, Etiquette 3, 
Expression 2, Intimidation 3, Investigation 2, Linguistics 3, 
Medicine 3, Occult 3, Politics 2, Subterfuge 2, Survival 1, 
Science 1; many witch-hunters possess Brawl 3, Dodge, 4, 
Firearms 4, Melee 3, Stealth 3 

Equipment: Bible, Silver Cross, Medal of St. Ignatius, 
Relics, Robe 


The Arcanum 


Lentered, charmed, and from a cobwebbed heap 

Took up the nearest tome and thumbed it through, 

Trembling at curious words that seemed to keep 

Some secret, monstrous if only one knew. 

— H.P. Lovecraft, Fungi from Yuggoth 

The formation of the Arcanum can be traced to the 
mystical "War of the Roses" that centered around Paris in 
the late 1800s (not related to the English Baronial Wars). 
A war of words (and, if the combatants’ words are to be 
believed, mystic forces) arose between two orders of 
Rosicrucians. The fighting between the orders become 
such a public scandal (and entertainment, hence the Pari- 
sian newspapers' "War of the Roses" brand) that many of 
both groups' best practitioners and scholars left their re- 
spectiveorders. Afterdraftinga greatcharter, these dissidents 
united to form the Arcanum. This order persists to the 
present. 

Though the Arcanum has only formally existed for less 
than 100 years, its history dates back even farther. The core 
of the Arcanum consists of a group that has branded itself 
the "White Monks." It is believed that these so-called 
White Monks were somehow involved in the Inquisition 
and learned of Garou there. However, they are not cur- 
rently connected with the Inquisition, and never actually 
engage in witch hunts. The Arcanum studies, but does not 
destroy. 

The Arcanum has three known Foundation houses — 
one in Boston, one in Paris, and a third in Vienna. Its 
members, recruited from the cream of intellectual society, 
are today concerned more with theory than practice. They 
seem devoted solely to the gathering and study of occult- 
related information, but are focused primarily on the past 
rather than the modern world. Some members have shown 
a degree of interest in the here and now, but these members, 
and the Arcanum itself, likely believe werewolves to be 
long gone if they ever existed at all. The Arcanum as a 
whole seems to be more interested in phenomena of a less 
tangible nature: magic, miracles and hauntings. 

Scholar: These intellectuals are involved in the gather- 
ing and classification of paranormal matters of all sorts, 
including alleged werewolf sightings. They are not inter- 
ested in violent confrontation with the supernatural and 
will avoid such at all costs. When in the field, investigators 
operate in groups of two to four to provide witnesses and 
greater safety. 

Character Creation: Attributes 9/6/3, Abilities 15/9/3, 
Backgrounds 7, Willpower 10 

Suggested Attributes: Assume ratings of 2, except for 
Charisma, Intelligence, and Manipulation, which should 
be 3 or even 4. 

Suggested Abilities: Drive 1, Enigmas 3, Etiquette 2, 
Expression 2, Intimidation 1, Investigation 4, Leadership 4, 
Linguistics 4, Occult 4, Science 3, Subterfuge 2. Those who

collecting ectoplasm, measuring the “magical” energy of ley

Equipment: Automobile, Various “Gadgets,” Investiga- 
tive Paraphernalia 


Other Supernatural 
Beings 


Dampires 


Lay down in the web of the black spider 
I'll drink your blood like wine 
So come on in 
it ain't no sin 
take off your skin 
and dance around in your bones. 
— Tom Waits, "The Black Rider" 

Vampires are creatures of the cities. They feed from the 
human population of urban areas. Vampires are largely 
responsible for the unchecked growth of urban sprawls. 

Vampires subsist on human blood and derive many 
special powers from it. A vampire who has recently feasted 
on blood is usually much stronger and faster than a mortal. 
The Blood Pool listing below takes this into consideration. 
A vampire may use one Blood Point to increase a Physical 
Attribute up to 5 (and sometimes higher) or to heal one 
Health Level (except for damage caused by fire, sunlight, or 
the teeth and claws of supernatural entities such as Garou). 

Gifts: The Gifts rating is the total level of Gifts a 
vampire possesses. These are not Garou Gifts as such, for 
vampires have no Gnosis and Rage and thus few ties to the 
spirit world — these are merely the equivalent powers. 
Many vampire powers deal with controlling the minds of 
mortals (and Garou) or corrupting others. 

If you are using Vampire: The Masquerade, use the 
Disciplines from that book instead of Gifts. 

Neonates: These are the youngest vampires, who have 
not yet reached 100 years of unlife. They are the “teenagers” 
of vampiric society. Garou are most likely to encounter 
these vampires, because neonates don’t know enough to 
stay hidden from werewolves. 

Character Creation: Attributes 7/5/3, Abilities 13/9/3, 
Backgrounds 7, Willpower 7, Gifts 2, Blood Pool 10 

Suggested Attributes: Assume ratings of 2 in all At- 
tributes. 

Suggested Abilities: Alertness 2, Athletics 1, Brawl 2, 
Dodge 1, Etiquette 1, Expression 1, Intimidation 2, Melee 1, 
Occult 1, Stealth 3, Streetwise 1, Subterfuge 3 

Suggested Gifts: Heightened Senses, Awe, Resist Pain 

Equipment: Fashionable Clothing, Switchblade, Sun- 
glasses 


Elders: Elders are the princes of their urban realms and 
often dominate a city’s politics. Elder vampires have potent 
blood, have survived between 300 and 1000 years, and thus 
have considerable inherent powers. The vampire stats 
below represent a traditional Western variety. 

Character Creation: Attributes 10/7/5, Abilities 21/9/3, 
Backgrounds 12, Willpower 8, Gifts 4, Blood Pool 20 

Suggested Attributes: Assume ratings of 4 in Social, 3 in 
Mental, and 2 in Physical Attributes. 

Suggested Abilities: Alertness 3, Athletics 1, Brawl 2, 
Dodge 3, Enigmas 2, Etiquette 3, Expression 1, Intimidation 4, 
Melee 2, Occult 2, Stealth 3, Streetwise 1, Subterfuge 4 

Suggested Gifts: Heightened Senses, Awe, Glib Tongue, 
Mindblock, Roll Over, Ultimate Argument of Logic 

Equipment: Outdated but Expensive Clothing, Tinted 
Glasses, Pocket Watch, Sword Cane 

Ghoul: Many vampires create ghouls. This is accom- 
plished by giving a mortal or animal some vampire blood 
without first draining the creature of its own life force. 
Because ghouls are essentially mortals, no statistics are 
given; use human or animal stats, maybe with slight addi- 
tions to Physical Attributes (particularly Strength) 

Special Rules: So long as ghouls imbibe vampire blood 
regularly, they can live forever. However, once the point of 
their natural lifespan has passed, ghouls must always have 
vampire blood in their systems. Otherwise, they will age 
and die very quickly — within a few days, or perhaps even 


a few hours. Ghouls can use the blood within them in 
precisely the same manner vampires do (i.e., to increase 
stats and heal). Assume ghouls have one to 10 Blood 
Points, depending on the generosity of their master. 


Mages 

Our fellow men are the black magicians. 

— Carlos Castaneda, Tales of Power 

Mages are humans with the apparent power to bend 
reality to their will. The uses to which they put this power 
vary with the mage in question, but most Garou distrust 
mages on principle. 

Many mages seek “Quintessence,” or the raw life-force of 
creation. This so-called Quintessence flows from caerns 
(which the mages call “Nodes”), and mages often form 
raiding parties to drain the sacred sites of their precious 
Quintessence. Naturally, this does not sit well with Garou. 

There are a variety of mage factions, and they wage a 
shadowy war over reality itself, fighting for something they 
call “Ascension.” Certain mages, called Marauders, em- 
brace the Wyld; others, called Nephandi, apparently serve 
the Wyrm. Two large factions, the Traditions and the 
Technocracy, are conglomerations of different groups gath- 
ered to pursue a common purpose; while the Traditions 
seek to liberate reality and expand the horizons of the 
human mind and spirit, the Technocracy strives to bind all 
of reality into a safely controlled static pattern, a Weaver- 


mesh for the common good. Most Garou neither know nor 
careaboutthedivisionsamongmages, butsomefew werewolves 
whoknow thesecrets of mage society have allied with Maraud- 
ers or Tradition mages. Two of the Traditions, called the 
Verbena and the Dreamspeakers, are especially close to some 
Garou. Nevertheless, mages are generally regarded with dis- 
trust, and they often earn their bad reputations. 

Amusingly enough, mages seem to feara mystic force called 
“Paradox.” This effect, a sort of reality backlash, limits the 
effects of the magick mages dare to use. Because of Paradox, 
mage magick tends to take the form of surprising coincidences 
rather than fireballs down Main Street. Paradox isa mystery to 
the Garou, who are immune to its effects; some Theurges 
speculate that Gaia herself punishes those prideful humans 
who step out of line too often, while other Garou have less 
prosaic theories. Galliards tell great tales of mages dragged to 
the Abyss by fearful Paradox spirits, or exploding from accu- 
mulated Paradox energy. Ragabash have tried to figure out 
how to use Paradox to their advantage, but only a few Uktena 
and Glass Walkers are willing or able to deal with such a 
manifestation of the Weaver. 

Gifts: Mages have a broad range of powers to call upon; 
using Gifts to approximate mage magick is problematic at best. 
TheStoryteller would be within her rights simply to allow an 
NPC mage to accomplish a range of given effects within one 
or twoareas of expertise. These effects would have difficulties 
from 5 to 8; the effectiveness of the magick would depend on 
how many successes the mage rolled — very little with one, 


un nf SL INTI A Ue CUI A IE, 


noticeable effects with two, a fair amount with three, great 
success with four and exceptional success with five or more. 
Most magick does not inflict aggravated wounds, but fire, 
electricity, silver and a powerful attack of pure Quintessence 
will do so with three or more successes: two Health Levels per 
success over the second. Give the mage two to six dice to roll 
for this, depending on the power of the mage. 

Alternatively, simply assign the mage 10 to 15 Gifts of 
Levels One to Five. If you have Mage: The Ascension, use 
the Spheres and Arete from that book instead. 

Adept: The mage listed below is a Tradition adept of the 
Order of Hermes, accomplished in magick and possessing 
some degree of mundane skill as well. 

Character Creation: Attributes 9/6/4, Abilities 20/8/3, 
Backgrounds 10, Willpower 8, Gifts/Magick Dice Pool 12/5 

Suggested Attributes: Assume ratings of 2 in Physical 
Attributes, 3 in Social, and 4 in Mental. 

Suggested Abilities: Alertness 2, Dodge 2, Empathy 2, 
Enigmas 3, Etiquette 3, Expression 1, Linguistics 2, Melee 2, 
Occult 4, Rituals (human) 4, Subterfuge 3 

Suggested Areas of Expertise: Forces (elements), Spirit 
(like Garou spirit Gifts) 

Equipment: Elegant Clothing (in vaguely archaic style), 
Ritual Accessories, Cold Iron Sword 

Most mages have skilled compatriots or followers of 
some sort. 


Wraiths 


Wraiths are dark shadows that dwell in forgotten places. 
Many Garou have sensed these creatures on the edges of their 
keen awareness. They are spirits, but notofthesort with which 
Garouare familiar; rather, they are spirits of the restless dead, 
and dwell in an Umbra all their own. Indeed, few Garou Gifts 
allow interaction with these spectral creatures; Spirit Speech 
and Sense the Unnatural have been used from time to time 
with varying effect, while the Rite of Summoning, Rite of 
Binding, Command Spirit and Call to Duty all fail. It is said 
that the Silent Striders understand wraiths’ true nature — 
indeed, it is said that the tribe's elders possess arcane knowl- 
edge about wraiths and can enter the dark, gloomy, 
fog-enshrouded Umbra in which they dwell. It is also said that 
some Hellholes connect to the dark Underworld and that 
some, ifnotall, wraiths are allied with the pawns ofthe Wyrm. 
Some Black Spiral Dancers have spoken of the Darkness and 
their ability to wander its fog-enshrouded depths. 

Wraithsdonotenterthe Living Umbra; they are unable toexist 
there, so Garou know them only by their infrequent manifesta- 
tions on Earth. Wraiths are definitely not spirits of Gaia, but hold 
many secrets of far Realms. At times they seem to be confused and 
quiet; at others, manic and demanding. 

Wraiths will often be found guardinga specific place, usually an 
abandoned area such as an old warehouse or rundown pool hall. 
Bone Gnawers often know of “haunted” sites. 

Theurges warn that these beings from beyond have powers 
that allow them to invade one’s soul and take control of one’s 
body. The Uktena believe they can be repelled by simple use 
of a salt water ward and windchimes. 

So far, no Garou has seen his Garou ancestor manifest as a 
wraith. Indeed, many point to the existence of Past Lives as proof 
that Garou ancestors retire to a common resting place. 

Wraiths can be used by Storytellers to add an element ofhorror 
to their Werewolf games. They often have things to say to 
werewolves and will try to get them to perform various small 
requests. Not all are of the Wyrm, although they certainly seem 
that way: many are grateful for whatever small quests they can get 
a Garou to perform. Some wraiths are initially affected by the 
Delirium, although they quickly become immune toit. A fewhave 
been known to incite Garou to frenzy. 

The Traits below are fora wraith that has manifested in the 
physical world. 

Attributes: 6/4/2, Abilities: 10/6/2, Health Levels: 7, 
Gnosis 5, Rage 8, Willpower 8 

Powers: Possession (2 Gnosis points cost; roll wraith’s 
Willpower versus target’s Willpower; difficulty is the target’s 
Intelligence + 3). Each success drains a Willpower point. 
When the Garou’s temporary Willpower is gone, the Garou 
becomes possessed. The Rite of Cleansing has been known 
to force a wraith out of a Garou or human body. 

Shadow Body: Wraiths are not harmed by normal weap- 
ons. A fetish weapon, such as a klaive, will damage them. 
When a wraith has no more Health Levels, it vanishes, 
temporarily destroyed. No one knows precisely how long it 


Appendix 


POL PS LT TR a 


takes wraiths to reform in the Underworld, but they invari- 
ably return to wreak vengeance on those who banish them. 


Changelings (Faeries) 


Long-time allies and friends of the Fianna, faeries are 
mostly gone from this world. During the early days of the 
Inquisition, most faeries departed for their homeland in the 
Deep Umbra, leaving behind only the ancient Trods they 
used to bridge the worlds. However, many faeries stayed 
behind in this world, and as the Gauntlet grew thick, they 
forgot who they were and became increasingly more mun- 
dane. Their blood became diluted with human blood, and 
soon their faerie nature was forgotten. Only a few true 
faeries escaped to ancient holdings beneath the hills (secret 
pockets in the Umbra) and retained their society. These 
last faeries called their quasi-mortal kin “changelings,” 
after the ancient practice of substituting faeries for human 
babies. The true faeries tried to help these half-kin when- 
ever possible, but the Trods to Arcadia were blocked, the 
bawn of the Summerlands was raised, and the Gauntlet 
prevented escape from the harsh reality of Earth. 

The Garou know many of these faeries and empathize 
with them; they too have been edged out of their traditional 
homes and wild forests. 

The Sidhe of Earth are changing and will not speak to 
the Garou of these changes. Several changelings have 
begun attempting to find ways to reenter Arcadia, and 
many Garou have been employed in their quests to do so. 

Below are some basic Traits for a changeling: 

Attributes: 7/5/3, Abilities: 13/9/5, Health Levels: 7, 
Gnosis 8, Rage 3, Willpower 5 

Powers: Faeries have powers based on their associations 
with various concepts and potentials. For example, a faerie 
allied with Winter would have powers of cold, snow, and 
ice, but would also be able to call forth the powers of Night, 
Stars, and the Wind because these are related concepts. 

Faeries usually appear as young, adolescent, or elderly 
humans. They are noble, powerful, and unearthly. 


Spirits 
The gods are here, if they are anywhere at all in the world. 
— Algernon Blackwood, “The Willows” 
Below are some examples of the spirits Garou often 


encounter, whether friendly or hostile. The Storyteller is 
free to create any spirit not detailed. 


Pack Totems 


The process of allying with, or “adopting,” a totem is 
more like that of a parent adopting a child than two friends 
devoting themselves to each other. The totem feels a tie to 
the Garou and speaks of those Garou who choose it as its 
"Children." The actual spirit that attends the Children is a 
Jaggling representative called a totem avatar. 


259 


Generally, a totem spirit is an Incarna. Totem spirits are 
usually animal spirits, but can be mythological creatures, 
elemental forces, or other kinds of spirits. Animal totems are 
alsocalled Animal Fathersby lupus (see Animal Spirits, below). 
Generally, all totems fall into one of three categories: Totems 
of Respect, Totems of War, and Totems of Wisdom. 

* Totems of Respect: These are ancient spirits that have 
been associated with the greatest of the Garou. They are 
Totems of Honor. For many years they have provided 
leadership advice, diplomatic assistance, and other kinds of 
aid. They have been known to lend their iron Will to their 
Children. 

* Totems of War: These are most often predatory 
animal spirits and ancestral warriors. They are Totems of 
Rage, aiding the Garou in battle, in tactics and strategy, and 
in reconnoitering. They are perhaps a bit too bloodthirsty 
to win much lasting respect from the Garou as a whole, but 
they are helpful in times of battle. They have been known 
to lend Rage to their Children and to aid them in war. 

* Totems of Wisdom: These are wild, strange, spiritual 
totems, usually nature spirits and elemental forces. They teach 
many Garou mystics the secrets of magic, and they continue 
to aid the Theurges of the Garou. Often these totems are 
looked upon with a measure of disrespect because they are 
secretive and unpredictable. They have been known to teach 
Gifts to their Children and protect them spiritually. 


Background Costs and Traits 


The Totem Background enables characters to “purchase” a 
totem spirit affiliated with their pack. The total number of 
Background points allocated by the characters to the pack 
totem provides the pack with a pool of points to spend. 
However, the pack must first spend the Background Cost of 
the particular totem they select, and then provide the totem 
with otherabilities. For more information, see Totem, pg. 113. 

All Traits granted by totems are granted on a per-turn basis, 
and to only one pack member at a time (except for Renown), 
unless stated otherwise. Traits may be “passed” back and forth 
among pack members; the current power-wielder designates 
the next receiver. All Attribute or Ability bonuses add to the 
pack member's Dice Pool for that Trait, even if the pack 
member normally has no dots in that Trait. All Renown 
bonuses and penalties apply immediately upon the pack's 
choosing the totem, unless otherwise stated. 

Each totem has a Ban, a rule or rules its Children must 
followtoremain in the totem’s favor. Garou who do not follow 
the Ban will find themselves cut off from their pack totem and 
will have to undergo a Rite of Contrition to regain its favor. It 
is possible that a totem will totally abandon a pack that 
continually violates its wishes. 

Pack totems, as with other spirits allied to the Garou, can 
teach Gifts to their Children. The types of Gifts they teach 
relate to their affiliations and powers. 

Below are lists of available totems and their affiliations. 
Many of these totems are also tribal totems. Members of a 


260 


tribe allied to that totem do not gain the Traits listed with 
each totem; these bonuses apply only to those packs allied 
to an avatar of that totem. Tribes instead benefit through 
the imparted wisdom and patronage of the totem: their 
tribal Gifts were first taught to them by their totem. 


Totems of Respect 


Falcon 


Background Cost: 5 

Noble and brave, Falcon soars high and leads all Garou. 
Falcon helps the Garou to be strong through his insight into 
their hearts. The Silver Fangs are served by Falcon, who 
helps them maintain communication and thus unity. Fal- 
con is a highly respected totem, although, because of the 
rumors about the Silver Fangs’ failings, perhaps not as 
respected as he once was. 

Traits: Packs chosen by Falcon can call upon four 
Willpower points per story, and gain +3 to a Leadership 
Dice Pool. Each pack member’s Honor rating increases by 
one. Silver Fangs often look upon packs of Falcon as being 
noble, although some will scoff and consider them poseurs. 

Ban: Children of Falcon can never allow themselves to 
lose permanent Honor. If they do, it is expected that they 
will right this discrepancy or perform the Rite of Contrition 
and atone by throwing themselves into an impossible battle 
with a minion of the Wyrm, thus effectively committing 
suicide. 


Grandfather Thunder 


Background Cost: 7 

“Thunder rules with a fist of Iron and a voice of Silk,” is 
the ancient adage. Thunder is more feared than respected, 
yet his place among the Totems of Respect is secure. His 
Stormcrows have eyes everywhere, and he rarely chooses a 
pack on his own. Instead of relegating a totem avatar to the 
pack, he sends one of his Stormcrows to tend to his 
Children. Thunder teaches patience, ingenuity, subtlety 
and strategy to those he chooses. 

Traits: Packs chosen by Thunder can call upon an extra 
five Willpower points per story, and gain +3 toan Etiquette 
Dice Pool. Very few people will trust them, but pack 
members can gain +2 to an Intimidation Dice Pool by 
invoking Thunder. Each pack member gains one point of 
Honor. Shadow Lords will want to know what packs of 
Grandfather Thunder are doing at all times. 

Ban: Children of Thunder usually do not tell the truth 
to those they do not respect. They never respect those 
whom they dominate. 


Pegasus 


Background Cost: 4 

Although this totem is associated with the Black Furies, 
it is also known for the power in its wings and the nobility 
it exudes. Pegasus is chiefly concerned with sacred places, 


Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


POL EN LT TR a A 


ever seeking to protect them. Because of the feud between 
the Get of Fenris and the Black Furies, Pegasus will not 
adopt a pack that has a Get in it. Pegasus is often repre- 
sented as a black, winged horse with fiery eyes. It controls 
the element of Air and can teach its Children Gifts associ- 
ated with travel and air. 

Traits: Packs chosen by Pegasus can call upon an extra 
three Willpower points per story, and gain +3 to an Animal 
Ken Dice Pool. Each pack member gains two points of 
Honor. Black Furies will always be well disposed toward 
them. 

Ban: Children of Pegasus must always aid females of all 
species, especially young females. 


Stag 


Background Cost: 4 

The master of the Wild Hunt, Great Stag is the represen- 
tation of the wild, masculine power of nature. He is an 
ancient totem, older than the Garou, and represents one of 
the fundamental aspects of life. He taught the Garou their 
affinity with nature and was perhaps instrumental in end- 
ing the Impergium; he is associated with virility as well. 
Stag will occasionally appear to lost Garou, leading them 
out of danger or aiding them in a crisis. 

Traits: Packs chosen by Stag can call upon an extra 
three Willpower points per story, and gain +3 toa Survival 
Dice Pool. Each pack member gains three points of Honor.

Fianna will always be well disposed toward them, as will 
faeries. 

Ban: Children of Stag must always aid faeries or their 
kin. 


Totems of War 
Bear 


Background Cost: 5 

Great Bear is a fierce warrior but very wise in peacetime. 
He is the ancient healer and ritemaster, old and wise in the 
ways of Gaia’s Vale (the Earth). He is viewed unfavorably 
by the Garou, however, because they distrust his true 
children, the Gurahl (werebears). 

Traits: Children of Bear gain +3 to a Medicine Dice 
Pool and the ability to hibernate for up to three months at 
a time without need for food or drink. Each pack member's 
Strength Attribute is permanently raised by one, and each 
pack member may use the Gift: Mother's Touch once per 
day. 

However, all members of a pack that has chosen Bear 
lose five temporary Honor points (if they have any) and 
must subtract one from any temporary Honor rewards they 
receive, thus making it harder for them to rise in Honor. 
Werebears look favorably upon Garou with this totem, as 
do certain native peoples. 


Ban: Bear asks nothing of his Garou children, for he 
knows that they already give him much simply by affiliating 
themselves with him. 


Coyote 


Background Cost: 7 

Coyote is the trickster. He is wild, unpredictable, the 
outlaw. He is the shadow in the woods. He is the root that 
tripseven themightiestof wolveson the run. Coyote's howl 
pierces the moon and calls Her down to dance. He is a great 
warrior, a master of deception and skullduggery. 

Traits: Coyote gives his Children +3 to a Stealth Dice 
Pool, +1 Survival, +3 Streetwise, and +1 Subterfuge. He 
always has the ability to find his pack wherever they are, 
automatically (this extra ability doesn't have to be pur- 
chased separately). 

However, the Garou do not see him as an especially wise 
totem. Each pack member subtracts one from any tempo- 
rary Wisdom rewards received. The pack is constantly 
blamed for problems and troubles, whether or not it is at 
fault. Coyote is quite a powerful totem to have, but very 
difficult. Boredom, however, will never bea problem for the 
pack. 

Ban: Coyote does not limit his Children. 


Fenris 


Background Cost: 5 

Fenris was known to the Norse of old, for he was their 
dreaded Wolf-God. The legends do not stray far; Fenris is 
bloodthirsty, powerful and strong. He expects no quarter 
and gives none. His is the warrior way. He chooses only 
warlike packs. 

Traits: Fenris’ patronage provides a pack with one 
additional point ina Physical Attribute (Dexterity, Strength, 
or Stamina — individual pack members choose), even if it 
increases the Attribute over 5. Each pack member gains 
two points of Glory. Get of Fenris will respect the pack a 
little more and will constantly invite its members on wild, 
frenzied hunts. 

Ban: Fenris requires that his Children never pass up the 
opportunity for a fight. 

Griffin 

Background Cost: 4 

Hungry, continually hungry, Griffin murders with light- 
ning claws and feasts on his fallen foes. He guards the 
wilderness against human encroachment and represents 
the most primal and animalistic powers. 

Traits: Griffin is a swift hunter and grants +3 to an 
Alertness Dice Pool. In addition, each pack member can 
communicate directly with all birds of prey without the 
need of a special Gift. Each pack member gains two points 


of Glory. Red Talons recognize Griffin devotees as kindred 
souls. 


262 


Ban: Griffin requires that his children not associate with 
humans and will only very rarely allow a Garou of the 


homid breed to be his Child. 


Rat 


Background Cost: 5 

Silent, quick and crafty, Rat is a master of guerrilla 
warfare, survival, and camouflage, and knows well the truth 
of the old adage, "Safety in numbers." Rat has taught many 
Garou these virtues and is quite violent himself when 
cornered. 

Traits: Packs chosen by Rat can call upon five Will- 
power points per story, and are taught how best to bite a foe, 
subtracting one from the difficulties of all rolls to bite. Rat 
Children also subtract one from the difficulties of all rolls 
to be stealthy or quiet. Each pack member gains one point 
of Wisdom. Bone Gnawers will aid Children of the Rat as 
best they can, but will generally not risk their own lives for 
them. 

Ban: Rat asks that his Children never kill vermin. 


Wendigo 


Background Cost: 7 

Wendigo is the beast of the snow and ice, the marauder 
of the frozen northern lands. It is a cannibal spirit, devour- 
ing the hearts of its foes, but it is too much of the Wyld to 
be tainted by the Wyrm. Wendigo teaches the Garou how 
to use the wild tactics of the storm in battle. It also teaches 
them to harness the cold bitterness within them, turning it 
into murderous rage. 

Traits: Each pack member gains five Rage points per 
story, regardless of actual Rage rating; thus, Children of the 
Wendigo can have more Rage points to spend than their 
ratings may allow. Each pack member also gains two points 
of Glory. The Wendigo tribe does not automatically trust 
Children of the Wendigo; it is often too wild and unpredict- 
able for sound judgment. 

Ban: Wendigo asks that its Children always aid native 
peoples when they are in trouble. 


Totems of Wisdom 


Chimera 


Background Cost: 5 

Chimera is She of Many Faces, the Lady of Mirrors, the 
Ever-Changing. She is the mysterious caretaker of dreams, 
and is thus the mistress of Enigmas and inner wisdom. 

Traits: Chimera gives her Children the ability to dis- 
guise themselves as something or someone else when in the 
Umbra (roll Gnosis; difficulty 7). The pack gains *3 to an 
Enigmas Dice Pool and +1 to Perception. Each pack mem- 
ber subtracts two from all difficulties involving riddles, 
Enigmas, finding things or interpreting dreams. Each pack 
member gains two points of Wisdom. Stargazers will notice

their opinion of them. 

Ban: Chimera does not limit her Children, but will not

Cockroach 


Background Cost: 6 

Cockroach is quick, hardy, and incredibly adaptable. 
Though ancient beyond measure, it is a totem of the 
modern age. Its kin scuttle through every corner ofthecity, 
infiltrating any nook and cranny. 

Traits: Cockroach’s Spawn gain the ability to Peek from 
the Umbra into datastreams and through electrical con-

a Gnosis roll, and view data that is stored on media or 
streaming through a computer cable. Each pack member 
favored by Cockroach subtracts two from all difficulties 
involving computers, electricity, and science (including 
Repair). They gain *3 toany rolls to activate Gifts affecting 
technology. 

Ban: Cockroach asks that all of its kin be spared by the 
pack. 


(Dana 


Background Cost: 8 

Dana is a powerful totem of the ancient Celts. Often 
thought to be a faerie spirit, Dana is actually the spirit of an 
ancient wise woman. Dana isa very hard totem to reach and 
thus does not often reveal herself to the Garou. In fact, not 
many Garou know of her. 

Traits: Dana grants her Children Second Sight, giving 
them the Gift: Pulse of the Invisible. Her packs gain the 
ability to entrance listeners through singing or howling 
(Manipulation * Performance; difficulty 8); the actual 
effects are up to the Storyteller. In addition, the pack gains 
Past Life 3; this is not an actual affinity with Garou 
ancestors, but an ability to learn ancient knowledge and 
lore by accessing primal memories. All Fianna and faeries 
will recognize and honor Children of Dana. 

Ban: Dana asks that her Children hold a moot in her 
honor on the solstices and the equinoxes. 


Owl 


Background Cost: 6 

Owl is silent and swift. In the night, Owl rules. He 
represents secret and hoary wisdom culled from the deepest 
recesses of the night. Owl is also associated with the secrets 
of death and the Dark Umbra; certain Native American 
tribes believed owls to be avenging ghosts. 

Traits: Owl lends quiet aid to his Children, often gifting 
them with premonitions of danger and leading them to 
forgotten mystic places (Storyteller’s discretion). Owl gives 
wings to each of his Children when they enter the Umbra, 
allowing them to fly from place to place. Owl’s Children 
subtract two from all difficulties involving stealth, silence,

Each pack member gains two points of Wisdom. Silent 
Striders will often appear seemingly out of nowhere to aid 
the pack when it is in danger. Children of the Rat do not get 
along well with Children of the Owl, as their totems are 
constantly in conflict. 

Ban: Owl asks that his pack leave animal sacrifices for 
him in the woods, in the form of small vermin that are tied

Uktena 


Background Cost: 6 

Uktena is a dark, powerful, and ancient water spirit with 
the features of a serpent and a cougar. Few spirits know and 
understand as many occult secrets as Uktena. 

Traits: Uktena surrounds each.of its Children with a 
protective ward when they are in the Umbra; this adds 
three dice to their soak rolls. Each pack member favored by 
Uktena is taught secret lore and knowledge, gaining two 
extra experience points per story that may only be applied 
to learning Enigmas, Occult, Rituals, Gifts, or other mysti- 
cal knowledge. 

The pack's association with Uktena is distrusted by 
other Garou; Social roll difficulties are increased by one 
when interacting with other Garou (except, naturally, 
Uktena Garou). Each pack member gains two points of

Wisdom. Garou of the Uktena tribe will treat the pack as

Ban: Uktena asks that its children recover mystical lore,
