Unicorn 


Background Cost: 7 

Unicorn is pure, powerful, strong and wise. She is a 
totem of peace, of harmony, and of healing. She represents 
the pure understanding and unbridled love of Gaia, and she 
extends this bliss to her Children. 

Traits: Unicorn's Children gain her swiftness in the 
Umbra, moving at twice normal speed across the shadowy 
landscape. Children of the Unicorn subtract two from all 
difficulties involving healing and empathy, but add two to 
all difficulties to harm or injure other Garou (at least those 
not of the Wyrm). They gain three additional dice when 
using Gifts involving peace, healing, strength and protec- 
tion. Each pack member gains three points of Wisdom. 
Children of Gaia will always give aid and will usually side 
with the pack in any disputes. 

Ban: Unicorn asks that her Children continually aid and 
protect the weak, the helpless, the abused and the ex- 
ploited, but not to the extent of furthering or aiding the 
Wyrm. 

There are many other totems, but the above are the ones 
most friendly and familiar to the Garou. 


Maturae 


These nature-spirits of the wilds are found most often in 
Glens, the places within the Umbra where they spawn. 
Many naturae are the spirits of dead and departed animals, 
while others are generated from the special significance or 
beauty of a particular spot. 

In the days when Gaia's Garden stretched across most of 
the Near Umbra, all rivers and trees may have had spirits. 
Now the Umbra is largely barren, and only a few such places 
have spirits. 


Animal Spirits 

Garou often interact with the spirits of animals, whether 
to learn Gifts from them or to appease them after hunting 
their kind for food. Animal spirits are similar to their 
physical counterparts, but they usually have a power they 
can teach to Garou — for example, a vole who can teach a 
Garou to burrow ora rabbit who can teach a Garou to leap. 
See Gifts, pp. 114-137, for more information on which 
particular animal spirits teach Gifts. 

The sheer variety of animal spirits prevents categoriza- 
tion, and the Garou believe many spirits have existed and 
disappeared along with their extinct animal counterparts. 
Garou believe that all Jaggling and Gaffling animal spirits

are allied to their patron Totem Incarna, whom the lupus 
call Animal Fathers. The Animal Fathers, so say the lupus, 
regulate the earthly populations of animals. If they are 
slighted or insulted, they will prevent new births of their 
kin into the harsh world. This can be disastrous for wolves 
if the slighted Incarna is Caribou or Deer; depletion of these 
herds would cause starvation among the few wolves left in 
the world. The Animal Fathers are said to live in lodges 
somewhere in the Near Umbra.

Glade Child 


Glade Children are tree spirits, the true souls of trees. 
They maintain the physical form of the tree, but in the 
Umbra they can be seen as luminescent figures, draped in 
robes, asleep within the tree. Their kind and wise faces keep 


| 


cm ed IR 


a careful vigil over their surroundings, and their green eyes 
watch all who pass by. 

The spiritual form of a Glade Child depends primarily on 
the physical location of its tree. If it is beside a busy 
highway, the spirit-tree will be grimy with the Blight, and 
perhaps Pattern Webs will be spun among its branches. In 
the wild the spirit appears magnificent and majestic. 

Glade Children possess a wealth of knowledge about the 
area within their sight; they will sometimes impart their 
wisdom to friendly Garou. However, the closer a tree is to 
the Blight, and the farther it has been woven into the sterile 
Pattern Web, the more warped its perception becomes, 
resulting in less reliable and sometimes misleading infor- 
mation. 

Glade Children are usually Gafflings or Jagglings, al- 
though some extremely old or powerful ones may be Incarna 
(these are usually associated with ancient trees and are 
called Oak Kings). 

Willpower 7, Rage 3, Gnosis 8, Power: variable (20 fora 
sapling, 80+ for an ancient redwood) 

Charms: Airt Sense, Cleanse the Blight, Forest Sense 


Lune 


Lunes are Jagglings of Luna. They appear as shimmering 
ribbons of light surrounded by auras of gold and blue. Great 
friends of Garou, they communicate empathically, undu- 
lating into various forms as they silently commune with 
another spirit. This motion becomes increasingly unstable 
as the moon waxes. The demeanors of Lunes change dra- 
matically depending on the phase of the Moon. Like their 
mistress, they are susceptible to lunar madness during the 
full moon. 

Lunes have the power to open any Moon Bridge at will, 
should they so desire. They sometimes perform this service 
to Garou who successfully petition them — a taxing task. 
However, should the Lune be suffering from madness, there 
is no guarantee the spirit will send the traveler where she 
wishes to go. 

Willpower 8, Rage 4 (8 during the full moon), Gnosis 7, 
Power 35 

Charms: Airt Sense, Open Moon Bridge (Cost 5), 
Reform 


Stormcrows 


Stormcrows are the spirit servants of Grandfather Thun- 
der, totem of the Shadow Lords. They are most often 
Jagglings, although they can also appear as pack totem 
avatars. They are connected to Thunder at all times, for 
they are his eyes and ears. 

Willpower 9, Rage 7, Gnosis 6, Power 35 

Charms: Airt Sense, Create Wind, Tracking 


The Wendigo 


The avatar of great Wendigo itself, this creature appears 
as a twisted humanoid with blue skin, claws and fangs,

blazing eyes, and black, hooflike stumps in place of feet. 
The Wendigo can run at up to 50 mph through the sky. The 
Wendigo is occasionally called by Garou on missions of 
vengeance; it will track its prey, rip it apart, and eat its 
heart. It may be summoned with the Wendigo Gift: Call 
the Cannibal Spirit. 

Willpower 7, Rage 10, Gnosis 3, Power 45

The Wild Hunt 


The manifestation of Stag’s vengeance, the Hunt is 
occasionally called by the Fianna against the worst of the 
Wyrm's menaces. This is very dangerous, however, for the 
Hunt is a personification of the Garou's rage and fury, and 
those who participate in the scourge may well be consumed 
by it. 

The Hunt iscomposed of raw spiritual energy. If "killed," 
it will merely dissipate into the Umbra once more, to 
reappear if called later. 

* The Huntsman: The Huntsman appears as a stag- 
antlered man with a pack of hounds. The Huntsman is a

Ancestor-Spirits 


Garou maintain connections to those who came before 
them, even beyond the veil of death. Garou believe their 
forefathers and mothers still exist in the spirit world, ready 
to aid their descendants with wisdom or battle prowess. A 
Garou with the Past Life Background can actually call upon 
his ancestors to possess him and act with him in the here 
and now. These Ancestor-spirits can often be found in the 
13 Near Realms in the Umbra (see Chapter Seven: The 
Spirit World). 

There is a controversy among Theurges as to the true 
nature of these spirits; some believe they are the actual 
spirits of the dead, while others argue that they are simply 
shadows, ephemera wrapped about memories, and that the 
true spirits reside in Gaia’s Womb, waiting to be reborn. 
Most Garou believe both of these arguments: that the dead 
leave something of themselves behind to aid their breth- 
ren, though their true selves return to Gaia. 

Sometimes, human ancestor spirits can be encountered, 
especially those of Kinfolk shamans. These spirits can 
sometimes be called upon to teach homid breed Gifts. 

Ancestor-spirits vary greatly in powers and abilities, 
depending on their power before death. The following is a 
sample Garou spirit: 

Willpower 6, Rage 8, Gnosis 7, Power 30 

Charms: Per their tribal Gifts. Children of Gaia might 
have the Healing Charm, while Glass Walkers might have 
Charms similar to an electricity elemental. 


Elementals 


These spirits are the manifestations of the elements — 
the building blocks of Gaia and all life. In recent years, the 
classical concept of the four elements of air, fire, earth and 
water has been replaced by the discovery of a multitude of 
different elementals. Indeed, in the urban domains, spirits 
of glass, metal and plastic have been contacted by certain 
Glass Walkers. The power level of elementals ranges; some 
are no more than Gafflings, while others are as powerful as 
any Incarna. The following are examples of minor elementals 
that might be contacted by Garou Theurges. 


Air Elemental 


Willpower 3, Rage 8, Gnosis 7, Power 40 
Charms: Airt Sense, Create Wind, Reform, Updraft

Charms: Airt Sense, Blast Flame, Create Fires

Atomic Spirits 

These are spirits that dance in the atomic fires. They are 
not radiation (that is of the Wyrm), but raw reaction. They 
do, however, understand much of the Wyrm and the basic 
structure of the universe, for they existed at the Beginning 
of All Things. They are occasionally consulted by Glass 
Walkers, and an atomic spirit will answer the queries of 
mortals, but only if they help it “advance” — often by 
detonating the cyclotron in which it is trapped. 

Willpower 10, Rage 5, Gnosis 10, Power 40+ (up to 1000 
at ground zero of a 100-megaton strike) 

Charms: Airt Sense, Break Reality, Materialize, Re- 
form, Solidify Reality 

Atomic Blast: The spirit can inflict damage as a bio- 
chemical attack. The Power cost is three per die of damage. 


Enigmatic Spirits 


Many spirits are inscrutable even to Garou. These are 
most often full-time residents of the Umbra, having no 
animal, plant or elemental equivalent in the physical 
world, and thus no common frame of reference by which 
they can be understood. Nonetheless, the Garou have 
allied with certain enigmatic spirits and gained much from 
the relationship. 


Chimerlings 


Chimerlings are Jagglings of the totem Chimera. They 
are mysterious wisps of ephemera given sentience; they live 
at the ends of dreamquests and embody Enigmas. Like their 
patron, they are amorphous and malleable, taking the wispy 
shape of this or that thing as they choose. They often teach 
enigmatic Gifts to Garou. They sometimes appear to Garou 


Appendix 


in dreams to impart strange messages, which are rarely 
understood. 

Willpower 3, Rage 5, Gnosis 10, Power 35 

Charms: Airt Sense, Reform, Shapeshift 
Englings 

Englings are Jagglings of Gaia and carry a part of Her 
within them. They are spirits of Gnosis, and Garou often 
ritually hunt them during moots. Once an Engling has been 
caught by the hunters, it must be ritually thanked for giving 
itself to the Garou so they may become stronger in their 
fight to defend Gaia. If the hunt is properly performed, 
Garou participants regain all their Gnosis. The Engling 
Reforms elsewhere in the Umbra. For more information on 
the hunt, see Gnosis, pg. 157. 
Willpower 5, Rage 1, Gnosis 10, Power 25 
Charms: Airt Sense 


Epiphlings 

Some spirits embody concepts or ideas, such as War, 
Death, Pain, Peace, Calm, Protection, etc. The Garou are 
not exactly sure how such spirits fit into the spirit hierarchy 
or Umbral courts. The Stargazers say that these spirits are 
pure ideas or abstract concepts filtered down from the 
Heavens (or up from the Underworld) into the middle

world, where they become mere shadows of their true 
power. Others believe they are Penumbral ephemera that 
spawn from strong emotions or ideas in the physical world. 
The Stargazers call these spirits Epiphlings, for they are 
often found near Epiph Domains. The Storyteller is free to 
create Traits for these spirits; they are almost always en- 
countered as Gafflings. Garou often bind them into fetishes. 


Wylolings 

Wyldlings are the children of the Wyld. They prefer to 
reside in the Deep Umbra, for the Pattern Web has made 
Gaia too stagnant and permanent for them. They generally 
appear as constantly shifting maelstroms of matter and 
energy. 

All Wyldlings have the Charm: Break Reality. 


Dortex 


The great Vortex is one of the most powerful Wyldlings, 
and is respected and feared by spirit and Garou alike. It 
appears as a huge, cloudy implosion of energy and solid, 
liquid and gaseous matter, always swirling and writhing. 
Vortices used to enter the physical world from time to time 
(where they feasted on the Wyld energies of magic), but 
now spend most of their time in the Deep Umbra. They are 
capricious, unpredictable and totally alien. 

As a Vortex comprises all things, all of its attacks do 
aggravated damage. 

Willpower 8, Rage 8, Gnosis 10, Power 80 

Charms: Airt Sense, Break Reality, Disorient, Material- 
ize, Reform, Shapeshift 


Lesser Wyldling 


While not so powerful as the Vortex, Lesser Wyldlings 
are nonetheless extremely dangerous spirits. They appear as 
shifting, hazy patterns. They will sometimes act as spirit 
guides, but are not to be trusted. 

Willpower 4, Rage 7, Gnosis 6, Power 40 

Charms: Airt Sense, Break Reality, Materialize, 
Shapeshift 


Weaver Spirits 


Weaver spirits are the myriad spawn of the Weaver. 
They inhabit the labyrinthine branches of the Pattern 
Web. Most Weaver spirits appears as spiders or strange 
geometric patterns. 

All Weaver spirits have the Charm: Solidify Reality. 


Pattern Spider 


Pattern Spiders are the most common and numerous 
servants of the Weaver. They ceaselessly spin the Pattern 
Web. Though primarily workers, Pattern Spiders can also 
attack those who violate the tenets of the Weaver, calcify- 
ing them into the Web for all eternity. 


Willpower 6, Rage 4, Gnosis 6, Power 25 
Charms: Calcify, Solidify Reality 


Net-Spider 

Wondrous things can be created when the Weaver and 
Wyld merge, an all-too-rare occurrence these days. Virtual 
reality is one such recent occurrence. There is a spiritual 
aspect to this new reality, a heart of the Wyld within the 
deepest reaches of the Pattern Web. Within this Umbral 
computer realm reside the Net-Spiders, tending the grow- 
ing mass of information. 

Net-Spiders are capable of discovering details about any 
and all data that is held on-line. Net-Spiders can travel 
only along phone lines or computer cables, and can be 
blocked by security programming (which is itself often a 
Net-Spider). 

Net-Spiders are used by Glass Walkers to recover infor- 
mation about institutions and corporations. They appear as 
small spiders floating atop strange fractal patterns of en- 
ergy. They are exceedingly useful in pirating data. All 
Net-Spider actions are half difficulty and cost when they 
relate to electronics and computers. 

Willpower 8, Rage 4, Gnosis 9, Power 40 

Charms: Airt Sense, Reform, Solidify Reality, Spirit 
Static 


Banes are the vile spirit minions of the Wyrm. They 
assume countless forms, for destruction takes many shapes 
throughout reality. Certain Banes are avatars or personifi- 
cations of principles such as hate and disease; others are 
simply random demonic entities. Banes are perhaps the 
greatest enemies of the Garou. 

All Banes are lost to the Wyrm, and destruction is the 
only sure way to rid an area of their influence. Even then it 
may be too late, for their dark emotions may have infected 
nearby humans. These emotions fester and grow, eventu- 
ally becoming strong enough to project a Blight in the 
Umbra. This often happens when groups of evil and corrupt 
people gather, thus allowing a Bane to manifest and feed 
from the cold hearts of those gathered. 

Banes, when in true form, are horrifying, and often cause 
an effect similar to the Delirium in humans. 

Most Banes have the Possession Charm. Banes also tend 
to have a specific power, or powers, based around the 
emotion or force they characterize. These powers can range 
from basic emotion control, to the ability to remove the 
Delirium from humans (allowing them to face Garou), to 
the ability to spread living corruption throughout the 
reality of a Realm. 


Storytellers should feel free to let their imaginations run 
free when creating Banes, so long as their powers reflect the 
forces they represent. These powers often require "activa- 
tion," which can be achieved by an expenditure of Power or 
by making success rolls based on Gnosis. Many Banes have 
powers of corruption or mutation, and Garou who fight 
these creatures risk their bodies and souls. 

The Storyteller should avoid letting Banes take the 
blame for every form of human evil. Banes simply magnify 
and parasitize the evil and corruption already inherent to a 
person's soul; they are not attracted to anyone who is not 
yet ready to come to the Wyrm. For this reason, Banes find 
it easiest to possess already deranged or corrupt souls. 

The Banes listed here are a scant few of the Banes that 
infect the Tellurian. Storytellers should feel free to create 
their own Banes, using those given here as guidelines. 


@light Chilo 


A Blight Child was once a Glade Child (see above), but 
has become corrupted and warped by the Blight. Such 
spirits are highly malevolent and dangerous to Garou, 
discarding their once valuable friendship for hate. 

Trees within the Blight take on wiry and gaunt appear- 
ances, and the humanoid spirits are nightmarish, with 
tattered robes and faces of rotting wood. Insect spirits 
burrow in and out of their bodies, causing them constant 
pain. 


Blight Children roam the Blight, seeking to spread their 
corruption. 


Willpower 6, Rage 8, Gnosis 4, Power 20 
Charms: Blighted Touch 


Kalus 


A Kalus is the spiritual manifestation of evil thoughts. 
These spirits roam the Blighted parts ofthe Penumbra, search- 
ingfor humans who can be easily corrupted. Once a Kalus has 
found such a victim, it latches onto the target’s mind and 
begins to suggest evil ideas and deeds to the target. 

The Kalus has no physical manifestation, but often 
appears in the target's dreams as a shadowy phantasm 
around 18 inches tall, with wings, tiny clawed hands and 
cloven hooves. If threatened, the Kalus will flee from the 
area, only to return again when it is safe. 

This purely malevolent spirit serves no other purpose 
save forcing one person to inflict misery upon others. A 
victim need only think some "bad thought" accidentally; 
this is fodder enough for the Kalus, who can turn one 
friendly and compassionate being against her family and 
friends. 

Willpower 5, Rage 3, Gnosis 7, Power 15 

Charms: Corruption 


Nexus Crawler 


Few minions of the Wyrm are as feared as the dread Nexus 
Crawlers. From whence they came is unknown, but it was 
definitely not from our continuum, for their presence causes 
reality to ooze and run like melted wax. In their natural state 


——— 


they are undetectable save for a black shimmering in the air; 
awarbling, vibrato drone; anda feeling on the skin like ground 
glass or nails scraped across a chalkboard. However, they are 
able to use their considerable store of Power to generate all 
manner of loathsome avatars. 

Nexus Crawlers have sentience of a sort, but they are 
very alien, and even other Wyrm minions are uncomfort- 
able around them. Their actions in combat rarely smack of 
rationality, and they do not often employ "logical" tactics. 

A Nexus Crawler may, after Materializing, spend one 
Power point to create a truly vile body — mortals will run 
screaming in terror, and even Garou must make a Will- 
power roll or fly into a Fox frenzy. Extra Power spent when 
Materializing allows the Crawler to form all sorts of gro- 
tesque appendages and weaponry — extra mouths, grasping 
arms, etc. 

Their most feared power, however, is the ability to warp 
reality (see below). 

Crawlers exist in the Umbra and may be defeated nor- 
mally. All of the Crawler's entropic effects (except damage 
sustained and other instantaneous effects) vanish when the 
Crawler is banished or destroyed. 

Willpower 6, Rage 10, Gnosis 10, Power 60 

Charms: Airt Sense, Materialize, Reform 


Warp Reality: Nexus Crawlers are beasts of raw entropy 
and may alter reality by spending Power. For one point, 
Crawlers may cause a minor shift in the reality paradigm — 
they may create a blurry and distorted illusion, cause a 
normal fire to light, change the facial features of an indi- 
vidual, or drop the temperature in a localized area. 


For three points, a Crawler may cause more serious 
changes — turning a stone floor viscous, changing a steel 
weapon to silver, changing the sweat of a foe to sulfuric 
acid, creating a sharp, clear illusion that affects sight and 
sound, or darkening an area to pitch night. The Crawler 
may also damage foes with blasts of raw entropic force — 
the damage is three dice, and the Crawler must make an 
attack roll based on its Willpower. 

For five points, a Crawler may cause truly spectacular 
effects: turning a person's bones to jelly, changing the air to 
carbon monoxide, removing a Garou's entire face (and all 
sensory organs), creating an illusion that affects all senses, 
altering the entire floor of a room to silver. At this level, 
damaging effects from the Crawler cause six dice of damage. 

Cost Effect 


1 Minor 
3 Serious; can do three damage dice with a Will- 
power roll 


5 Spectacular; can do six damage dice with a Will- 
power roll 


Psychomachiae 


Psychomachiae are dark spirits that feed on fear and life 
force. These entities possess disturbed individuals, corrupt- 
ingthem intopsychotic serial killers. Physical manifestations 
of these spirits can be very horrible, with razors, fangs, or 
other instruments of torture and death. 

Willpower 7, Rage 10, Gnosis 8, Power 20 (+10 per 
death inflicted by its host) 

Charms: Airt Sense, Materialize, Possession 


Scrag 


Scrags are one of the many warrior Bane races that serve 
the Wyrm. Within the Umbra they appear as semi-physi- 
cal, almost incorporeal ghoulish spirits with razor-sharp 
claws and fangs. Scrags do not walk upright, but slouch in 
a nearly quadrupedal position; this does not seem to affect 
their speed of movement within the Umbra. 

Scrags are killers, without mercy orremorse. They live to 
kill, reveling in the mayhem and bloodshed they cause. 
They often indulge in frenzies of killing and dismember- 
ment. Scrags travel in packs and are malevolent in the 
extreme. 

When entering the physical world (or a Realm in the 
Umbra), a Scrag must attempt a possession in order to 
manifest. The possessed being suffers extreme pain during 
the brief possession process, but then feels fine — for the 
time being. Successful possession places a dormant Scrag 


272 


within a body; the spirit will slowly attempt to take control 
of the victim. Unless an exorcism takes place, the victim 
will become a Scrag in about 48 hours. During this time the 
victim will begin to exhibit many traits of the Scrag: 
antisocial habits, bad attitudes, a short and violent temper, 
and a ravenous hunger for raw, red meat. The physical 
transformation takes effect at the end of this period. Should 
theScrag depart the body at any time, the victim will return 
to normal and must face the carnage she has caused. 

Willpower 6, Rage 10, Gnosis 4, Power 40 

Charms: Incite Frenzy, Possession 


The (Dark Trinity 


You are not like Cerberus, three gentlemen at once, are you? 
— Richard Brinsley Sheridan, The Rivals 

Within the World of Darkness there are three legendary 
Banes that work their evil in concert and have become a 
true threat to the Garou. This “pack” of malign beings is 
called the Dark Trinity. Its members are: Gorgul, the Nexus 
Crawler; Raza, the Scrag; and Fek, the Psychomachiae. 
They lurk in the Penumbra surrounding New York City, 
hatching their dark plots against unsuspecting humans, but 
they can also be found elsewhere throughout the reaches of 
the spirit world, skulking on mysterious errands. 

The Trinity's leader, if it can be said to have one, is 
Gorgul, the most powerful of the three Banes. Gorgul is 
certainly not its true name, but only a pronounceable 
approximation given it by the Garou. This cosmic horror 
seeks to destroy the source of the Garou's power in New 
York — the Central Park Caern. Its motivations cannot be 
fully fathomed, for its intelligence is alien and incompre- 
hensible. Its power to warp reality makes it a deadly 
opponent, and Garouare thankful that Gorgul spends most 
of its time in bizarre Wyrm Realms in the farthest reaches 
of the Umbra, gathering strange powers and allies. Gorgul 
isrumored to be an agent of the Eater-of-Souls aspect of the 
Wyrm. 

Next in power is Raza. This monstrous entity prowls the 
Penumbral streets seeking victims, be they spirits in the 
spirit world or humans in the physical world. Its ever- 
watchful eyes constantly Peek into the physical world, 
seeking hapless prey. Raza is the enforcer of the Dark 
Trinity, the one who performs the most dangerous combat 
tasks. While Gorgul plots and plans, Raza acts. Raza is 
rumored to be an agent of the Beast-of- War aspect of the 
Wyrm. 

Finally, there is Fek. This Psychomachiae is more pow- 
erful than any of its brethren, but is nonetheless the least of 
the Trinity (at least, so the Garou and the rest of the Trinity 
believe). However, it is most cunning and wily, and its 
powers ensure that it can hurt the Garou in ways they can 
least counter — by possessing their loved ones and driving 
them mad. Fek is perhaps the most reviled of the Trinity, 
although not the most feared. Fek is rumored to be an agent 
of the Defiler Wyrm. 


Werewolf: The Apocalypse

These beings are rumored to have their lair in a Blight 
underneath the Penumbra of the Wollman Rink. (See 
Central Park, below.) 


Gorgul 

Gorgul appears — in the Umbra or when Materialized — 
as a giant, insectoid thing with long, thin limbs and long, 
spidery fingers. It is covered in a chitinous carapace, the 
folds and whorls of which appear to shape dark runes. 

Willpower 7, Rage 10, Gnosis 10, Power 70 

Charms: Airt Sense, Materialize, Reform, Warp Reality 


Raza 


Raza is about the size of a Garou in Crinos form (eight 
feet tall). It resembles a cross between a human, a lizard and 
a predatory mammal, and is mottled with disgusting, sharp 
bristles and reptilian scales. Its fingers are razor-sharp 
blades; its eyes are swirls of glowing light. Its limbs and torso 
appear tattered (scars from previous battles). Like the rest 
of its kind, it runs on all fours. 

Willpower 7, Rage 10, Gnosis 5, Power 45 

Charms: Incite Frenzy, Possession, Tracking 


Fek 


Fekappeatsasaliuman male of indeterminate race. “He” 
is thin and looks sickly; mucus continually runs down his 
chin from his nose. His hair is long and greasy, and he 


Appendix 


appears to be wearing tattered clothes, the kind gathered 
from dumpsters. His eyes, however, are beautiful, brimming 
with compassion. This compassion, like everything else 
about Fek, is a lie — a lure for his prey. 

Willpower 7, Rage 10, Gnosis 8, Power 35 (* 10 per 
death inflicted by its host) 
Charms: Airt Sense, Materialize, Possession 


Sample Fetishes 


Below is a short list of fetishes the Storyteller may use 
within a chronicle. They are ranked by level, from one 
through five, corresponding with the Fetish Background 
Trait. Characters with this Background may choose one or 
more of these items (up to their level in the Background), 
or the Storyteller may make up one of his own. 

Storytellers are encouraged to create their own fetishes 
using the basic rules outlined in Chapter Seven: The Spirit 
World (Fetishes, pp. 184-185) and the Rites section of 
Chapter Six (Rite of the Fetish, pg. 146). However, they 
should take great care to avoid including too many fetishes 
in their stories, for these items are rare and cherished. 


Harmony Flute 


Level 1, Gnosis 5 
This small flute is made from hickory and has many small 
feathers attached to it. When activated and played (this 


273 


| 


— 20 LS PA BID IVA ATADO CUI 


requires a Performance roll), the flute emits a harmonious 
melody; all aggressive creatures who hear the song must 
make successful Rage rolls or cease fighting. If they are 
attacked, they may defend themselves, but they can initiate 
no offensive action. 


To create a Harmony Flute, one of the following spirit 
types must be bound into the hickory flute: Peace, Calm, 
Water, or Bird-spirit. 


Spirit Tracer 

Level 2, Gnosis 5 

This is a human hair suspended in an iron ingot. When 
the wielder concentrates upon a specific spirit, the ingot 
pulls in that direction. 

Tocreate a Spirit Tracer, one of the following spirit types 
must be bound into the ingot: a Hunting- or Predator-spirit, 
or one that has the Charm: Tracking. 


Baneskin 


Level 3, Gnosis 7 

This tiny piece of a Bane spirit is carefully wrapped in 
cloth and worn as an amulet. When activated, it causes all 
malevolent spirits, especially Banes, to react to the wearer 
as if she were a kindred soul — a “wolf in Bane’s clothing” 
as it were. 


Fang Dagger 

Level 3, Gnosis 6 

This dagger is carved from the tooth of some great beast. 
After the character has made a successful melee attack, he 
can activate the dagger. If successful, the damage inflicted 
is doubled as the fang “bites” deeper into the wound. The 
damage is aggravated. 

To create a Fang Dagger, one of the following spirit types 
must be bound into the tooth: War, Pain, Death, or Snake- 
spirit. 


Ohoebe's Ueil 


Level 3, Gnosis 7 

This is a small, golden pendant in the shape of a half 
moon. It is attached to a leather thong and meant to be 
worn around the neck. When the pendant is activated, the 
wearer becomes invisible to both mundane creatures and 
spirits for one minute per success scored. This works against 
all senses but touch (sight, sound, scent). 

Tocreate Phoebe's Veil, one of the following spirit types 
must be bound into the pendant: Illusion, Shadow, Hiding, 
or Chameleon-spirit. 


Sanctuary Chimes 


Level 3, Gnosis 6 

This miniature tubular bell, when activated, emits chimes 
into the wind. All spirits, unless invited to do so, may not 
Materialize within 100 feet. 

To create Sanctuary Chimes, one of the following spirit 
types must be bound into the tubular bell: Protection, 
Guardian, or Turtle-spirit. 


Klaive 

Level 4, Gnosis 6 

A klaive is a ritual dagger of the Garou. Klaives are rare 
weapons, for they are made of silver, and their manufacture 
and use are deadly to Garou. A klaive is about as big as a 
Bowie knife. A Garou who carries a klaive loses one point 
from his effective Gnosis rating (see Silver, pg. 198). A 
War-spirit is usually bound into the klaive, allowing the 
weapon to inflict aggravated damage upon non-Garou foes. 
Without the spirit, a klaive does not inflict aggravated 


damage. However, a Garou does not need to attune a klaive 
that has no spirit in it. 


Pulling a klaive on another Garou is considered a grave 
action, for a klaive duel is most often a duel to the death. 
Nonetheless, klaive duels among Garou are becoming 
increasingly common as the wilds dwindle and tribal fric- 
tion grows. 

The difficulty to attack with a klaive is 6, and it inflicts 
Strength *2 damage. Because it is a silver weapon, Garou 
may not soak this damage. 


Monkey Puzzle 


Level 4, Gnosis 6 

This talisman ofambercontainsasingle human hair. Wher 
activated, it causes all humans viewing the Garou to believ 
him a normal human, regardless of current form. However, a: 
action such as tearing out an enemy's throat will be seen as th 
act of a psychotic. 

Tocreate a Monkey Puzzle, one of the following spirit type 
must be bound into the talisman: Ghost, Illusion, or Trickste: 
Spirit Whistle 

Level 4, Gnosis 8 

This small ivory whistle, when activated and blowr 
emits a wailing scream causing immense pain to all spirit 
within the wielder's line of sight. Any spirits present must 
roll Gnosis (difficulty 6) and score a number of successes 
equal to or greater than the wielder’s successes; otherwise, 
they will flee from the scream. 

To create a Spirit Whistle, one of the following spirit 
types must be bound into the ivory whistle: Screaming, 
Madness, Discord, or Screech Owl-spirit. 


Grand Klaive 


Level 5, Gnosis 7 

These are the legendary klaives of heroes. They are as big 
as swords and, like their smaller counterparts, are made of 
silver. A Garou who carries a Grand Klaive loses two points 
from his effective Gnosis rating (see Silver, pg. 198). A 
War-spirit is usually bound into the Grand Klaive, allowing 
it to inflict aggravated damage upon non-Garou foes. With- 
out the spirit, a Grand Klaive does not inflict aggravated 
damage. However, a Garou does not need to attune a Grand 
Klaive that has no spirit in it. 


Grand Klaives are very rare and are often handed down 
by Garou lineages, especially among the Silver Fangs, 
Fianna and Shadow Lords. Besides the usual War-spirit, 
another spirit is sometimes bound into the Grand Klaive — 
for example, a Gnosis-spirit (to provide magical energy to 


the Garou), or even an Ancestor-spirit. Because these YA 
weapons are so honored and legendary, the secondary spirit 
usually does not mind sharing the fetish. 

The difficulty to attack with a Grand Klaive is 7, and it 
inflicts Strength +4 damage. Because it is a silver weapon, 
Garou may not soak this damage. 

Talens 

Below are a number of sample talens. The Storyteller 
should feel free to create more, bearing in mind that they 
are always one-shot items. 

Gane Arrows 

Gnosis 4 

These obsidian-headed arrows are able to seek out and 
home in on Banes, whether or not they are visible. These 
arrows automatically hit and inflict three dice of aggravated 


damage. Furthermore, the bite of a Bane arrow is so painful 
that no Bane can resist howling in agony. 

Tocreate a Bane Arrow, one of the following spirit types 
must be bound into the arrow: War, Air or Pain. 


(Death (Dust 


Gnosis 6 

This small jar of dust, when broken open, activated and 
sprinkled over the body of a recently (within a day) dead 
creature, allows the wielder to communicate with the spirit 
of the corpse. 

To create Death Dust, one of the following spirit types 
must be bound into the jar: Death, Communication, or 
Divination. 


Moon Glow 


Gnosis 8 
This is a single moonbeam caught within a small crystal. 
Upon embarking on a journey into the Umbra, the wielder

may activate this talen from Luna. So long as it is continu-

Moon Sign 


Gnosis 5 

This small waxen seal bears the sign of the full moon.

Garou must make a Willpower roll (difficulty 7) or imme-

To create a Moon Sign, one of the following spirit types

Nightshade 


Gnosis 5 

This talen is distilled from the very essence of night. One 
fluid ounce of this liquid, when quaffed, turns the imbiber's 
body into shadow, rendering her virtually invisible in 
darkness. This effect wears off after an hour. 

To create Nightshade, one of the following spirit types 
must be bound into a vial: Night, Hiding, or Darkness. 


Wyrm Scale 


Gnosis 8 

Thissigil is imbued with a limited resistance against the 
power of the Wyrm. Servants of the Wyrm will, when the 
sigil is activated, revert to their true forms. However, this 
action alerts the Wyrm to the existence of the sigil, and the 
sigil will thereupon be consumed in a blaze of flames. 

To create a Wyrm Scale, a Wyrm spirit must be bound 
into the sigil.

Central Park: A Setting 
for Werewolf 


on a nice afternoon, 
to go poisoning pigeons in the park... 
—Tom Lehrer 

The following is a sample setting for Werewolf: The 
Apocalypse. Below you will find all the information you 
need to begin a chronicle in New York's Central Park. 
Several brief adventure ideas are given at the end of this 
section. 

Keep in mind as you design adventures for your pack that 
the Gothic-Punk world differs from our own. The influence 
of supernatural forces has shaped and molded the course of 
history. There are numerous differences between the New 
York of the World of Darkness and our own Big Apple. For 
instance, in our world, New York is slowly winning the 
battle to restore Central Park. Olmstead and Vaux's origi- 
nal vision is being restored. In the World of Darkness, much 
ofthe needed financial and political assistance never came. 
The fight to keep the park alive is entirely up to the Garou, 
and they have remade parts of the park for their own uses. 
In this world, Central Park is slowly falling apart, crime in 
the neighborhood is on the rise, and the forces of the 
Weaver and the Wyrm are slowly encroaching. 

However, there have been some changes for the better. 
Automobiles are not present in the park. Horses and horse- 
drawn carriages are more common (despite the horses’ 
occasional tendency to spook at the scent of werewolves), 
and the roads for automobile traffic that run through the 
middle of the real Central Park were never built in the 
Gothic-Punk world. The residents of New York don't drive 
through the park anymore; some are used to the idea of 
riding in a taxi to the edge of the park, hopping in a horse- 
drawn carriage fora ride across the park and hailing another 
cab on the other side. This has decreased pollution and 
made the park more peaceful. The world of the werewolves 
is dangerous, but it is not without victories. 

Central Park is a refuge of wilderness surrounded by the 
madness of civilization — a source of life and energy in the 
midst ofa prison of rigid order and conformity. Anyone who 
walks into Central Park enters a slightly different reality: 
vibrant, living and energetic, but also violent, unpredict- 
able and grim. The world of the humans is left behind. The 
world of the Garou lies ahead. 

Watch your step. 


Sept of the Green 


Caern: The Central Park Caern, Central Park, New 
York 

Level: 3 

Gauntlet: 3 

Type: Fellowship 


| 


The caern was originally dedicated to the Wyld, but as 
the city grew around the caern, the forces of the Weaver 
reduced its power. After the Bone Gnawers started to care 
for the dying caern, a second totem was brought into the 
park. Now the location acts as a magnet, drawing Garou 
together. Indeed, the caern is nicknamed "The Melting Pot 
Caern,” because of its open policy and location near what 
was once the immigrant capital of North America. 

Caerns of Fellowship are sites where Garou can celebrate 
their diversity and set aside their differences. The caern is 
a gathering place for many important regional moots. The 
points gained from activating the caern (see Rite of the 
Opened Caern, pp. 140-141) can be added to Expression, 
Performance and Empathy. 

Tribal Structure: Mostly Bone Gnawers, but all tribes 
are represented here. 

Totems: The caern has two totems: Mera, originally 
summoned by the Silver Fangs; and the Great White 
Mouse, who came to the aid of the Bone Gnawers. 


Mera is a powerful water spirit whose domain includes all 
the water that flows through New York City. Water acts as 
a focus for her powers, and her Moon Bridges join several 
bodies of water within the park. 

The Great White Mouse is an old totem fighting to 
survive. His existence predates the origin of the Bone 
Gnawers. He was once a minor totem of the Garou, but 


when the Bone Gnawers formed long ago, the followers of 
Mouse were slain by the Children of Rat. 

The caern's original totem, Mera, was summoned when 
the Silver Fangs first opened the caern in 1855. As the site 
declined, Mera weakened. During the Great Depression, 
however, the number of homeless in the park drastically 
increased, and a great Theurge brought Mouse from the 
depths of the Umbra to help the Bone Gnawers survive. 

Mouse gains power from large gatherings of Garou. 
(Afterall, one mouse can only hide, but a nest of many mice 
can achieve far more to ensure their communal survival.) 
He is meek and unassuming, but his powers are excellent for 
gathering lost Garou together. 


Geography 

Central Park is located in Manhattan. 110th Street (or 
"Central Park North") forms the northern border, and 
visitors can enter from the north through the Farmer's Gate 
or the Warrior's Gate. East 59th Street (or "Central Park 
South") forms the southern border. The Artisan's Gate and 
the Artist's Gate are located here, along with Columbus 
Circle and Grand Army Plaza. The western border of 8th 
Street, with four entrances, is referred to as Central Park 
West, and Fifth Avenue, with five entrances to the park, 
lies along the eastern border. There are many other smaller 
entrances. Refer to the accompanying map for more details.

Grand Army Plaza 


Four horse paths cut across the park from west to east: 
they roughly correspond to 97th Street, 85th Street, 79th 
Street and 65th Street. The Reservoir is the most visible 
landmark, dividing the park in half. 


The Bawn 


The entire park forms the bawn of the caern, allowing 
the Garou to watch the humans quite closely. The force of 
the Wyld is strong here, and it holds the Weaver at bay. The 
Bone Gnawers want the citizens of New York to enjoy the 
serenity of nature while drawing upon the energy of the 
wilderness. The diversity, energy and beauty seen through- 
out Central Park show that their stewardship is working 
quite well. 

At the same time, Garou have a chance to interact with 
(and attempt to understand) humans. People expect un- 
usual things in New York, especially in Central Park, so 
there is a great deal of freedom. The Gnawers’ communal 
attitude and acceptance of everyone is part of the demo- 
cratic spirit pervasive throughout the caern. However, 
despite the liberal nature of Central Park’s Bone Gnawers, 
there are rules governing conduct within the bawn. 


The Center 


The caern actually has two “centers.” The stronger one, 
overseen by Mera, encompasses the Esplanade and Bethesda 
Fountain. The spirit of Mouse can also be summoned near 
the Great Lawn: there is a nexus of energy located under 
nearby Turtle Pond.

Fifth Avenue 


Bethesda Fountain is a focus for Mera’s power. The 
fountain marks the spot where the Silver Fangs first opened 
the caern. Since then, the ground has been covered in 
concrete, but the fountain, named after a place of healing 
in Jerusalem, is still a place of power. The nature of the 
Wyld is alive there, and meditating by the fountain or 
looking out upon the lake gives insight and inspiration to 
troubled souls. 

On one side of the fountain is a huge restored building 
with a massive open area on the ground floor. Staircases 
ascend on either side of the building, and the roof of the 
edifice allows an outstanding view of the surrounding area. 
A lake can be seen on the other side of the fountain; boats 
and canoes from the Loeb Boathouse traverse this body 
during the day. A peninsula extends into the lake. From its 
tip, the Master of the Rite can call upon Mouse or Mera to 
open a Moon Bridge. 

Turtle Pond, the less powerful center, is located at the 
southern edge of the Great Lawn. The Wyld, aided by 
Mera, long ago created a Chimare (a Realm of dreams) 
around the park. Silver Fangs sleeping near the pond had 
incredible, inspirational dreams. Unfortunately, neglect 
has weakened this spiritual power. 

During the Great Depression, many of the city's home- 
less built a shantytown on the Great Lawn. They called it 
“Hooverville.” The Bone Gnawers of the city protected the 
residents. Seeking the wisdom to guide the Bone Gnawers, 
a powerful Theurge (the Reverend Barnaby Morton of the 
Church of Hooverville) slept by the banks of Turtle Pond.

His dreams took him through the Chimare surrounding it 
and led him deep into the Umbra. He quested for anything 
that could help the sept. Deep in a lost Realm, he found the 
lair of Mouse and brought him back to the park. The spirit 
ofthe Great White Mouse now rests beneath Mera's waters, 
dreaming in the Chimare. 


Landmarks 


Dozens of unusual sites grace the park, but each tribe has 
a favorite meeting place. Garou visiting the park are wel- 
come to explore anywhere, but if a pack is trying to find 
members of a particular tribe, it helps to know where to 
look. 

* The Great Lawn — Although Bone Gnawers feel free 
to sleep anywhere and explore all sections of the park, they 
always get nostalgic about the Great Lawn. The grass there 
is among the most carefully tended flora on Earth; in fact, 
a Kinfolk descendant of Olmstead still cares for it. The 
northern end of the lawn has a number of softball fields, but 
the majority ofthe lawn is reserved for picnics and relaxing. 
In the center of the southern part of the lawn is a magnifi- 
centelm tree, the largest in the eastern U.S. Folk entertainers 
and storytellers can often be found there, along with the 
occasional Galliard trying to pick up a few tips about the 
Bone Gnawer art of street performance. 

Another favorite site of the Bone Gnawers is a fetish 
called the Ever Meal, known to many as “The Moldy 
Grail." It isa garbage can that refills empty containers with 
food or drink. Empty cups placed in the Grail are magically 
refilled with soda, and Styrofoam containers become warm. 
again as they are replenished with fast food. Each container

can only be used once, however, and expensive food is 
always replaced with sleazy, yet delectable alternatives. 

* The Great Hill — Wild forests surround this hill, and 
the Black Furies have claimed this area as a gathering place. 
Hidden from prying eyes, they organize occasional religious 
ceremonies and try to avoid the hustle and bustle of the 
park. 

* Strawberry Fields — This is one of the most beautiful 
gardens in the park. It serves as a memorial to John Lennon, 
who was tragically slain outside his nearby home. One 
memorial marker is a round mosaic with one word in the 
center— "Imagine." 

Children of Gaia often meet here to discuss politics and 
news from around the world. Intellectuals discussing phi- 
losophy are common here, as are musicians practicing their 
craft. In addition, the Gauntlet in the middle of these 
gardens has a rating of 3, just like the caern center. 

* Belvedere Castle — Constructed in 1872, this castle 
was one of the park's original buildings. When the Silver 
Fangs controlled the park, many Theurges communed with 
the spirits of rain, wind, thunder and other forces of nature. 
As the Weaver strengthened, the spiritual connection to 
the elements faded, and the castle was converted into a 
weather monitoring station in 1919. 

Thanks to some fancy bureaucratic manipulation from 
Simon Gentle, a local Glass Walker, the facility was reor- 
ganizedsothatall the weather instruments could be operated 
by remote control. The hiring of a Fianna Kinfolk to 
supervise the facility was also fortuitous. 


The Fianna now cc atrol Belvedere Castle. They have 
added a few features t the inside of the castle, including a 
secure “guest room" ‘or important visitors. The Fianna 
demonstrate their hospitality quite well. Among the visi- 
tors to Belvedere Castle in 1993 were two faeries, a group 
of three Dreamspeaker mages hiding from vampires, and 
the ghost of a demented 14th century Irish chieftain, who 
confused the castle with an old haunt of his. 

* Swedish Cottage — This building, constructed in 
Sweden for an exposition in Philadelphia, was moved to 
New York in 1876. When the landmark was refurbished in 
the '80s, it almost became the home of a charming mari- 
onette theater. Unfortunately, the presence of angst-filled 
Germanic headbashers who hung out there discouraged the 
troupe of puppeteers, and they moved to another section of 
the park. Since then, two Get of Fenris Kinfolk have 
opened a German restaurant in the building. It is now the 
best place to get German beer in the park. 

Many Get of Fenris feel uncomfortable in a setting as 
sedate as Central Park. One permanent resident of the sept, 
Wilhelm "Quarterback" Krause, has been trying to coax 
visiting Get to make use of the many athletic fields in the 
park. Rugby and tackle football games become extremely 
violent when the Get play. Krause, however, has been very 
disappointed that he cannot assemble a team of nine Garou 
who can match the Bone Gnawers' "All-American" base- 
ball team. 

The puppeteers, by the way, have moved to the Delacorte 
Theater, although they do compete with the occasional 
Shakespeare Festival. The Theater Building also has an 
amusing German clock. Every hour, a carefully crafted 
animal band circles the clock to the accompaniment of a 
mechanical glockenspiel. 

* "Millionaire Mile" — Throughout the history of the 
park, there has always been a movement to preserve the 
park proper as a place for "The People." However, many 
wealthy organizations and philanthropic individuals have 
fallen into the recurring habit of thinking of the area as 
"their park." Some of the tenants on Millionaire Mile have 
even been known to consider the park a kind of huge 
"backyard." 

Fifth Avenue is home to some very expensive real estate 
overlooking Central Park. The houses and apartments 
owned by thearea’s Glass Walkers are no exceptions. These 
Garou feel much safer transacting their business close to 
the safety to the park, especially with so many Sabbat 
vampires in the city. Simon Gentle holds most Glass 
Walker meetings in his penthouse apartment. A consider- 
able portion of his time is spent getting some of the 
residents of Fifth Avenue, as well as many large corpora- 
tions, to direct their time and resources toward keeping the 
park alive. 

* Central Park Zoo — The old zoo met with great 
approval when it opened, but eventually became one of the 
greatest tragedies of the park. Animal activists (including 
some Kinfolk) were quite vocal in their opposition to many

p/m. am, EN mar n ————— À 


of the zoo’s inhumane practices. Under the subtle direction 
of the Garou, the new zoo serves both the animals and the 
werewolves quite nicely. A Kinfolk of the Get of Fenris 
works as a night watchman, and a Kinfolk of the Children 
of Gaia oversees the wolf enclosure. 

Many Red Talons hate visiting the park, mainly because 
the sept forbids any Garou to wander freely in Lupus form. 
Only one Red Talon permanently resides in the park: 
Spotlight, who sleeps in the zoo by day and patrols the 
Ramble by night. However, the Kinfolk night watchman 
has been known to allow visiting werewolves to roam freely 
behind the locked gates of the zoo at night, so long as they 
stay clear of the animal enclosures. The carefully orches- 
trated arrangement has worked well so far. 

* The Ramble — During the day, the Ramble is a scenic 
area, ideal for leisurely strolls. Birdwatchers are especially 
fond of the area. At night, however, the Ramble becomes 
one of the most dangerous parts of the park. This is partly 
because of the nightly patrols of the Red Talon, Spotlight 
(mentioned above). Many New Yorkers tell horror stories 
about violent crimes committed in the Ramble. Part of this 
also stems from the effects of the Delirium. 

However, something very dangerous is indeed occurring 
in the Ramble. Some of the sequestered areas of this 
labyrinth provide meeting places for the Shadow Lords who 
visit the park. Spotlight has become part of their con- 
spiracy, and he keeps an eye out for anyone who would 
interfere with these machinations. More details are in- 
cluded in the section on “Personalities” below. 

* The Obelisk, “Cleopatra’s Needle" — One of the 
most spectacular monuments in the park was a gift from the 
Khedive of Egypt in 1877. The 71-foot Egyptian obelisk was 
a monument to King Thometes III and was built around 
1600 B.C. The obelisk, known to many as "Cleopatra's 
Needle," has a sinister history; it is rumored that over a 
dozen men died transporting it to the United States. 

Many of the hieroglyphics carved on its pink granite 
surface have eroded, but a plaque donated from Cecil B. de 
Mille contains an (alleged) translation. There is also an 
account of several lead-covered time capsules buried under 
the monument. This document lists many bizarre items 
buried underneath, including a ship's propeller, a copy of 
the U.S. Constitution, a freshly made anchor, a copy of 
Webster's Dictionary, and a collection of the works of 
William Shakespeare. This account is, of course, com- 
pletely fabricated. Only a few Garou know what's really 
buried under Cleopatra's Needle. 

Every three months, a different Silent Strider messenger 
visits the caern and waits by the obelisk for an entire 
afternoon. The tribe also retains the right to perform 
undisturbed rituals by the monument in the middle of the 
night. The Striders will not, however, explain why the 
rituals are needed. Other Striders are asked to perform. 
mysterious missions involving the obelisk, missions even 
those who perform them do not understand. Despite inves- 


tigation by various members of the sept, the secrets of the 
obelisk have been kept. 

* Cherry Hill — Cherry Hill sees quite a bit of traffic, 
mainly from horses and carriages. The fountain there once 
served as a trough for passing horses. It is also a favorite 
resting place for the only Silver Fang permanently residing 
in the park. Alexandra Zamyatin is a Galliard who loves to 
tell tales about the history of park, including stories dating 
back to the time when the Silver Fangs cared for it. 

Alexandra is also a fanatic equestrian. She loves to go for 
long rides on the horse trails throughout the park. A four- 
and-a-half-mile track runs along the periphery of most of 
the park. Any visiting Silver Fangs will be invited to 
accompany her on a ride. 

* Zan Shu, Greatest of the Elusive Treehouses — Over 
a period of eight years, the police in Central Park were 
confronted with a very adventurous and ambitious indi- 
vidual. Someone was covertly building treehouses in the 
park. Each house was camouflaged and carefully placed, 
and police often had trouble finding the latest project. 

The first houses were destroyed, but the police later 
proved reluctant to look too closely into the incidents. This 
is because the builder of these treehouses had friends: he 
was a Kinfolk of a Stargazer living at the sept. Several of the 
houses are still secretly hidden. Late at night, Crinos 
werewolves hide on the rooftops and gaze at the stars. A 
total of 13 treehouses have been built; the most elaborate 
is a two-story, five-room house near 79th Street. 


* Sheep Meadow — This is the most meditative section 
ofthe park. The area is officially a “quiet zone": loud music 
and noisy conversations are not tolerated here. Stargazers 
and Children of Gaia enjoy this location, but Wendigo are 
the werewolves most commonly found here. Many visitors, 
including humans, are oddly affected by spending an after- 
noon in the meadow. The spirituality in the meadow is 
strong, and many people completely forget about the mod- 
ern world while they rest within. No one ever leaves with 
a violent thought. 

However, if any Garou is in the meadow at midnight 
during a time corresponding to her auspice, the area be- 
comes a focal point for the energies of the Wyld. Shocking 
scenes are witnessed in the middle of the field. Brutal 
visions of the past, and sometimes of distant eras, come to 
life. The individual who sparked these visions often re- 
ceives insight into her present situation and sometimes 
even a prophecy of her future. For this reason, Garou often 
meetaround this time to create the proper environment for 
oneofthese visions. The Delirium conceals their activities. 

* Harlem Meer — This lake has undergone many 
changes. The most recent one involved lowering the water 
to create an island spanning a quarter of an acre in the 
middle of the lake. An underwater fence prevents boaters 
or canoers from approaching the island...unless they know 
the secret of getting there. Tall reeds obscure the center of 
the island, and a few Uktena occasionally gather there to 
meet in privacy. 


Other Locations 


* Wollman Memorial Rink — The Garou considered 
this artificial ice rink to be an ugly blight on the park and 
were happy when it closed. Unfortunately, Donald Trump 
financed its restoration a few years ago. The ice rink is quite 
busy during the winter; it also converts into (gasp) a 
miniature golf course during the rest of the year. 

* Chess House — Many elderly people frequent this 
location, and chess and checker sets can be checked out for 
free. Certain Garou are devoted chess players (and crafty 
characters can learn about their personalities by challeng- 
ing them to a game or two). 

* The Dairy — This now serves as an Information 
Center, and general information about the park is easily 
found — Tuesday through Friday during partial business 
hours, of course. 

* Police Precinct — There isa police patrol in the park. 
A Glass Walker Kinfolk on the force helps keep the Glass 
Walkers informed of police activity. Additionally, any 
Glass Walker can easily monitor their radio traffic. 

* Metropolitan Museum of Art — This huge museum 
holds a variety of exhibits, including a room recreating an 
Egyptian temple from the same era as Cleopatra's Needle. 


Umbrascape 


The physical world is only one part of the caern. Hidden 
in the Umbra, the force of the Wyld struggles to emerge 
intothephysical world. Conversely, the force ofthe Weaver 
can be seen outside the park, waiting for the opportunity to 
rush in and impose its stasis. Garou traveling into the 
Penumbra can see the spiritual roots of the activity within 
the bawn, as well as representations of the battle between 
the Weaver and Wyld. Some examples are listed below. 

* Turtle Pond: Anyone peering deeply into the pond 
will see a shifting white mass at the bottom. Further 
examination reveals the spirits of hundreds and hundreds of 
tiny white mice climbing over each other. There is the faint 
stench of a mouse nest, and a frightened, childlike voice is 
sometimes heard singing from the depths. 

* Belvedere Castle: The elements are strong here. On 
tempestuous days, elemental forces batter against the battle- 
ments of the castle. A thread of electrical energy (a data 
stream) spurts from the castle, but the spirit of the Wyld can 
be sensed glowing warmly behind the castle walls. 

* Fifth Avenue: Everything is orderly and precise. Long 
threads stretch along the street, struggling to keep the 
traffic flowing in regular patterns. The bright green energy 
of the forest quickly fades into life-sapping gray. Spirits 
trapped in nearby stoplights shout one-word commands. 
About once a week, a foolish Pattern Spider will make a 
desperate foray into the park, only to be consumed by the 
Wyld. 

* Zachary Ellison: This agent of the Shadow Lords 
(listed below) is continually surrounded by a cloud of

darkness. Banes hover around him, whispering dangerous 
and obscene thoughts. His determination and spiritual 
focus hold them at bay. 

* Bethesda Fountain: An aura of healing surrounds the 
fountain. The concrete around it ripples like water, and the 
whole area is more than alive: it's capricious, contempla- 
tive, mysterious and rejuvenating. Waves on the nearby 
lake roll from the peninsula into a huge whirlpool; this 
watery vortex marks the spot where Moon Bridges are 
strongest. 

* Wollman Rink: Layers of spiderwebs and dancing 
fields of electricity elementals hold the Pattern in place. 
The Weaver knits its Pattern over the Earth and yearns to 
spread further into the park. Naturae scream under the 
webbing, and Blight Children skate merrily on the surface 
of the ice, mocking any Garou who come nearby. 

Beneath the ice, in a frozen Blight, reside the Dark 
Trinity, the three Banes who work in concert to destroy the 
Garou (see Dark Trinity, pp. 272-273). This Blight can only 
be entered by breaking a hole in the Penumbral ice. Even 
then, invaders must travel icy caverns and suffer frigid 
temperatures to reach the actual lair deep beneath. 


History 


During the history of the Garou, there have been fewer 
than 20 Imperial Moots. One such moot was held on 
Manhattan Island in 1855. To quell the expansion of the 
cities, the Silver Fangs audaciously dedicated caern in the 
middle of the country's largest city. No revel had ever been 
greater. After an unheard-of expenditure of Gnosis, a caern 
of the Wyld, dedicated to Mera, was created. 

New York City’s government was certain that no busi- 
nesses would want to develop the area. Squatters had 
already built makeshift homes; open drains and sewer 
tunnels were quite visible. The city set aside over 800 acres 
fora park. A prize of $2,000 was offered for the design of the 
park, and out of about 20 entries, one outstanding design 
was chosen (with a little assistance from Kinfolk). The 
winners of the competition were Calvert Vaux, a Kinfolk of 
the Glass Walkers; and Frederick Law Olmstead, a Kinfolk 
of the Bone Gnawers. Both aspired to create a nurturing, 
thriving natural place for the people of New York. 

Between 1858 and 1874, the park was built. The Silver 
Fangs “oversaw” the whole process, but the process of 
integrating a caern into the middle of a city was slightly 
beyond their ken. They became less enthusiastic about the 
idea, and the Weaver was happy to work around their 
lassitude. The Glass Walkers and Bone Gnawers of the city, 
however, felt right at home. The totem, Mera, was ne- 
glected, but the children of the Cockroach and the Rat 
thrived. The Silver Fangs’ optimistic aspirations of re- 
claiming the land fell by the wayside. 

As Mera was neglected, the force of the Wyld began to 
diminish within the park. The few Bone Gnawers who 
actually lived in the park were very disorganized, and their 


| 


apathy grew until the tragedy of the Great Depression hit 
New York City. The number of homeless grew, and the 
power of the Rat was taxed heavily. Bone Gnawers helped 
erect acity of homeless, called *Hooverville," on the Great 
Lawn. Their support of the "city" demonstrated that the 
park was really for all the residents of New York, including 
the city's poor. 

A powerful Bone Gnawer Theurge living in Hooverville 
often slept by the side of Turtle Pond, seeking inspiration 
for his weekly sermons. One dream led him far into the 
Umbra, where he found an ancient and neglected totem 
sleeping. The Theurge awakened the Great White Mouse 
from his slumber and accompanied him on an epic journey 
through the Umbra, showing him how the world had 
changed. Together they returned to the Chimare near 
Turtle Pond. Mouse aided the Bone Gnawers in their time 
of need and has since become a second totem of the sept. 

The Weaver's encroachment continued throughout the 
20th century. Numerous outrageous plans for the park were 
advanced. Examples included: the construction of an air- 
plane landing field; a WWI Memorial consisting of extensive 
trenches; a vast circus ground; and an underground parking 
lot for 30,000 cars. Carefully orchestrated interference 
from the city’s Glass Walkers prevented these plans from 
coming to fruition. 

Maintenance of the park was another problem. Without 
sufficient funds for upkeep, the park would stagnate. The 
wealthy did have plans for the park, but many of these plans 


Appendix 


did not take into account the city as a whole. Arguments 
over whom the park should really serve vitiated the strength 
of its support. A few Glass Walkers valiantly fought to keep 
the park funded, but by the mid-20th century, the park was 
again dying. 

Restoration has been a long and painful process, but the 
park is gradually being reclaimed. There are many flaws the 
casual visitor doesn't notice. Buildings are crumbling, and 
restoration groups fight to stop the old buildings from being 
razed. New constructions are rare. Dedicated volunteers 
organize a wide variety of festivals and events to draw 
support for the park. Millions of people visit the park each 
year, and the wear and tear on the facility is overwhelming. 
TheSeptofthe Green continues the fight to keep the spirit 
of the park alive. 


«Che Sept 


The Sept of the Green is unusual, mainly because of the 
diverse Garou living there. Most caerns are dominated by 
one or two tribes, but the Bone Gnawers are anything but 
elitist with regard to such matters. Anyone is welcome to 
visit and (hopefully) learn. 

Casual, democratic sept government results in very little 
open conflict over howto run the caern. Conflict, however, 
does occur. Outside the formal meetings, rivalries and 
misunderstandings are waged in secret. Most Garou machi- 


283 


L 


G Nt 
v. HM 


nations are not brought to the sept meetings, and mysteries 
lie shrouded beneath the caern's placid appearance. 


7 


Most of the permanent residents of the caern don’t 
concern themselves overmuch with long-term problems. 
For them, a chance to help visitors to the park learn and 
grow is quite enough. Others are amazingly individualistic, 
caring little about "the big picture." 

Some individuals, however, have other plans... 


Uisiting the Caern 


Any visitors to the caern will quickly learn a few rules of 
etiquette. Mother Larissa and Spotlight oversee the 
Chiminage the sept receives. Any Garou passing through 
the park or visiting for the day should leave a gift in the 
Ramble with either Mother Larissa or Spotlight. The na- 
ture of this gift largely depends on the caern’s current needs, 
although items for the homeless — food, clothes, blankets 
and so on — are always greatly appreciated. If money is 
donated, Simon Gentle will make sure it goes toward the 
maintenance of the park. 

Any Garou who plans to spend the night should also 
offer to tell a story by the great elm near the Great Lawn. 
The tale-teller has the option of telling a story with humans 
present. This is usually a story that does not betray the 
secrets of Garou society, but still encourages a better under- 
standing of nature. 


Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


W 


Spotlight fanatically preserves Central Park's Veil. Fright- 
ening people in the park isstrictly forbidden, and, regardless 
of the Delirium, Garou are heavily discouraged from mani- 
festing their Crinos forms. Punishment is either banishment 
or, in extreme cases, death. Spotlight can be very cruel and 
creative with his punishments. 


Those who work well with the sept are occasionally 
offered membership. Joining the Sept of the Green requires 
giving a point of Gnosis to the Great White Mouse or 
presenting the sept with a fetish. The prospective member 
must demonstrate how he can benefit the sept.

Image: Many of the people in Central Park overlook 
Mother Larissa the first time they visit. She'sa small, skinny 
bag lady who patrols the park while pushing a battered 
shopping cart. Her routine includes picking up empty food 
containers from trash cans (she later brings the containers 
to the Ever Meal near the Great Lawn). 

In Homid form, she usually wears ill-fitting polyester 
clothing, orthopedic shoes and tacky accessories. (She has 
a stockpile of used pantyhose hidden under a rock.) In 
Lupus form, she is a small, sleek wolf with a mangy coat of 
brown fur. In any form she appears old, worn-out and 
crotchety, but she practically glows with youth when given 
the chance to take care of someone. 

Roleplaying Hints: Everyone is younger than you. There- 
fore, everyone owes you respect! Stare at anyone who 
speaks to you. Stare at them until you realize what's wrong 
with them. Everyone has a flaw, and if you look hard 
enough, you'll see one. Smile knowingly when you know 
you're right (which is, of course, all of the time). Don't 
forget to play up the whole "crusty old witch" routine. Bah- 
ha-ha-ha! 

You are in charge, and you have a large number of Bone 
Gnawers backing you up to prove it. No Get of Fenris is too 
mighty to have his ear tugged if he's out of line. No Silver 
Fangis too glorious to avoid being chewed out. Remember, 
Mother knows best. 

History: Mother Larissa is over 70 years old. She is the 
last surviving pupil of the Bone Gnawers who originally 
governed the caern. She's a survivor, but she's willing to do 
whatever it takes to maintain the caern. Ensuring the 
survival of the park is more than her job — it's her destiny. 

All Garou defer to her leadership, and many humans 
enjoy her bizarre stories. She may threaten a lot, but she's 
not violent. Just in case, though, she's hidden a Grand 
Klaive in a shrubbery by the Ramble.
