Adventure Jdeas 


+ Unholy Rites — Several Silent Striders arrive in Central 
Park. They demand the right to perform rites around the 
Egyptian Obelisk, and to do so undisturbed. Mother Larissa 
has given permission and won't listen to Fengy's reports of 
"dark energies gathering around the obelisk." The Silent 
Striders plan to draw upon something buried beneath the 
monument, and the players must stop them from unleashing 
something they don't truly understand. 

* The “Fisher” Thing — Old Penn is a homeless man 
who often goes fishing by Turtle Pond every day at noon 
and then falls asleep. One day, after a disturbing dream, he 
fishes an old wooden sword out of the pond silt. He manages 
to stir up some of the park’s regulars, and for some reason, 
they start talking about a “new kingdom.” Banes are hover- 
ing around Penn, and they've got him convinced he's the 
next King Arthur... 

* Spirit Journey — An injured member of the pack tries 
to meditate by Bethesda Fountain...and it dries up! The 
pack is given one day to find out why, or their packmate will 
lose a lot of Honor for harming the center of the caern. The 
answer lies in the Umbra: someone has broken a forgotten 
taboo of the park. 

* Breakout! — The Glass Walker Kinfolk at the Police 
Precinct reports that a Garou has been arrested. The police 
are cracking down on transients in the park, and the players 
have a chance to gain some Honor by freeing the septmate 
and discouraging the police. 

* Competition — The Galliard Alexandra Zamyatin is 
hostingastorytelling competition, and high-ranking mem- 
bers of the other auspices follow suit by staging similar 
events. The characters have a chance to compete against a 
variety of Garou and demonstrate their skills. 


288 


Yara mri mr TA ——————— À 


e In the Shadows... — By a statue of the Mad Tea Party, 
Zachary Ellison is seen conversing with strange men in 
black. They're talking about breaking into the Metropoli- 
tan Museum. The word “temple” is overheard. What strange 
plot is this? 

* Ugly Tourists — A pack of crass Garou is visiting the 
park, and its members don't seem to care much for the sept's 
rules. Mother Larissa assigns the characters the task of 
watching over the visitors to make sure nothing dangerous 
happens. 

* Gang War — Two rival gangs have foolishly decided 
to start a war in Central Park. The characters are the first 
to find out; they can gain some quick Honor if they avert it. 
What happens when the pack's Theurge detects a 
Psychomachiae? 

* Monkeywrenching — Simon Gentle tips off the pack 
that a corporation is trying to open a ridiculous new 
building in the park (this could be a video arcade, roller 
coaster, video wall, etc.). The story hasn't hit the media yet, 
but the contracts are nearly finalized. 

* Black and White and Red All Over — A sleazy 
journalist is hacking out an article plugging his thrilling 
new novel, Werewolves of Central Park! Most of his work is 
shoddy, but he does have quite a bit of “evidence,” includ- 
ing a photo of one of the characters. He thinks the pack's 
Philodox is the "King of the Werewolves." Now he's got 
some toughs backing him up, and he wants to "negotiate" 
a deal whereby he can get some real information about 
what's going on in the park... 


Inside the World of 
(Darkness 


Each game in the Storyteller Series has been designed as 
a unique, stand-alone system. This means that each game, 
be it Vampire: The Masquerade, Werewolf: The Apoca- 
lypse, Mage: The Ascension or any of the others, can be 
played without the rest. We at White Wolf expect that 
most people will find one of the games to be their favorite 
and will not need the others. 

However, we have also designed the games to interlink. 
They share the same world (the World of Darkness), the 
same systems and the same vision. Adding vampires to a 
Werewolf chronicle, either as villains or as characters for 
the players, does not require much work for the Storyteller. 
By the same token, mages have as great an interest in the 
spirit Realms as the Garou do. 

While Storytellers do not need the other games to add 
such supernatural beings to their stories, Vampire or Mage 
will help them add a great deal of depth to these characters. 
Because it is impossible to summarize the two games com- 
pletely herein, this section assumes that the Storyteller has 
access to them and is not relying on the information given 
earlier in the Appendix. 


Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


Adding Antagonists 


Vampires, mages, faeries, ghosts, mummies and other 
creatures have plenty of reasons to interact with werewolves. 
These are the secret lords of the world, and their fiefdoms 
tend to overlap. Uktena and Glass Walkers have the most 
reasons to deal with vampires, but that does not mean other 
Garou never meet the undead. 

The important fact to remember when adding vampires 
to a Werewolf chronicle is that while werewolves are 
masters of combat, vampires are masters of manipulation. 
It's all well and fine that a Rank Three Get of Fenris 
Ahroun can deal out enough damage to sink a destroyer, 
but when the vampire neonate activates her power of 
Entrancement, the werewolf becomes a slobbery puppy 
dog, doing anything to please his mistress. 

Werewolves have little chance against vampires who are 
aware of them. Phalanxes of ghouls load their shotguns 
with 00 silver buckshot. Tremere begin ancient rituals 
designed to cause the Garou more pain than a dozen battle 
scars ever could. Elders use their vitae to increase their 
Attributes astronomically, until they’re the equivalent of 
an entire pack, 

Additionally, when werewolves and vampires meet in a 
social setting, the Kindred have a decided advantage. They 
tule the cities, and the Garou swiftly discover that the 
Gauntlet tends to be strongest in those places the Kindred 
make their havens — business districts, centers of govern- 


ment and the like. Of course, if the vampire can trick or 
convince a werewolf to drink her blood three times, the 
Blood Bond makes the entire issue moot. 

None of this means, of course, that vampires are immune 
to werewolves. Werewolves are infamous among the Kin- 
dred for the destruction they have wrought. Whole cities of 
Kindred have been wiped out in war with the Garou. But 
neither should Garou underestimate the powers of the 
undead. 

Mages, also no match for werewolves in a toe-to-toe 
fight, have their own ways to best their foes. While an 
entire werewolf pack is likely too much for a mage, and a 
single werewolf can probably destroy a mage in combat, 
mages usually make sure they never face such a fate in the 
first place. Shapeshifters at odds with spell casters find that 
the “little things” start going against them. Then they find 
themselves inexplicably stuck in Lupus form. Finally, the 
next time they have to relieve themselves, they discover a 
high-voltage line hidden under them. 

The important thing to remember when adding antago- 
nists from other Storyteller games is that each group has its 
own area of power. Werewolves control the wilderness, and 
anyone caught in their territory has bitten off much more 
than he can chew (pun intended). The Garou, however, 
are out of their element when they visit the cities of the 
Kindred, the sanctums of the mages, the lands of the dead 
or the homes of the fey. 


TD. o 


Adding Characters 

Allowing players to import other supernatural beings 
into a Werewolf chronicle creates even more complica- 
tions, but is often well worth it. A clique drawn from a 
number of alien cultures is an especially volatile mixture, 
and that's always fun. When vampires and werewolves 
must set aside their differences in order to deal with a more 
pressing problem, they learn that they can work together— 
sometimes. 

This sort of mix works best if the players enjoy roleplaying 
amongst themselves and the Storyteller is not afraid to let 
the players tell some of the stories. A mixed troupe must 
deal with a lot of basic issues, such as the vampires’ ties to 
the Wyrm, the extra powers vampires get by drinking 
Garou blood, how much Quintessence the mages could 
steal by killing their allies, and so on. 

Such a group will spend a lot of its time figuring out how 
the characters feel about each other, what ties keep them 
together, and why they don’t screw each other over at a 
moment's notice — or, more likely, how they screw each 
other over. The Storyteller should create an appropriate 
setting and interesting events to prod things along. For 
instance, if the vampires’ main nemesis among the elders 
has made a deal with Pentex to destroy the werewolves’ 
caern, then both sets of characters must come to some sort 
of accord to stop this threat. This “temporary” truce may 


290 


prove more lasting, allowing vampires and werewolves to 
work together in the future. 

Storytellers do not have to give the players the luxury of 
choice, however, and a number of fun stories involve the 
characters having no option but to cooperate. For instance, 
a powerful hunter sees no difference between Kindred and 
Garou (“Demon spawn! All demon spawn!”), and begins to 
slay vampires and werewolves alike. When the characters 
finally defeat the hunter after an epic conflict, they dis- 
cover that he left a trail — and now the Inquisition is 
coming after them. Divided the characters fall; united they 
survive. 

Hopefully, as time goes by, each side learns enough about 
the other to find common ground. Perhaps when the 
Brujah decides to devote herself to battling Pentex, the 
Stargazer finds a way to aid her on her quest for Golconda. 
Maybe the Glass Walker turns to the Ventrue to fight a 
hostile takeover of his software company; in return, the 
Ventrue asks the Glass Walker to spy on her Nosferatu 
enemies. 

Mages also have a lot to offer other supernatural beings, 
and many reasons to seek their help. The war against the 
Technocracy makes for strange bedfellows, and a Euthanatos 
may find a certain poetic justice in enlisting vampires to 
fight the Syndicate. A Dreamspeaker could require Garou 
help to stop an Iteration X plot. Both Garou and Kindred 
could use magickal help to fight their foes. 


Werewolf: The Apocalypse 


Modifying the Systems 


One problem Storytellers and players have when using 
characters from the different games is the difference in 
Traits. Werewolves do not worry about their ties to humans 
(Humanity), but are very concerned about their ties to the 
Umbra (Gnosis). Mages do not explode in Rage (not 
quantifiably, anyway), but they do accidentally summon 
Paradox spirits when they work some of their magicks — 
something that does not happen to werewolves and vam- 
pires. 

This becomes a problem when somebody's Discipline or 
Gift hasa difficulty based on a Trait not found in the other 
system. Storytellers have a number of ways to resolve this 
problem; the easiest is to replace the Trait with another. For 
instance, when a kindly Theurge uses the Mother's Touch 
Giftona vampire or mage, he can use a number of different 
Traits to replace Rage. Most basically, he can opt to have 
the Theurge roll against Willpower. 


Appendix 


On the other hand, if a vampire uses the Presence power 
of Majesty against a werewolf, the Garou does not have a 
Courage Virtue to use against it. Thus, the werewolf would 
roll his Rage, or half his Rage, or any other Trait the 
Storyteller desired. When in doubt, Willpower (difficulty 
6) is generally a fair default. 

Storytellers should not feel afraid to fiddle with the 
systems in this manner. If mages walk all over werewolves, 
give the Garou an inherent resistance to magick, perhaps 
equal to Gnosis or Willpower + 3. On the other hand, if the 
werewolf pack keeps slashing up the mages before they have 
achance to do anything, allow the spell casters to soak with 
Life Sphere * Stamina instead of just Stamina. The Story- 
teller System is flexible and should always be treated that 
way. 


p 


(Developer's Notes 


Werewolf has come a long way in the nearly two years 
since its initial release. As of this Second Edition, 16 
supplementary products have been released for the game — 
one approximately every month and a half! That's a hefty 
schedule by industry standards. But it's not time to slow 
down yet. We're only getting started. 

When deciding what to change for the Second Edition, 
one guideline superseded all other considerations: I didn't 
want to contradict the supplements we've put out so far. 
There's some damn good stuff in those books. This didn't 
hold me back, however, in changing what was necessary. 

Which brings me to my second guideline: compatibility 
with other Storyteller games. It is necessary that Werewolf 
share the same overall rules with Vampire and Mage, 
especially the combat rules. When Garou and Kindred 
clash, there has to be a common ground, and the rules are 
it. Werewolf Second Edition combat is now fully compat- 
ible with Vampire Second Edition and Mage. 

And my third guideline: Garou culture. The Garou fight 
a lot, but that's not all they do. They have a culture and 
society with depth and meaning. I tried to represent this 
more in the Second Edition, from the expanded descrip- 


————— 


tions of what Garou do during their rituals to the rules and 
regulations they impose on auspice roles — like most 
"primitive" cultures, the Garou expect members of society 
to live up to their birthrights, even if they don't always like 
it. Part of roleplaying a Garou is putting up with societal 
taboos. The energy from this repression is fueled into the 
fight against the Wyrm — all their anger is directed at an 
outside foe. At least, that's the theory; in practice, this 
doesn't work well for the Garou. 

In addition, the Garou's dealings with spirits have been 
emphasized. Spirits teach werewolves their powers, their 
Gifts. Garouarea part ofa living world, an animistic society 
where they are but one of Gaia's many lifeforms. They must 
interact with this forgotten world in order to save it. If the 
spirits die, so does the Garou's link to spiritual power. 

I want to thank all the Werewolf players who supported 
the game in its first two years; their dedication to the game 
anddesire to improve it made this Second Edition possible. 
I also want to give a grateful thanks to all the authors and 
artists who contributed to this book. The respect and care 
that went into itare testaments to their professionalism and 
talent. 


Bill Bridges 


Afterword 


This morning I awoke in a blue funk. My head was 
full of static; my thoughts were blurred. The noise and 
motion of the modern world had become too much for 
me to take. Life had worn me down. Before I had even 
crawled out of bed, I found myself unable to face the 
day. 

After finally getting to work I wasn't feeling any 
better. Writing was out of the question. What was the 
point of it anyway? I didn’t want to throw away my 
time, but I knew I wouldn’t be productive for a while. 
So I decided to go on a journey. There is nothing 
better than to explore, adventure, and quest. 

Because the weather was as bleak as my mood, I 
wound up in the dark recesses of my hard drive. For the 
first time in years | opened my “Stray Thoughts” 
folder, where I throw everything that doesn't have a 
home. It was like entering a crypt, there was such a 
bewildering cornucopia of files. There was Life Phi- 
losophy, Why Life Sux and a series named Brave New 
Thoughts 1, 2, 3, etc. There are few things I find more 
humiliating than reading the unedited gibberish and 
schlock which I once thought were “pearls of wis- 
dom." In a better mood I might have given myself a 
break, but each file made me more demoralized. I 
couldn't believe how banal and pathetic my thoughts 
were. 

Then, I opened a file called "Design Precepts." 
Inside I found some of the first words I had ever written 
for Werewolf. Here, wonders of wonders, was some- 
thingrealand true, and (most importantly) interesting 
to me. It consisted of seven fundamental themes and 
concepts in Werewolf which I wanted to remind 
myself of. Points to keep me on track. Here's that file, 
just as I found it: 

Design Precepts: 

1) Elegantly Simple: the rules need to be simple, 
but in a beautiful way. No excess or stray rules of any sort 
can be tolerated. Every rule needs to apply to the basic 
rules system. 

2) KISS: We want this game to be even simpler 
than Vampire; we need to keep the complexity level way 
down. 

3) Violence: This is a game about tragic, epic 
battle, not about sex . Itis Macbeth, not Romeo and Juliet. 
The difference needs to be constantly apparent, in every 
rule, in every phrase. 

4) Society: Garou society is even more complex 
than Vampire society. Its strictures and standards should 
be demonstrated not so much in rules, but in stories and 


Last Words 


EEE SE PT TR c-———— A 


myths. Players should get a sense of what this bizarre 
society is like from the very first sentence on. 

5) Spirituality: Though much of this game will 
deal with spiritual matters, it needs to be understated: a 
subtext rather than something we hit people over the head 
with. The theme is that spirituality is a private relationship: 
discovered, not taught 

6) Heroics: While tragic, Werewolf is about 
heroes — heroes fighting against an insurmountable evil. 
It's not about winning, it's about doing the right thing. 

7) In your Face: This game needs to be bold and 
brutally honest. The themes and issues should be black and 
white (at least at first glance). 

I was amazed at how well Werewolf seems to 
fulfill these words. Often, when you set out on a 
journey, you end up at a completely different place 
from where you wanted to go. With Werewolf, 
however, through some divine providence, we suc- 
ceeded at what we set out to do. Somehow we stayed 
on course; the dream came true. Perhaps it even had 
something to do with Werewolf's success. It is most 
gratifying to find some evidence that the creative 
process isn't just chaos and blind luck. 

After I finished reading the file, my mood shifted. I 
began to think back to the early days of designing 
Werewolf. My most vivid memory is of a week spent 
alone in an empty office building. White Wolf was a 
tiny enterprise at the time, but still we had grown out 
of our rickety old house. The office building was to be 
our new home, and I moved in ahead of everyone else 
in order to get some peace and quiet for work on 
Werewolf. 

The building wasn't much, little more than a metal 
shed with offices in front and a warehouse in back. 
The wind would blow, making the whole building 
hum. The metal would ripple and rattle the founda- 
tions. All day andall night the building sang to me as 
Father Wind drew his bow back and forth. Fora week 
I lived and wrote in solitude as Caia pressed herself 
against me. 


The building still sings, but you can't hear it any- 
more. The White Wolf offices are too full of noise and 
motion. There is too much energy and life here now. 
No one hears the wind anymore, not even me. 

It is so easy to forget where you are. To forget the 
things that surround and pervade your being. It is so 
easy to get disconnected, to forget your purpose and 
mission. I know I have forgotten. Sometimes I get so 
wrapped up in my thoughts and worries that my soul 


293 


collapses in misery and hunger. It's a fatal distraction, 
a modern disease. 

As I write this, it’s not morning anymore, it's night. 
I'm at White Wolf; no one is here except me and the 
ghosts. I’ve turned off all the computers and all the 
lights. I’ve even unplugged the fridge and microwave. 
There's no sound now, except the wind and the 
shivering of the metal and this pen on paper. The 
world is alive, and I'm a part of it again. Morning is 
only hours away, and I'm glad. 


^ Om. 


Mark ReineHagen 

P.S. In general, I don’t get excited by concerts 
anymore. At one time I went to them to be carried 
away, to be connected to the world — but it so rarely 
happened. Now I have rediscovered an old love, 
thanks to Crash Worship, a very unique band. This 
tribe of drummers reenacts pagan rituals and ancient 
myths. They create a sacred sacrament in a sick world. 
Through a passionate orgy of fire, mud, wine, sweat, 
and dancing in which everyone takes part, they tear 
away your preconceptions and modern arrogance, and 
then bring you back to yourself. The experience is 
more powerful than anything I've encountered before: 
attend at your own risk. 


294 


Bl 


Environmental Action 
Committee 


Our commitment to the environment remains un- 
changed. White Wolf pledges to put 3% of the profits 
from this book toward helping environmental issues. 
That means you are helping by buying this book. 

One of the causes the EAC has been instrumental 
in aiding since its creation is the fight against the 
proposed “wolf kill" in Alaska. The “wolf kill” is a plan 
to murder wolves so that out-of-state hunters will have 
more caribou to hunt. The plan accuses wolves of 
depleting the caribou population, even though scien- 
tific studies show otherwise. As usual, the wolf is the 
first to be blamed for problems. EAC coordinator 
Lyndi Hathaway marshaled her resources to fight this 
proposal, and was definitely heard by the state. While 
Alaska still pushes forward its plans, the resistance is 
greater thanks to Lyndi and the EAC. Updates on 
EAC activities can be found monthly in White Wolf 
Magazine. 

We want your input in this endeavor, and ask that 
you send your suggestions to us at the following ad- 
dress: 

White Wolf EAC 

4598 Stonegate Industrial Boulevard 

Stone Mountain, GA 30083
